Suspect Status:  
The suspect was shot and wounded.  The bullet struck both Mackin’s lungs and was a through 
and through gunshot; however, he is in stable condition and expected to survive. Mackin was 
later released from the hospital and booked into Martinez Detention Facility on 10/16/2023.

INVESTIGATION: 
 
Notification:  
On Sunday, October 1, 2023, at 0930 hours, I received a telephone call at my residence from 
Lieutenant Conaty.  Lieutenant Conaty informed me there had been an officer involved shooting 
in the city of Antioch, which involved four actor officers, and several witnessing officers.  
Lieutenant Conaty advised the suspect had been transported to the hospital and was in critical 
condition.   
 
At approximately 1000 hours, I arrived at the Antioch Police Department.  Upon arrival, I met 
with additional Inspectors from the District Attorney's Office, and Detectives from the Antioch 
Police Department.     
 
At approximately 1200 hours, I attended a briefing conducted by Antioch Police Detective 
Sergeant Colley regarding the shooting and what led up to it.  During the briefing, I learned the 
following information:   
 
On Thursday, September 26, 2023, at approximately 1418 hours, Community Service 
Officer Graham responded to the Cube Smart Self Storage located at 1790 Vineyard 
Drive in the city of Antioch.  CSO Graham was responding to the onsite manager, 
 
DocuSign Envelope ID: 83C48DCC-8B25-4398-B589-898679103D0E
Contra Costa County District Attorney’s Office 
Supplemental Report

13 
, who was reporting a vehicle theft from the location.  At this time, CSO Graham 
reviewed surveillance footage of the vehicle theft, which occurred earlier the same day.  
While reviewing the surveillance footage, CSO Graham saw that on Thursday, September 
26, 2023, at approximately 0130 hours, two unknown male subjects were walking 
around inside the storage yard.  At approximately 0152 hours, a blue or purple panel van 
is seen entering the storage yard via the rear gate, located at the end of Vineyard Drive.  
The panel van then can be seen pushing a white 1987 Chevrolet Monte Carlo (Cal. 
License Plate #
) out of the south gate of the storage yard onto E. 18th Street.  
Once the panel van and the Monte Carlo exited the south gate, CSO Graham was unable 
to see them because it was out of the surveillance camera's view.   
 
advised that nobody had permission to be at the storage yard, at that 
time.   
then provided CSO Graham with the owner of the Monte Carlo 
personal information.  CSO Graham made telephone contact with the owner of the 
Monte Carlo, (
 who currently resides in Florida, and he advised that he 
did not give anyone permission to have his vehicle.  CSO Graham completed a stolen 
vehicle report, and requested the surveillance footage of the incident from Cube Smart 
Self Storage, as evidence of the theft.  CSO Graham later entered the stolen Monte Carlo 
into the Stolen Vehicle System (SVS) and returned to his duties.   
 
On Sunday, October 1, 2023, at approximately 0741 hours, CSO Graham was conducting 
his patrol duties, when he noticed a white Chevrolet Monte Carlo backed into the 
carport of 
  The Monte Carlo was covered with a tarp.  CSO 
Graham noticed a blue panel van backed into the carport next to the Monte Carlo.  CSO 
Graham believed the blue panel van was similar to the one he saw involved with the 
theft of the Monte Carlo on Thursday, September 26, 2023.  Based on this, CSO Graham 
contacted dispatch, and requested assistance from patrol.  K-9 Officer Marques 
responded to assist CSO Graham, as did Officer Dibble, Officer Mulholland, and his 
Trainee Officer Posey.   
 
Officer Marques arrived on the scene followed by Officer Dibble.  The officers 
approached the suspected stolen Monte Carlo, pulled back the tarp, and discovered it 
DocuSign Envelope ID: 83C48DCC-8B25-4398-B589-898679103D0E
Contra Costa County District Attorney’s Office

14 
was unoccupied.  Officer Marques confirmed the Monte Carlo was the stolen vehicle 
CSO Graham had been investigating on Thursday, September 26, 2023.  Officer Marques 
then conducted a record check of the blue panel van which had a license plate of 
.  This vehicle returned with an expired registration in 2018.  Officer Marques 
began looking into the interior of the blue panel van through the side cargo door 
windows on the passenger side.  As Officer Marques did this, he noticed someone (later 
identified as suspect Daniel Mackin) was sleeping in the rear cargo area of the vehicle 
with a handgun lying next to him in plain view.   
 
Officer Marques advised dispatch of this observation, and the officers quickly backed 
away from the suspect vehicle and took cover near their patrol vehicles.  At this point, 
Officer Mulholland and his trainee, Officer Posey arrived on the scene.  Hearing this 
information over the radio, Officer Borg, and his trainee, Officer Armstrong responded as 
well.  Officers noticed that Mackin was now awake, and looking out the front windshield 
at the Antioch Police Officers surrounding the van.  Officers began giving Mackin orders 
to step out of the van with his hands up, however, he did not comply.  Officers Borg and 
Officer Armstrong arrived on the scene and took a position near Officer Marques' patrol 
vehicle.  
 
At this time, Mackin got into the driver's seat of the van and started it.  Mackin then 
attempted to flee, by driving the van through the apartment building's parking lot over a 
curb/green belt area, and onto A Street.  The van then hit a utility box, and a street sign 
pole, at which time it became stuck.  Officers continued to give Mackin orders to come 
out of the van, but Mackin refused.  Mackin began to back up and drive forward several 
times, in an attempt to free the van and escape.  At this time, Officer Mulholland utilized 
a 40mm less lethal weapon to break out the driver's side window of the van.  After four 
unsuccessful attempts to break the van's driver's side window, Mackin fled on foot out 
the side cargo doors of the van.   
 
As Mackin fled from the van he was holding something in his waistband or hooded 
sweatshirt front pocket with his left hand.  As Mackin fled eastbound on A Street, Officer 
Marques deployed his police K-9 to apprehend him.  As Mackin fled he was followed by 
DocuSign Envelope ID: 83C48DCC-8B25-4398-B589-898679103D0E
Contra Costa County District Attorney’s Office 
Supplemental Report 
 
 
 
Subject / Defendant: 
Mackin, Daniel Jackson D.O.B. 8/16/1993 
Docket / Report No. 
Antioch PD Case #23-007441 
Crime Lab Case # 23-3800-1 
DA’s Office Case #23-012 
 
Written By: 
 
Inspector Kirk Sullivan #214 
Date: 10/1/2023 
 
15 
a small dog that had been inside the van.  The small dog distracted the police K-9, which 
prevented the K-9 from apprehending Mackin.  As Mackin ran, the officers could now 
see a chrome handgun in his right hand.   
 
As Mackin continued to run east, he turned several times toward the police officers 
pursuing him, and was now pointing the handgun in their direction.  The pursuing 
officers, then fired several times at Mackin as he fled.  At one point Mackin fell to the 
ground and came to rest in a seated position on the north curbline, still pointing the 
handgun at the officers.  Officers then fired additional shots at Mackin as he got to his 
feet, still pointing the handgun in the direction of pursuing officers.  Mackin continued to 
run eastbound on A Street, with the handgun in his right hand.  As Mackin ran, he threw 
the handgun, over his head in a northern direction.  The handgun landed on the north 
sidewalk of A Street, where it was later recovered fully, loaded with six live rounds.   
 
Once the handgun was discarded, officers verbally announced Mackin had discarded it, 
and no other shots were fired.  Mackin ran approximately another 10-15 yards until he 
came to a stop, went to his knees, and laid down on the ground in the middle of A 
street.  Officers approached Mackin who had sustained one through and through 
gunshot wound to his torso.  Mackin was immediately handcuffed, and emergency 
medical personnel were requested.  Officers obtained a medical kit from a patrol vehicle, 
and began administering first aid.  Fire and ambulance personnel arrived and Mackin 
was transported to John Muir Hospital, Walnut Creek Campus.  Per medical staff at John 
Muir Hospital, Mackin had sustained injuries to both lungs as a result of being shot.  
Mackin was intubated and was being treated for his injuries.   
 
After Sergeant Colley's briefing, we reviewed the body-worn camera footage of the involved 
officers.  Sergeant Colley advised that Mackin was currently listed in critical condition, but was 
expected to survive.

16 
After the briefing by Sergeant Colley, all the investigators reviewed the body-worn 
camera footage from the involved officers. The information provided in the briefing was 
consistent with the content of the video provided in body-worn camera footage.     
 
After reviewing the body-worn camera footage, teams were established pursuant to the 
Protocol.  The teams consisted of representatives of the Contra Costa County District Attorney's 
Office and the Antioch Police Department.  The investigative teams and their specific tasks were 
as follows:

Crime Scene Description:  
 
At approximately 1300 hours, Detective Duffy and I responded to 
to assess 
the crime scene.  The scene was cordoned off by crime scene tape, and Antioch Police 
personnel were providing scene security and maintaining a crime scene log.  The Contra Costa 
Crime Lab, Contra Costa District Attorney's Office, and Antioch PD Crime Scene Investigators 
were also on the scene conducting their duties.  I could see the blue van Mackin attempted to 
flee in, had struck a utility box and a street sign pole from driving over the curbed parking lot 
and into the vegetation between the parking lot and A Street.  In an easterly direction on A 
Street, I could see several crime scene plaques marking numerous expended shell casings.   
Further east on the north sidewalk of A Street, I saw another crime scene plaque that marked a 
chrome revolver.  A short distance further east was clothing and blood in the middle of the 
street.   
 
 is a three story apartment complex comprised of the first floor being eight 
storage units and a carport.  The second and third floors consist of four, two bedroom

After assessing the crime scene, Detective Duffy and I responded back to the Antioch Police 
Department.  Upon our arrival, we were advised that the actor officers were not going to 
provide statements that day, and those interviews were scheduled for Tuesday, October 3, 2023, 
at 1000 hours, at the Antioch Police Department.   
 
In preparation for the interviews of the officers, Detective Duffy and I conducted a further 
review of the body-worn camera footage of the incident.  This was done in an attempt to 
determine when the last shot was fired, relative to when Mackin discarded the handgun.  At 
08:05:51 hours the last shot was fired and at 08:05:54 hours, Mackin discards the handgun.  
This was confirmed by the Antioch Police Department's shot spotter system and the officers' 
body-worn cameras.   
 
On Tuesday, October 3, 2023, at 1011 hours, Detective Duffy and I met with Officer Armstrong 
and his attorney, Michael Rains of Rains, Lucia, Stern, St. Phalle & Silver, PC.  We met in the 
second floor conference room of the administrative wing of the Antioch Police Department.  
This interview was digitally recorded with Officer Armstrong's knowledge.  After introducing 
ourselves, I initiated the interview by explaining to Officer Armstrong that the purpose of the 
interview was to determine the facts and circumstances that surround this incident.   
 
I also told Officer Armstrong this was a voluntary statement, and that he could stop at any time 
if he needed to take a break or speak with his attorney.  Officer Armstrong told me he 
understood.  I then asked Officer Armstrong to tell me about his background, including his 
training and experience.  Officer Armstrong in substance told us the following:  
 
Officer Kyle Armstrong Training and Experience:  
He attended the basic police academy and was hired by the Antioch Police Department.  
He has been in orientation training for approximately a week, and Sunday, October 1, 
2023, was his first day on patrol.  He spent 10 years in the military, and reached the rank 
of Sergeant in the U.S. Army, in a communications unit.  He deployed once to

Afghanistan and once to Somalia.  He does not have any prior law enforcement

After Officer Armstrong provided his training and experience, I asked him to explain what 
happened that led to the officer involved shooting.  Officer Armstrong in substance told us the 
following:  
 
Officer Kyle Armstrong Statement:  
Sunday, October 1, 2023, was his first day in the field training program.  He works from 
0630 hours until 1900 hours, which is a red day's schedule.  He had a good night's sleep 
and was well rested and ready for his day.  He was dressed in the Antioch Police 
Uniform, with visible A.P.D. patches on his shoulders and an embroidered badge as well 
as a duty belt with his department issued firearm.  His firearm is a 9mm, Glock 17, Gen 5 
department issued handgun, which can carry a standard 17-round magazine plus one 
additional round in the chamber.  He was loaded with 16 rounds in the magazine and 
one in the chamber.  He also had two additional magazines with him.  One had 16 
rounds and the other had 17 rounds.  He was short 2 rounds of duty ammunition, 
because while he was at the range the week before he dropped two rounds on the 
ground and never found them.  He was wearing a department issued body camera, 
which was activated during this incident.    
 
He attended a briefing with his Training Officer, Officer Borg.  After the briefing, they 
collected paperwork he would need in preparation for his day.  As they did this, there 
was a call over the police radio of a subject sleeping in a vehicle with a firearm in his 
hand.  Officer Borg told him they were going to respond to the call, so they headed to 
their fully marked A.P.D. patrol vehicle.  Once at their patrol vehicle, they responded to 
the detail.  As they responded, Officer Borg had him read the details of the call from the 
computer (Mobil Data Terminal, M.D.T.).  The details of this call were that officers had 
located a possible stolen vehicle, and next to the vehicle a subject was sleeping in a van 
with a firearm in his lap.

They drove down 2nd Street to respond to the call, and did not turn on any emergency 
lights or siren to get there.  Upon arrival, they parked their patrol vehicle, and he could 
see Training Officer Mulholland and his trainee, Officer Posey.  He also saw Officer 
Dibble and K9 Officer Marques.  He could see two patrol vehicles facing a blue panel van 
with their overhead emergency lights on.  He also could see officers pointing their 
firearms at the van and giving commands to a subject inside the van (later identified as 
Daniel Mackin).   He and Officer Borg drew their firearms, and took a position to assist.   
 
He could not see anyone in the van at this time; however, he was told Mackin was in the 
back of the van, and he could see some movement inside.  There was a curtain between 
the front compartment of the van and the cargo area in the back, which prevented him 
from clearly seeing into the van.  From this vantage point, he could see the curtains 
dividing the front and the back of the van shift as if someone had crawled underneath 
them to move to the front of the cabin.  Suddenly he could see Mackin in the driver's 
seat, as the van's engine started.     
 
Numerous commands were given to Mackin to get out of the van; however, Mackin did 
not comply.  Mackin put the van in drive, and started to pull out of the parking stall he 
was backed into.  Mackin attempted to drive over the curb bordering the parking lot and 
onto A Street; however, the van became stuck or high-sided in the vegetation between 
the parking lot and A Street.  Mackin also hit a utility box and a street sign pole with the 
front of the van.   
 
At this point, Officer Borg ran back to their patrol vehicle and turned it around.  Officer 
Borg positioned the vehicle facing northbound on 3rd Street in the event Mackin was 
able to drive away and a vehicle pursuit ensued.  Officers continued to give Mackin 
verbal commands to surrender.  He noticed that K9 Officer Marques had retrieved his K9 
from his patrol vehicle.  At this point, they all had taken cover near their patrol vehicles 
in the area behind the van.  Officer Mulholland utilized a 40mm less lethal gun in an 
attempt to break out the driver's side window of the van.  This was not effective as the 
rubber rounds ricocheted off the van.  Officer Mulholland continued to fire several

rounds at the van, but he was uncertain how many.  The rounds just kept ricocheting off 
the van, which he believed was due to the angle Officer Mulholland was firing from.   
 
He could see Mackin moved out of the driver's compartment area and back into the rear 
cargo area of the van.  He could no longer see Mackin, and they were aware he was still 
in possession of the handgun.  Officer Mulholland ran out of ammunition for the 40mm, 
so Mulholland moved to another vehicle to retrieve more.  During this time, Mackin 
continued to try and free the van by backing up and driving forward.  The tires of the van 
were just spinning, and he was unable to free the van.  Officer Borg requested Officer 
Mulholland attempt to shoot out the back window of the van with the 40mm less lethal 
weapon.  As Officer Mulholland was repositioning himself to take a shot with the 40mm, 
the right side cargo door of the van opened and Mackin stepped out of the van.  Officer 
Borg and Officer Mulholland both gave Mackin commands to get down on the ground, 
but he did not comply.   
 
Mackin pulled the hood of his hooded sweatshirt up over his head.  As Mackin did this, 
he had a small dog in the van with him that jumped out as well.  Mackin looked like he 
was holding the handgun in his front sweatshirt pocket with his left hand as he began to 
flee eastbound on A Street.  He could see what appeared to be the handle of the 
handgun sticking out of the sweatshirt pocket.  K9 Officer Marques deployed his K9 and 
began to pursue Mackin.  He and Officer Borg both gave chase as well.  As they pursued 
Mackin, Officer Marques, and Officer Borg were to his left.  He was not sure where 
Officer Mulholland, Officer Dibble, or Officer Posey were exactly; however, he knew they 
were somewhere around him.   
 
As Mackin fled on foot, Mackin fell near a light pole.  When Mackin fell to the ground, 
Mackin took a seated position along the curb line.  He could now see Mackin holding the 
silver or chrome firearm in his right hand and pointing it in the direction of Officer 
Marques and Officer Borg.  He could not tell if the handgun was a revolver or a semi-
automatic.  He could only see the barrel of the handgun.  He feared for the lives of his 
fellow officers, at which time he felt deadly force was necessary.  He then heard a shot 
fired by one of the officers near him, possibly to his left.  He then stopped running, took

aim, and fired approximately 2 rounds at Mackin.  He estimated he was approximately

At this time, he heard several rounds being fired by his fellow officers to his left.  
However, Mackin did not appear to be hurt or hit, at which time Mackin got back up and 
continued running eastbound on A Street.  As Mackin was fleeing eastbound, Mackin 
continually turned, looking back at the officers pursuing him.  He wasn't sure if Mackin 
was turning to shoot at them while fleeing, so each time Mackin turned towards them 
with the handgun in his hand, he and the other officers would fire at Mackin.  He fired 
approximately 6 more rounds at Mackin and each time he fired, he reassessed the 
situation.    
 
As Mackin fled, Mackin did what he described as a "Kareem Abdul-Jabbar hook shot" 
and threw the handgun with his right hand over his head in a northern direction.  Once 
Mackin discarded the handgun, he yelled out to everyone, "he dropped the gun."  Once 
he yelled out that Mackin no longer had the handgun in his possession, no other shots 
were fired.  It was unclear if Mackin was merely discarding the handgun or trying to 
throw it into the adjacent river.   The handgun came to rest on the north sidewalk of A 
Street.  Moments later, Mackin collapsed and fell to the ground where he was 
handcuffed and taken into custody.  Once Mackin was safely in custody, they began 
administering first aid.  Mackin had sustained an apparent gunshot wound to his torso 
during the incident.   
 
They immediately requested emergency medical personnel to their location.  He quickly 
ran back to his patrol vehicle and brought it to the location to get medical supplies out of 
the rear.  CSO Graham had also brought his car up.  At that point, he began blocking off 
the crime scene and preventing traffic from coming through.   
 
He is uncertain if Mackin fired his gun.  He believes he fired approximately 8 rounds at 
Mackin during this incident.  There were several minutes between the time Mackin was 
first confronted and ordered out of the van, and when Mackin high sided the van, and 
orders were given for him to surrender.  Mackin never complied with any of the orders

He attended a basic police academy and worked for the Alameda County Sheriff's

After Officer Borg provided his training and experience, I asked him to explain what happened 
that led to the officer involved shooting.  Officer Borg in substance told us the following:  
 
Officer Borg's Interview:  
He had a full night's sleep the night before this incident and was well rested.  He was 
dressed in the APD class "C" uniform, which is their BDU uniform.  He was wearing an 
outer load vest cover with APD patches on each shoulder and an embroidered star on 
his left chest.  He was wearing his duty belt, and carrying his department issued firearm.  
His firearm is a 9mm, Glock 17, Gen 5 department issued firearm, which was fully loaded 
and has a capacity of 17 rounds in the magazine.  He had one round in the chamber 
which gave him a total of 18 rounds, which is how he was carrying it on the day of the 
incident.  He also had two additional magazines with him that were both loaded to a 
capacity of 17 rounds each.  He was wearing a department issued body camera, which 
was activated during the incident.    
 
He is a training officer and Officer Armstrong is his trainee.  After the briefing on Sunday, 
October 1, 2023, he gave Officer Armstrong a tour of the department, as this was Officer 
Armstrong’s first day on patrol.  While touring the police department, he heard the 
details of Officer Marques' call with a possible stolen vehicle and an unresponsive man 
sleeping in a different vehicle, with a gun in plain view.   He and Officer Armstrong 
respond to the location in their fully marked patrol vehicle.   
 
Upon arrival at A Street and W. 3rd Street, he parked their patrol vehicle on W. 3rd 
Street.  He could see 2-3 patrol vehicles with their emergency lights on, parked in the 
driveway facing the carport area of the apartments.  The officers were conducting a 
high-risk stop and ordering a person out of a van.   He and Officer Armstrong

immediately got out of their patrol vehicle and took cover behind the patrol vehicles in 
the driveway area.   He spoke with Officer Dibble who confirmed that the van was the 
involved vehicle.     
 
At this point, he took a position on the passenger side of a patrol vehicle, and directed 
Officer Armstrong to stay with him.  Both he and Officer Armstrong drew their sidearms 
and pointed them at the blue van.  Officers began giving orders to the person in the blue 
van to surrender and come out with his hands up (this person was later identified as 
Mackin).   After a few moments, he saw Mackin move into the driver's seat of the blue 
van.  It was difficult to see into the van because there was a curtain dividing the front 
seat and the rear cargo area.  The side windows of the van were also tinted, making it 
difficult to see into the van.  Mackin did not comply with their orders to give up during 
the 2-3 minutes Mackin was being ordered out of the van.  All the officers were in full 
uniform, and the patrol vehicles were fully marked, with the emergency lights on.   
 
At this point, Mackin moved into the driver's seat, and he could hear Mackin trying to 
start the van.  Officers gave Mackin orders to not start the van and to come out with his 
hands up; however, Mackin did not comply.  Mackin put the van into drive and 
accelerated, driving towards the officers.  Mackin then veered away from the officers 
and tried to drive over the curbed parking lot and through the vegetation in an attempt 
to drive onto A Street.  Mackin hit a metal utility box and got the van stuck in a grassy 
area.  Mackin began to reverse the van and drive it forward in an attempt to free it.       
 
At this point, things became chaotic with officers talking over each other and giving 
Mackin commands to surrender.  He quickly returned to his patrol vehicle, in the event 
Mackin was able to free the van and a vehicle pursuit ensued.  Once he realized Mackin 
was unable to free the van, he returned to his position of cover at the patrol vehicle 
parked in the driveway.  He noticed that Officer Marques had his police K9 out.  At this 
point, they all had taken cover near their patrol vehicles in the area behind the van.  
Officer Mulholland had the 40mm less lethal deployed.  They were trying to deescalate 
the situation by shooting out the driver's side window in an attempt to gain Mackin's 
compliance with their orders to surrender.

He yelled out to Officer Mulholland to have one person give commands, so it wouldn't

He requested dispatch contact the Brentwood Police Department to see if they had stop

After 2-3 minutes, he saw the side passenger door open and Mackin jumped out of the

head.  He could see that Mackin had his left hand in the front pocket of the sweatshirt or

his hands up.  He yelled out that Mackin had exited the van, and he was now reaching

He gave chase and took an angle to the right in an attempt to cut Mackin off.  As he ran 
up a dirt embankment, he tripped and fell to the ground.  He quickly got up and 
continued to pursue Mackin.   He could now see Mackin was running with a handgun in 
his left hand.  As Mackin fled from him, Mackin turned and looked at him while holding 
the handgun in his left hand.  He believed that Mackin was attempting to gain a sight 
picture of the pursuing officers.  At this time, he felt he needed to use lethal force to 
stop Mackin and prevent him from shooting any officers.  He believed Mackin had the 
intention to harm someone, and Mackin could cause death or harm to officers or 
citizens.  He then fired at least one round at Mackin.   He estimates he was 15-20 feet 
away from Mackin at the time he initially engaged him.   
 
Mackin ran a short distance and then collapsed on the sidewalk on the north side of A 
Street.  When Mackin fell to the ground, he fell in a seated position on the sidewalk.  
Mackin was facing him and his fellow officers.  He recalled Officer Marques was to his 
immediate left and they were close together.  Mackin was now holding the handgun in 
his right hand and began raising it, at which time he could see the silver barrel of the gun 
pointed at him.   He thought Mackin fired a shot at him because he heard a shot come

After firing at Mackin, Mackin got onto his feet again, and was still holding the handgun 
in his right hand.  He conducted a tactical reload, to make sure he had a fully loaded 
firearm.  After the tactical reload, he pointed his handgun at Mackin, however, he does 
not recall if he fired any more shots.  Within seconds, Mackin started to flee from 
officers again.  Mackin then threw the handgun over his head in a northern direction.   
He could see that Mackin was no longer armed or had anything in his hands, so he 
transitioned to his taser and holstered his firearm.   He could see Mackin was slowing 
down, and he began giving Mackin commands to get onto the ground.  After Mackin 
discarded the handgun, there were no additional shots fired by officers.   
 
He could see Officer Marques' K9 run passed him.  The K9 began circling Mackin; 
however, the K9 never engaged Mackin because of the distraction of Mackin’s dog.  At 
this point, Mackin slowed down and collapsed onto the ground.  Mackin was 
handcuffed, and officers began requesting a medical bag, and emergency medical 
personnel to respond.  They also began securing the crime scene.   
 
After our interview, Officer Borg indicated that he had not spoken with anyone about this

interview.  Officer Borg was offered an opportunity to review his body-worn camera footage; 
however, he declined.  Officer Borg had nothing further to add, so we ended our interview.

INVESTIGATION: 
 
Notification:  
On Sunday, October 1, 2023, at 0930 hours, I received a telephone call at my residence from 
Lieutenant Conaty.  Lieutenant Conaty informed me there had been an officer involved shooting 
in the city of Antioch, which involved four actor officers, and several witnessing officers.  
Lieutenant Conaty advised the suspect had been transported to the hospital and was in critical 
condition.   
 
At approximately 1000 hours, I arrived at the Antioch Police Department.  Upon arrival, I met 
with additional Inspectors from the District Attorney's Office, and Detectives from the Antioch 
Police Department.     
 
At approximately 1200 hours, I attended a briefing conducted by Antioch Police Detective 
Sergeant Colley regarding the shooting and what led up to it.  During the briefing, I learned the 
following information:   
 
On Thursday, September 26, 2023, at approximately 1418 hours, Community Service 
Officer Graham responded to the Cube Smart Self Storage located at 1790 Vineyard 
Drive in the city of Antioch.  CSO Graham was responding to the onsite manager, 
 
DocuSign Envelope ID: 83C48DCC-8B25-4398-B589-898679103D0E

13 
, who was reporting a vehicle theft from the location.  At this time, CSO Graham 
reviewed surveillance footage of the vehicle theft, which occurred earlier the same day.  
While reviewing the surveillance footage, CSO Graham saw that on Thursday, September 
26, 2023, at approximately 0130 hours, two unknown male subjects were walking 
around inside the storage yard.  At approximately 0152 hours, a blue or purple panel van 
is seen entering the storage yard via the rear gate, located at the end of Vineyard Drive.  
The panel van then can be seen pushing a white 1987 Chevrolet Monte Carlo (Cal. 
License Plate #
) out of the south gate of the storage yard onto E. 18th Street.  
Once the panel van and the Monte Carlo exited the south gate, CSO Graham was unable 
to see them because it was out of the surveillance camera's view.   
 
advised that nobody had permission to be at the storage yard, at that 
time.   
then provided CSO Graham with the owner of the Monte Carlo 
personal information.  CSO Graham made telephone contact with the owner of the 
Monte Carlo, (
 who currently resides in Florida, and he advised that he 
did not give anyone permission to have his vehicle.  CSO Graham completed a stolen 
vehicle report, and requested the surveillance footage of the incident from Cube Smart 
Self Storage, as evidence of the theft.  CSO Graham later entered the stolen Monte Carlo 
into the Stolen Vehicle System (SVS) and returned to his duties.   
 
On Sunday, October 1, 2023, at approximately 0741 hours, CSO Graham was conducting 
his patrol duties, when he noticed a white Chevrolet Monte Carlo backed into the 
carport of 
  The Monte Carlo was covered with a tarp.  CSO 
Graham noticed a blue panel van backed into the carport next to the Monte Carlo.  CSO 
Graham believed the blue panel van was similar to the one he saw involved with the 
theft of the Monte Carlo on Thursday, September 26, 2023.  Based on this, CSO Graham 
contacted dispatch, and requested assistance from patrol.  K-9 Officer Marques 
responded to assist CSO Graham, as did Officer Dibble, Officer Mulholland, and his 
Trainee Officer Posey.   
 
Officer Marques arrived on the scene followed by Officer Dibble.  The officers 
approached the suspected stolen Monte Carlo, pulled back the tarp, and discovered it

14 
was unoccupied.  Officer Marques confirmed the Monte Carlo was the stolen vehicle 
CSO Graham had been investigating on Thursday, September 26, 2023.  Officer Marques 
then conducted a record check of the blue panel van which had a license plate of 
.  This vehicle returned with an expired registration in 2018.  Officer Marques 
began looking into the interior of the blue panel van through the side cargo door 
windows on the passenger side.  As Officer Marques did this, he noticed someone (later 
identified as suspect Daniel Mackin) was sleeping in the rear cargo area of the vehicle 
with a handgun lying next to him in plain view.   
 
Officer Marques advised dispatch of this observation, and the officers quickly backed 
away from the suspect vehicle and took cover near their patrol vehicles.  At this point, 
Officer Mulholland and his trainee, Officer Posey arrived on the scene.  Hearing this 
information over the radio, Officer Borg, and his trainee, Officer Armstrong responded as 
well.  Officers noticed that Mackin was now awake, and looking out the front windshield 
at the Antioch Police Officers surrounding the van.  Officers began giving Mackin orders 
to step out of the van with his hands up, however, he did not comply.  Officers Borg and 
Officer Armstrong arrived on the scene and took a position near Officer Marques' patrol 
vehicle.  
 
At this time, Mackin got into the driver's seat of the van and started it.  Mackin then 
attempted to flee, by driving the van through the apartment building's parking lot over a 
curb/green belt area, and onto A Street.  The van then hit a utility box, and a street sign 
pole, at which time it became stuck.  Officers continued to give Mackin orders to come 
out of the van, but Mackin refused.  Mackin began to back up and drive forward several 
times, in an attempt to free the van and escape.  At this time, Officer Mulholland utilized 
a 40mm less lethal weapon to break out the driver's side window of the van.  After four 
unsuccessful attempts to break the van's driver's side window, Mackin fled on foot out 
the side cargo doors of the van.   
 
As Mackin fled from the van he was holding something in his waistband or hooded 
sweatshirt front pocket with his left hand.  As Mackin fled eastbound on A Street, Officer 
Marques deployed his police K-9 to apprehend him.  As Mackin fled he was followed by 
DocuSign Envelope ID: 83C48DCC-8B25-4398-B589-898679103D0E
Contra Costa County District Attorney’s Office

Written By: 
 
Inspector Kirk Sullivan #214 
Date: 10/1/2023 
 
15 
a small dog that had been inside the van.  The small dog distracted the police K-9, which 
prevented the K-9 from apprehending Mackin.  As Mackin ran, the officers could now 
see a chrome handgun in his right hand.   
 
As Mackin continued to run east, he turned several times toward the police officers 
pursuing him, and was now pointing the handgun in their direction.  The pursuing 
officers, then fired several times at Mackin as he fled.  At one point Mackin fell to the 
ground and came to rest in a seated position on the north curbline, still pointing the 
handgun at the officers.  Officers then fired additional shots at Mackin as he got to his 
feet, still pointing the handgun in the direction of pursuing officers.  Mackin continued to 
run eastbound on A Street, with the handgun in his right hand.  As Mackin ran, he threw 
the handgun, over his head in a northern direction.  The handgun landed on the north 
sidewalk of A Street, where it was later recovered fully, loaded with six live rounds.   
 
Once the handgun was discarded, officers verbally announced Mackin had discarded it, 
and no other shots were fired.  Mackin ran approximately another 10-15 yards until he 
came to a stop, went to his knees, and laid down on the ground in the middle of A 
street.  Officers approached Mackin who had sustained one through and through 
gunshot wound to his torso.  Mackin was immediately handcuffed, and emergency 
medical personnel were requested.  Officers obtained a medical kit from a patrol vehicle, 
and began administering first aid.  Fire and ambulance personnel arrived and Mackin 
was transported to John Muir Hospital, Walnut Creek Campus.  Per medical staff at John 
Muir Hospital, Mackin had sustained injuries to both lungs as a result of being shot.  
Mackin was intubated and was being treated for his injuries.   
 
After Sergeant Colley's briefing, we reviewed the body-worn camera footage of the involved 
officers.  Sergeant Colley advised that Mackin was currently listed in critical condition, but was 
expected to survive.

After the briefing by Sergeant Colley, all the investigators reviewed the body-worn 
camera footage from the involved officers. The information provided in the briefing was 
consistent with the content of the video provided in body-worn camera footage.     
 
After reviewing the body-worn camera footage, teams were established pursuant to the 
Protocol.  The teams consisted of representatives of the Contra Costa County District Attorney's 
Office and the Antioch Police Department.  The investigative teams and their specific tasks were 
as follows:

Crime Scene Description:  
 
At approximately 1300 hours, Detective Duffy and I responded to 
to assess 
the crime scene.  The scene was cordoned off by crime scene tape, and Antioch Police 
personnel were providing scene security and maintaining a crime scene log.  The Contra Costa 
Crime Lab, Contra Costa District Attorney's Office, and Antioch PD Crime Scene Investigators 
were also on the scene conducting their duties.  I could see the blue van Mackin attempted to 
flee in, had struck a utility box and a street sign pole from driving over the curbed parking lot 
and into the vegetation between the parking lot and A Street.  In an easterly direction on A 
Street, I could see several crime scene plaques marking numerous expended shell casings.   
Further east on the north sidewalk of A Street, I saw another crime scene plaque that marked a 
chrome revolver.  A short distance further east was clothing and blood in the middle of the 
street.   
 
 is a three story apartment complex comprised of the first floor being eight 
storage units and a carport.  The second and third floors consist of four, two bedroom

apartments on each floor.  The apartments all face north with a common parking lot that is 
accessible from a W. 3rd Street entry/exit point.  
 
After assessing the crime scene, Detective Duffy and I responded back to the Antioch Police 
Department.  Upon our arrival, we were advised that the actor officers were not going to 
provide statements that day, and those interviews were scheduled for Tuesday, October 3, 2023, 
at 1000 hours, at the Antioch Police Department.   
 
In preparation for the interviews of the officers, Detective Duffy and I conducted a further 
review of the body-worn camera footage of the incident.  This was done in an attempt to 
determine when the last shot was fired, relative to when Mackin discarded the handgun.  At 
08:05:51 hours the last shot was fired and at 08:05:54 hours, Mackin discards the handgun.  
This was confirmed by the Antioch Police Department's shot spotter system and the officers' 
body-worn cameras.   
 
On Tuesday, October 3, 2023, at 1011 hours, Detective Duffy and I met with Officer Armstrong 
and his attorney, Michael Rains of Rains, Lucia, Stern, St. Phalle & Silver, PC.  We met in the 
second floor conference room of the administrative wing of the Antioch Police Department.  
This interview was digitally recorded with Officer Armstrong's knowledge.  After introducing 
ourselves, I initiated the interview by explaining to Officer Armstrong that the purpose of the 
interview was to determine the facts and circumstances that surround this incident.   
 
I also told Officer Armstrong this was a voluntary statement, and that he could stop at any time 
if he needed to take a break or speak with his attorney.  Officer Armstrong told me he 
understood.  I then asked Officer Armstrong to tell me about his background, including his 
training and experience.  Officer Armstrong in substance told us the following:  
 
Officer Kyle Armstrong Training and Experience:  
He attended the basic police academy and was hired by the Antioch Police Department.  
He has been in orientation training for approximately a week, and Sunday, October 1, 
2023, was his first day on patrol.  He spent 10 years in the military, and reached the rank 
of Sergeant in the U.S. Army, in a communications unit.  He deployed once to

Afghanistan and once to Somalia.  He does not have any prior law enforcement 
experience and has a high school diploma and some college; however, he does not have 
a degree.   
 
After Officer Armstrong provided his training and experience, I asked him to explain what 
happened that led to the officer involved shooting.  Officer Armstrong in substance told us the 
following:  
 
Officer Kyle Armstrong Statement:  
Sunday, October 1, 2023, was his first day in the field training program.  He works from 
0630 hours until 1900 hours, which is a red day's schedule.  He had a good night's sleep 
and was well rested and ready for his day.  He was dressed in the Antioch Police 
Uniform, with visible A.P.D. patches on his shoulders and an embroidered badge as well 
as a duty belt with his department issued firearm.  His firearm is a 9mm, Glock 17, Gen 5 
department issued handgun, which can carry a standard 17-round magazine plus one 
additional round in the chamber.  He was loaded with 16 rounds in the magazine and 
one in the chamber.  He also had two additional magazines with him.  One had 16 
rounds and the other had 17 rounds.  He was short 2 rounds of duty ammunition, 
because while he was at the range the week before he dropped two rounds on the 
ground and never found them.  He was wearing a department issued body camera, 
which was activated during this incident.    
 
He attended a briefing with his Training Officer, Officer Borg.  After the briefing, they 
collected paperwork he would need in preparation for his day.  As they did this, there 
was a call over the police radio of a subject sleeping in a vehicle with a firearm in his 
hand.  Officer Borg told him they were going to respond to the call, so they headed to 
their fully marked A.P.D. patrol vehicle.  Once at their patrol vehicle, they responded to 
the detail.  As they responded, Officer Borg had him read the details of the call from the 
computer (Mobil Data Terminal, M.D.T.).  The details of this call were that officers had 
located a possible stolen vehicle, and next to the vehicle a subject was sleeping in a van 
with a firearm in his lap.

They drove down 2nd Street to respond to the call, and did not turn on any emergency 
lights or siren to get there.  Upon arrival, they parked their patrol vehicle, and he could 
see Training Officer Mulholland and his trainee, Officer Posey.  He also saw Officer 
Dibble and K9 Officer Marques.  He could see two patrol vehicles facing a blue panel van 
with their overhead emergency lights on.  He also could see officers pointing their 
firearms at the van and giving commands to a subject inside the van (later identified as 
Daniel Mackin).   He and Officer Borg drew their firearms, and took a position to assist.   
 
He could not see anyone in the van at this time; however, he was told Mackin was in the 
back of the van, and he could see some movement inside.  There was a curtain between 
the front compartment of the van and the cargo area in the back, which prevented him 
from clearly seeing into the van.  From this vantage point, he could see the curtains 
dividing the front and the back of the van shift as if someone had crawled underneath 
them to move to the front of the cabin.  Suddenly he could see Mackin in the driver's 
seat, as the van's engine started.     
 
Numerous commands were given to Mackin to get out of the van; however, Mackin did 
not comply.  Mackin put the van in drive, and started to pull out of the parking stall he 
was backed into.  Mackin attempted to drive over the curb bordering the parking lot and 
onto A Street; however, the van became stuck or high-sided in the vegetation between 
the parking lot and A Street.  Mackin also hit a utility box and a street sign pole with the 
front of the van.   
 
At this point, Officer Borg ran back to their patrol vehicle and turned it around.  Officer 
Borg positioned the vehicle facing northbound on 3rd Street in the event Mackin was 
able to drive away and a vehicle pursuit ensued.  Officers continued to give Mackin 
verbal commands to surrender.  He noticed that K9 Officer Marques had retrieved his K9 
from his patrol vehicle.  At this point, they all had taken cover near their patrol vehicles 
in the area behind the van.  Officer Mulholland utilized a 40mm less lethal gun in an 
attempt to break out the driver's side window of the van.  This was not effective as the 
rubber rounds ricocheted off the van.  Officer Mulholland continued to fire several

rounds at the van, but he was uncertain how many.  The rounds just kept ricocheting off 
the van, which he believed was due to the angle Officer Mulholland was firing from.   
 
He could see Mackin moved out of the driver's compartment area and back into the rear 
cargo area of the van.  He could no longer see Mackin, and they were aware he was still 
in possession of the handgun.  Officer Mulholland ran out of ammunition for the 40mm, 
so Mulholland moved to another vehicle to retrieve more.  During this time, Mackin 
continued to try and free the van by backing up and driving forward.  The tires of the van 
were just spinning, and he was unable to free the van.  Officer Borg requested Officer 
Mulholland attempt to shoot out the back window of the van with the 40mm less lethal 
weapon.  As Officer Mulholland was repositioning himself to take a shot with the 40mm, 
the right side cargo door of the van opened and Mackin stepped out of the van.  Officer 
Borg and Officer Mulholland both gave Mackin commands to get down on the ground, 
but he did not comply.   
 
Mackin pulled the hood of his hooded sweatshirt up over his head.  As Mackin did this, 
he had a small dog in the van with him that jumped out as well.  Mackin looked like he 
was holding the handgun in his front sweatshirt pocket with his left hand as he began to 
flee eastbound on A Street.  He could see what appeared to be the handle of the 
handgun sticking out of the sweatshirt pocket.  K9 Officer Marques deployed his K9 and 
began to pursue Mackin.  He and Officer Borg both gave chase as well.  As they pursued 
Mackin, Officer Marques, and Officer Borg were to his left.  He was not sure where 
Officer Mulholland, Officer Dibble, or Officer Posey were exactly; however, he knew they 
were somewhere around him.   
 
As Mackin fled on foot, Mackin fell near a light pole.  When Mackin fell to the ground, 
Mackin took a seated position along the curb line.  He could now see Mackin holding the 
silver or chrome firearm in his right hand and pointing it in the direction of Officer 
Marques and Officer Borg.  He could not tell if the handgun was a revolver or a semi-
automatic.  He could only see the barrel of the handgun.  He feared for the lives of his 
fellow officers, at which time he felt deadly force was necessary.  He then heard a shot 
fired by one of the officers near him, possibly to his left.  He then stopped running, took

aim, and fired approximately 2 rounds at Mackin.  He estimated he was approximately

At this time, he heard several rounds being fired by his fellow officers to his left.  
However, Mackin did not appear to be hurt or hit, at which time Mackin got back up and 
continued running eastbound on A Street.  As Mackin was fleeing eastbound, Mackin 
continually turned, looking back at the officers pursuing him.  He wasn't sure if Mackin 
was turning to shoot at them while fleeing, so each time Mackin turned towards them

approximately 6 more rounds at Mackin and each time he fired, he reassessed the

As Mackin fled, Mackin did what he described as a "Kareem Abdul-Jabbar hook shot" 
and threw the handgun with his right hand over his head in a northern direction.  Once 
Mackin discarded the handgun, he yelled out to everyone, "he dropped the gun."  Once 
he yelled out that Mackin no longer had the handgun in his possession, no other shots 
were fired.  It was unclear if Mackin was merely discarding the handgun or trying to 
throw it into the adjacent river.   The handgun came to rest on the north sidewalk of A 
Street.  Moments later, Mackin collapsed and fell to the ground where he was 
handcuffed and taken into custody.  Once Mackin was safely in custody, they began 
administering first aid.  Mackin had sustained an apparent gunshot wound to his torso 
during the incident.   
 
They immediately requested emergency medical personnel to their location.  He quickly 
ran back to his patrol vehicle and brought it to the location to get medical supplies out of 
the rear.  CSO Graham had also brought his car up.  At that point, he began blocking off 
the crime scene and preventing traffic from coming through.   
 
He is uncertain if Mackin fired his gun.  He believes he fired approximately 8 rounds at 
Mackin during this incident.  There were several minutes between the time Mackin was 
first confronted and ordered out of the van, and when Mackin high sided the van, and 
orders were given for him to surrender.  Mackin never complied with any of the orders

After Officer Borg provided his training and experience, I asked him to explain what happened 
that led to the officer involved shooting.  Officer Borg in substance told us the following:  
 
Officer Borg's Interview:  
He had a full night's sleep the night before this incident and was well rested.  He was 
dressed in the APD class "C" uniform, which is their BDU uniform.  He was wearing an 
outer load vest cover with APD patches on each shoulder and an embroidered star on 
his left chest.  He was wearing his duty belt, and carrying his department issued firearm.  
His firearm is a 9mm, Glock 17, Gen 5 department issued firearm, which was fully loaded 
and has a capacity of 17 rounds in the magazine.  He had one round in the chamber 
which gave him a total of 18 rounds, which is how he was carrying it on the day of the 
incident.  He also had two additional magazines with him that were both loaded to a 
capacity of 17 rounds each.  He was wearing a department issued body camera, which 
was activated during the incident.    
 
He is a training officer and Officer Armstrong is his trainee.  After the briefing on Sunday, 
October 1, 2023, he gave Officer Armstrong a tour of the department, as this was Officer 
Armstrong’s first day on patrol.  While touring the police department, he heard the 
details of Officer Marques' call with a possible stolen vehicle and an unresponsive man 
sleeping in a different vehicle, with a gun in plain view.   He and Officer Armstrong 
respond to the location in their fully marked patrol vehicle.   
 
Upon arrival at A Street and W. 3rd Street, he parked their patrol vehicle on W. 3rd 
Street.  He could see 2-3 patrol vehicles with their emergency lights on, parked in the 
driveway facing the carport area of the apartments.  The officers were conducting a 
high-risk stop and ordering a person out of a van.   He and Officer Armstrong

immediately got out of their patrol vehicle and took cover behind the patrol vehicles in 
the driveway area.   He spoke with Officer Dibble who confirmed that the van was the

At this point, he took a position on the passenger side of a patrol vehicle, and directed 
Officer Armstrong to stay with him.  Both he and Officer Armstrong drew their sidearms 
and pointed them at the blue van.  Officers began giving orders to the person in the blue 
van to surrender and come out with his hands up (this person was later identified as 
Mackin).   After a few moments, he saw Mackin move into the driver's seat of the blue 
van.  It was difficult to see into the van because there was a curtain dividing the front 
seat and the rear cargo area.  The side windows of the van were also tinted, making it 
difficult to see into the van.  Mackin did not comply with their orders to give up during 
the 2-3 minutes Mackin was being ordered out of the van.  All the officers were in full 
uniform, and the patrol vehicles were fully marked, with the emergency lights on.   
 
At this point, Mackin moved into the driver's seat, and he could hear Mackin trying to 
start the van.  Officers gave Mackin orders to not start the van and to come out with his 
hands up; however, Mackin did not comply.  Mackin put the van into drive and 
accelerated, driving towards the officers.  Mackin then veered away from the officers 
and tried to drive over the curbed parking lot and through the vegetation in an attempt 
to drive onto A Street.  Mackin hit a metal utility box and got the van stuck in a grassy 
area.  Mackin began to reverse the van and drive it forward in an attempt to free it.       
 
At this point, things became chaotic with officers talking over each other and giving 
Mackin commands to surrender.  He quickly returned to his patrol vehicle, in the event 
Mackin was able to free the van and a vehicle pursuit ensued.  Once he realized Mackin 
was unable to free the van, he returned to his position of cover at the patrol vehicle 
parked in the driveway.  He noticed that Officer Marques had his police K9 out.  At this 
point, they all had taken cover near their patrol vehicles in the area behind the van.  
Officer Mulholland had the 40mm less lethal deployed.  They were trying to deescalate 
the situation by shooting out the driver's side window in an attempt to gain Mackin's 
compliance with their orders to surrender.

pointed at him.   He thought Mackin fired a shot at him because he heard a shot come

Sergeant Serrato #4079 of the Sheriff's Lakeside Substation and Sergeant Carrillo #2821 of the Sheriff's 
Division of Inspectional Services responded to the hospital for follow-up investigation regarding the 
utilization of a Sheriff's canine. Sergeant Leyva #3394 of the Sheriff's Canine Unit was notified of the 
incident by phone.  
 
Officer Garcia #550 of the National City Police Department arrested and booked Zachariah Iban into the 
San Diego County Central Jail for residential burglary, resisting arrest and a probation violation warrant.  
 
Lieutenant Ramirez #422 of the National City Police Department was the incident's commander. They 
documented their investigation under case number 2320896.  
 
I took photographs of the scene, Zachariah Iban and Iban's injuries, which were placed into evidence at 
the Lakeside Substation.  
 
I reported this incident to the San Diego County Department of Animal Services.  
 
This incident was captured on body worn camera.  
 
 
ORIGIN: 
 
 
On 08/19/23, at approximately 1447 hours, I was dispatched to 817 Eta Street, in National City, to assist 
the National City Police Department. The National City Police Department informed Sheriff's 
Communications they wanted a canine unit to assist them with a call of an intoxicated male who was 
hitting vehicles, possibly had a gun and walked into an apartment, against officers' commands.  
 
Event Number: E8730087 
 
 
BACKGROUND: 
 
 
None 
 
 
INVESTIGATION: 
 
 
At the time of this incident, I was on-duty, in full uniform and driving a marked, Sheriff's, canine vehicle. I 
was working my regularly scheduled shift as a canine handler for the Lakeside Substation. I responded

until the dog was removed from the search area. Lieutenant Ramirez informed me one of his tactical 
officers was retrieving their armored vehicle and bringing it to the scene. He said they would start by 
giving announcements from their armored vehicle and go from there.  
 
While awaiting the arrival of the armored vehicle, I opened my vehicle's front doors and placed old 
ballistic vests over each window. This provided me with more ballistic coverage should Zachariah Iban 
start shooting from the apartment. I then retrieved my department-issued rifle from the back of my vehicle 
and placed it on my passenger seat, for quick access.  
 
The apartment into which Zachariah Iban fled was a second story unit on the southeast corner of an 
eight-unit building. There were two upper units and two lower units facing east, with the other units facing 
west. The entrance to the units was recessed into the middle of the eastern wall. From my position, I 
could see all the apartment's windows, but could not see the doorway. I could only see the lower steps of 
the stairwell, which led to the door. Some of the apartments windows were open.  
 
The armored vehicle arrived and parked next to my patrol vehicle. I remained on the south side of the 
building with Sergeant Shanahan, Lieutenant Ramirez, a couple tactical officers, an agent and another 
patrol officer. A contact team was established at a patrol car positioned off the northeast corner of the 
building. The officers moved the vehicle south a short distance in order to better observe the doorway 
and stairwell, should Zachariah Iban exit.  
 
Officers began making announcements from the public announcement system on the armored vehicle. 
After a few rounds of announcements, I noted the volume appeared low. Wanting to ensure Zachariah 
Iban could hear the announcements, I requested they turn up the speaker's volume. The officer adjusted 
the volume and continued. After making the adjustment, I felt content with the speaker's volume and 
believed officer's commands were sufficiently loud that they would be heard by Iban, even if he was 
sleeping in the apartment. Officers continued giving commands for Zachariah Iban to come out of the 
apartment, calling him by name and giving the apartment number. Most of the officer's commands 
included the fact they had a police dog present and stated if he did not come out the dog would be sent 
inside and he would be bit. I believe it fair to say they gave dozens of canine warnings during the 
incident.  
 
During the time when officers were giving commands, I coordinated with an officer on the contact team 
who was holding a specialty munitions shotgun. I told him if Zachariah Iban came out of the apartment 
and was not following commands, I might request he deploy the specialty munitions shotgun in order to 
give my canine a safer opportunity to approach, potentially preventing Iban from drawing a firearm or 
being able to quickly retreat back into the apartment. The officer informed me he would deploy, upon my 
request.  
 
Officers were able to evacuate the rest of the building's residents, except those who lived on the opposite 
side of the landing. Officers gave those residents an order to shelter in place in a back bedroom, not 
wanting them to overexpose themselves during an evacuation.

 said might be aggressive toward other dogs. I informed Lieutenant Ramirez my concern was

I was informed Lieutenant Ramirez was calling out their SWAT team and a CNT negotiator.  
 
At approximately 1724 hours, just over two hours after my arrival on scene and more than two and a half 
hours after the arrival of the National City Police Department, an officer advised the door was opening. At 
the time of this announcement, I was standing on the rear, driver's-side corner of the armored vehicle. 
There were no officers with me on that side. I decided to move forward to the driver's door of the armored 
vehicle, as a position of cover. I planned on using the door to give me a closer position from which to 
safely deploy Nike, if necessary. As I moved toward the front of the vehicle, Zachariah Iban had already 
stumbled out into the street, from the stairs. He stumbled quickly in the direction of the contact team. 
Officer began giving him commands to put his hands up, but he was not complying. I yelled, "Hands up!" 
When Iban regained his balance, he turned away from the officers of the contact team, not complying 
with their commands, and started moving in my direction. I yelled at him to get on the ground three times, 
but he continued walking toward me. While giving him commands to get on the ground, he raised his 
hands up slightly, exposing his palms, looked at me and pointed forward, with his right, index finger. I 
could see he did not have anything in his hands, but was unable tell if there was a gun or other weapon 
tucked in his waistband.  
 
Standing by myself on the driver's side of the armored vehicle, with Zachariah Iban advancing in my 
direction, ignoring all commands to put his hands up, stop or get on the ground, I feared for my safety. 
There were a handful of officers in the contact team on the other side of the apartment, but none of them 
would be able fire if Iban produced a weapon, because I was standing on the other side of him. Further, 
knowing there was a crowd gathered all around our scene, I worried Iban might try to flee and make his 
way into the crowd. Based upon the fact the call originated because Iban was being aggressive to 
residents, reportedly had a gun and was hitting cars, I worried he might attack anyone of the onlookers or 
potentially take them hostage. Further, if Iban reached the crowd, my force options to subdue him would 
be greatly limited because they might put others at risk of injury. Because of this, I believed I had to stop 
him before he got to me and certainly before he reached the crowd. Not wanting to go hands on with a 
potentially armed person, I believed the safest way of stopping Iban was to deploy Nike. No other force 
option I had at my disposal would allow me to do so, without sacrificing the safety of distance or 
compromising my chances of success. I believed deploying Nike would likely prevent Iban from reaching 
for a weapon or at least make it more challenging for him to manipulate one and prevent him from 
reaching me or getting to the crowd. 
 
I removed Nike's traffic lead and released my grip on his collar, giving him the command to bite 
Zachariah Iban. Nike ran at Iban, jumped and bit him on the inside of his upper, right arm. As Nike bit 
Iban, I ordered him to get on the ground. I drew my pistol and began walking at Iban, pointing my gun at 
him to be better prepared, should he produce a weapon. I continued to order Iban onto the ground and 
he sat down. Iban was holding Nike's front, right leg with his left hand and had his right arm around the 
back of Nike's neck. Iban responded to my commands to get on the ground, saying, "Okay," and laid on 
his right side. With Iban showing signs of compliance, both lying down and replying okay to my 
commands, I believed it was safe to holster and detain him. Further, with Iban lying on his back and 
moving to his side, I had more time to scan his body for weapons and did not see any. I put my gun away

I took photographs of the apartment, the location where Zachariah Iban was arrested and the location of

Officer Garcia #550 of the National City Police Department informed me she was the arresting officer and

INJURIES: 
 
 
Zachariah Iban sustained approximately ten lacerations/punctures on his upper, right arm, proximal to his 
elbow, as a result of being bit by my canine partner, Nike. The largest laceration was on the inside of 
Iban's arm and measured approximately three inches in length. Iban was transported to Paradise Valley 
Hospital by American Medical Response's Medic 419, which was staffed by Paramedic 
 
and EMT 
 
 treated Iban at the hospital. Iban received 18 sutures.

None

ORIGIN: 
 
 
On 08/19/23, at approximately 1447 hours, I was dispatched to 817 Eta Street, in National City, to assist 
the National City Police Department. The National City Police Department informed Sheriff's 
Communications they wanted a canine unit to assist them with a call of an intoxicated male who was 
hitting vehicles, possibly had a gun and walked into an apartment, against officers' commands.  
 
Event Number: E8730087 
 
 
BACKGROUND: 
 
 
None 
 
 
INVESTIGATION: 
 
 
At the time of this incident, I was on-duty, in full uniform and driving a marked, Sheriff's, canine vehicle. I 
was working my regularly scheduled shift as a canine handler for the Lakeside Substation. I responded 
to the request for canine assistance from the area of El Cajon. While driving to the call, the National City 
Police Department cancelled the request and I returned to my service area.  
 
At approximately 1521 hours, the National City Police Department contacted Sheriff's Communications 
and requested I return to the same incident. I responded to the request for canine assistance from the 
area of Santee.  
 
I arrived on scene at approximately 1539 hours.  
 
Upon arrival, I met with Sergeant Shanahan #393. Sergeant Shanahan informed me his officers were 
dispatched to a call of a male being aggressive, intoxicated and hitting cars. Sergeant Shanahan said the 
paramedics were also dispatched to the incident and, upon arrival, were told the male had a gun, so they 
backed out. When the officers arrived, they attempted to conduct a pedestrian hot stop, but the male 
walked away and entered apartment 2502. Sergeant Shanahan informed me the male was reaching and 
grabbing at his waistband while walking away from his officers.  Since that time, officers were able to 
identify the male as Zachariah Iban, determined he was a high-risk probationer who was on probation for 
 and confirmed he did not live in that apartment. Sergeant Shanahan said 
his officers made contact with the 
 of apartment
 who stated they did not know the male, 
had left their door unlocked and did not want him inside. The 
 gave the police department

permission to go inside. Sergeant Shanahan claimed his officers had remained on scene the entire time, 
ensuring me Iban was still inside the apartment.  
 
Officer Garcia #550 informed me she had spoken to the 
 of apartment 
, who said there was 
no one else inside the apartment, but stated they had a small dog inside. Officer Garcia reiterated the 
fact that Zachariah Iban was reaching for his waistband when he walked away from them and into the 
apartment. I questioned the source of information about Iban possessing a firearm and she claimed it 
was reported to the fire department from citizens, but they were unable to reach the fire department for 
further.  
 
I contacted Sergeant Leyva #3394 of the Sheriff's Canine Unit. I briefed him of the incident's details and 
expressed my concern for safety of officers who might have to enter an apartment occupied by a male 
who resisted arrest and was reportedly armed with a firearm, despite the fact he was only wanted for 
trespassing and resisting arrest at the time. He agreed that officer safety was priority and believed the 
utilization of a canine during such a search was reasonable. We discussed possible solutions to working 
around the fact there was a dog inside the apartment and decided it was likely best to enter the 
apartment with my canine partner, Nike, on a leash in order to try to get the dog out of the apartment or 
locked into a bathroom before continuing the search.  
 
Lieutenant Ramirez #422 of the National City Police Department arrived on scene, assuming the position 
of incident commander. I briefed with Lieutenant Ramirez and Sergeant Shanahan. I informed them I 
was willing to assist them with a canine search inside the apartment, if they chose to make entry, but 
expressed my concerns for there being a dog inside. I told them I might have to start the search on lead 
until the dog was removed from the search area. Lieutenant Ramirez informed me one of his tactical 
officers was retrieving their armored vehicle and bringing it to the scene. He said they would start by 
giving announcements from their armored vehicle and go from there.  
 
While awaiting the arrival of the armored vehicle, I opened my vehicle's front doors and placed old 
ballistic vests over each window. This provided me with more ballistic coverage should Zachariah Iban 
start shooting from the apartment. I then retrieved my department-issued rifle from the back of my vehicle 
and placed it on my passenger seat, for quick access.  
 
The apartment into which Zachariah Iban fled was a second story unit on the southeast corner of an 
eight-unit building. There were two upper units and two lower units facing east, with the other units facing 
west. The entrance to the units was recessed into the middle of the eastern wall. From my position, I 
could see all the apartment's windows, but could not see the doorway. I could only see the lower steps of 
the stairwell, which led to the door. Some of the apartments windows were open.  
 
The armored vehicle arrived and parked next to my patrol vehicle. I remained on the south side of the 
building with Sergeant Shanahan, Lieutenant Ramirez, a couple tactical officers, an agent and another 
patrol officer. A contact team was established at a patrol car positioned off the northeast corner of the 
building. The officers moved the vehicle south a short distance in order to better observe the doorway 
and stairwell, should Zachariah Iban exit.

Officers began making announcements from the public announcement system on the armored vehicle. 
After a few rounds of announcements, I noted the volume appeared low. Wanting to ensure Zachariah 
Iban could hear the announcements, I requested they turn up the speaker's volume. The officer adjusted 
the volume and continued. After making the adjustment, I felt content with the speaker's volume and 
believed officer's commands were sufficiently loud that they would be heard by Iban, even if he was 
sleeping in the apartment. Officers continued giving commands for Zachariah Iban to come out of the 
apartment, calling him by name and giving the apartment number. Most of the officer's commands 
included the fact they had a police dog present and stated if he did not come out the dog would be sent 
inside and he would be bit. I believe it fair to say they gave dozens of canine warnings during the 
incident.  
 
During the time when officers were giving commands, I coordinated with an officer on the contact team 
who was holding a specialty munitions shotgun. I told him if Zachariah Iban came out of the apartment 
and was not following commands, I might request he deploy the specialty munitions shotgun in order to 
give my canine a safer opportunity to approach, potentially preventing Iban from drawing a firearm or 
being able to quickly retreat back into the apartment. The officer informed me he would deploy, upon my 
request.  
 
Officers were able to evacuate the rest of the building's residents, except those who lived on the opposite 
side of the landing. Officers gave those residents an order to shelter in place in a back bedroom, not 
wanting them to overexpose themselves during an evacuation.  
 
Throughout this incident, large crowds of residents, including children, were gathered around our 
periphery. The groups were asked to leave multiple times, but kept returning. Ultimately, officer placed 
crime scene tape around a large portion of the complex to prevent onlookers from getting too close, 
interfering or being in harm's way.  
 
I was informed officers were attempting to contact probation and was later told they were obtaining a 
probation hold warrant. This led me to believe Zachariah Iban was now arrestable for violating his

living room window and saw him walking away from the apartment's front door, back toward the middle of 
the apartment. Another officer later noticed Iban look out a window on the south side of the building, 
stating he moved the blinds and put his face up to the glass. This activity led me to believe Iban was 
aware of our presence and likely plotting his next move. I was concerned there was the potential Iban 
might start shooting at us and was possibly assessing our locations for possible avenues of escape.  
 
Lieutenant Ramirez informed me the dog inside the residence was reportedly a small chihuahua, which 
the owner said might be aggressive toward other dogs. I informed Lieutenant Ramirez my concern was 
not for the safety of Nike, rather, that if he was released into the apartment, he might start fighting with 
the small dog, distracting us from the danger Zachariah Iban posed. I suggested if we made entry into 
the apartment, two officers with guns enter in front of me and said I would follow with Nike on lead, 
assess and go from there.  
 
I informed Lieutenant Ramirez I thought a flash bang could be useful, believing it might get Zachariah 
Iban's attention and possibly convince him to exit. I would rather contact Iban outside the apartment than 
be forced to make entry into the apartment. If we had to make entry into the apartment, Iban would 
certainly have the tactical advantage. Since I knew he was aware of our presence and possibly armed 
with a gun, I worried it was possible Iban used furniture to barricade the apartments door, could be lying 
in wait, prepared for an ambush, or might ambush us on our approach to the apartment, up the narrow 
stairwell.  
 
I was informed Lieutenant Ramirez was calling out their SWAT team and a CNT negotiator.  
 
At approximately 1724 hours, just over two hours after my arrival on scene and more than two and a half 
hours after the arrival of the National City Police Department, an officer advised the door was opening. At 
the time of this announcement, I was standing on the rear, driver's-side corner of the armored vehicle. 
There were no officers with me on that side. I decided to move forward to the driver's door of the armored 
vehicle, as a position of cover. I planned on using the door to give me a closer position from which to 
safely deploy Nike, if necessary. As I moved toward the front of the vehicle, Zachariah Iban had already 
stumbled out into the street, from the stairs. He stumbled quickly in the direction of the contact team. 
Officer began giving him commands to put his hands up, but he was not complying. I yelled, "Hands up!" 
When Iban regained his balance, he turned away from the officers of the contact team, not complying 
with their commands, and started moving in my direction. I yelled at him to get on the ground three times, 
but he continued walking toward me. While giving him commands to get on the ground, he raised his 
hands up slightly, exposing his palms, looked at me and pointed forward, with his right, index finger. I 
could see he did not have anything in his hands, but was unable tell if there was a gun or other weapon 
tucked in his waistband.  
 
Standing by myself on the driver's side of the armored vehicle, with Zachariah Iban advancing in my 
direction, ignoring all commands to put his hands up, stop or get on the ground, I feared for my safety. 
There were a handful of officers in the contact team on the other side of the apartment, but none of them 
would be able fire if Iban produced a weapon, because I was standing on the other side of him. Further, 
knowing there was a crowd gathered all around our scene, I worried Iban might try to flee and make his

way into the crowd. Based upon the fact the call originated because Iban was being aggressive to 
residents, reportedly had a gun and was hitting cars, I worried he might attack anyone of the onlookers or 
potentially take them hostage. Further, if Iban reached the crowd, my force options to subdue him would 
be greatly limited because they might put others at risk of injury. Because of this, I believed I had to stop 
him before he got to me and certainly before he reached the crowd. Not wanting to go hands on with a 
potentially armed person, I believed the safest way of stopping Iban was to deploy Nike. No other force 
option I had at my disposal would allow me to do so, without sacrificing the safety of distance or 
compromising my chances of success. I believed deploying Nike would likely prevent Iban from reaching 
for a weapon or at least make it more challenging for him to manipulate one and prevent him from 
reaching me or getting to the crowd. 
 
I removed Nike's traffic lead and released my grip on his collar, giving him the command to bite 
Zachariah Iban. Nike ran at Iban, jumped and bit him on the inside of his upper, right arm. As Nike bit 
Iban, I ordered him to get on the ground. I drew my pistol and began walking at Iban, pointing my gun at 
him to be better prepared, should he produce a weapon. I continued to order Iban onto the ground and 
he sat down. Iban was holding Nike's front, right leg with his left hand and had his right arm around the 
back of Nike's neck. Iban responded to my commands to get on the ground, saying, "Okay," and laid on 
his right side. With Iban showing signs of compliance, both lying down and replying okay to my 
commands, I believed it was safe to holster and detain him. Further, with Iban lying on his back and 
moving to his side, I had more time to scan his body for weapons and did not see any. I put my gun away 
and grasped Iban's left hand, requesting the officers move in to assists by calling out, "Hands." The 
officers ran up and took control of Iban's left hand. I informed them not to grab his right arm and moved 
around to gain physical control of Nike. As I grasped Nike's collar with my left hand, I could see the 
officers had sufficient control of Iban, so I used my break stick to release Nike from the bite. Nike 
instantly released his grasp of Iban and I stepped back. The officers detained Iban in handcuffs and 
checked him for weapons. I later reviewed my body worn camera and found Nike was actively biting 
Zachariah Iban for approximately 16 seconds.  
 
I returned to my patrol car and placed Nike in the back seat.  
 
I asked the officers if they had requested paramedics respond to evaluate Zachariah Iban's injuries and 
they informed me they had.  
 
I used my vehicle's radio and requested Sheriff's Communications inform the Lakeside Substation's 
supervisor of the canine contact. Sergeant Serrato #4079 acknowledged the notification.  
 
American Medical Response's Medic 419 arrived on scene and the paramedics began evaluating 
Zachariah Iban.  
 
Sergeant Carrillo #2821 of the Sheriff's Division of Inspectional Services contacted me by phone. He 
informed me he would be conducting the follow-up. I informed him the paramedics would be transporting 
Zachariah Iban to Paradise Valley Hospital for treatment. He informed me he would meet me there.

. While Iban was being treated, I briefed Sergeants Carrillo and Serrato of the
