Use of Force Supplemental Instructions 
 
Lines 1 & 3:  Fill in the blanks.  
 
Line 2: If the suspect was committing a crime and force was used to stop or apprehend the subject, document the appropriate penal 
code.  If the UOF occurred in the performance of the officer's duties, document the incident description, i.e. officer transport, officer 
escort, making arrest, detaining suspect, cell extraction etc. 
 
Primary Reason for Using Force: Check appropriate box(s). 
 
Subject Appeared To Be: Check if applicable. 
 
Number of Officers on Scene: List number of officers present.  
 
Number of Officers Using Force: List number of officers that used force. 
 
Level(s) of Resistance Encountered: Check appropriate box(s). 
 
L.E. Tool/Technique Used: Check appropriate box(s).  If known and/or applicable, include duration (approximate length of time) 
tool/technique was used.  If known and/or applicable, include the number of contacts (approximate number of strikes, impacts, etc.) 
when requested on form. 
 
Was Initial Use of Force Effective?  If initial force used was effective, check “Yes.”  If initial force used was ineffective and additional 
force was necessary, check “No.”   
 
Was Additional Control or Force Needed:  If initial force used was ineffective and additional force was necessary, check “Yes.”  If 
initial force used was effective, check “No.”   
 
Target Distance: If applicable (refers primarily to less lethal weapon systems), approximate distance or provide range (i.e. 7-15 feet, 
15-20 yards, etc.) from subject during application of force.   
 
Subject Injured: Check “Yes” if medically treated for injury sustained as a possible result of force applied by a officer(s) – does not 
include previous injuries suffered prior to officer contact.  Check “No” if subject was not injured or simply complains of injury/pain 
suffered as a result of force applied by an officer(s) and refuses medical attention.  Any complaints of pain shall be documented in the 
use of force report narrative (whenever any physical force used by a officer results in a complaint of injury or an injury that necessitates 
medical treatment of a subject, a supervisor will be notified immediately). 
 
Extent of Treatment: Check appropriate box. Check none if subject was evaluated and no treatment was required.  Specifically, check 
“Treated at Scene” if subject was treated at scene by EMS for injuries that may have resulted due to force applied by officer(s).  Check 
“Treated at Hospital” if subject was transported to hospital for treatment of injuries that may have been sustained as an apparent result 
of force applied by officer(s).  Check “Hospitalized” if subject was admitted to the Hospital as a result of injuries that were sustained as 
a result of force applied by officer(s).  
 
Officer Injured:  Check appropriate box (see above).  
 
Extent of Treatment:  Check appropriate box. Check none if officer was evaluated and no treatment was required.  Specifically, check 
“Treated at Scene” if officer was treated at scene by EMS for injuries.  Check “Treated at Hospital” if officer was transported to hospital 
for treatment of injuries.  Check “Hospitalized” if officer was admitted to the Hospital as a result of injuries.   
 
Other Force Used/Comments/Equipment Performance:  This section can be used to document other force options not listed on the 
form; relevant comments about the incident such as complaints of pain/injury (room permitting) and negative/positive comments 
regarding equipment performance.   
 
Mark Figure to Indicate Contact Points: When applicable, mark the areas on the figure where applied force contacted the subject’s 
body.

Lieutenant: Sign, list ARJIS number and date reviewed.  
 
Captain: Sign, list ARJIS number and date reviewed.

I asked Iban if he was aware I was recording our conversation. Iban replied "no sir." I explained to Iban I was recording our 
interview.  
 
I asked Iban if he had been diagnosed with any type of mental illness. Iban replied "yes sir", I asked Iban if he could tell me 
what type of mental illness he suffered from. Iban stated "plenty", I asked Iban if he could elaborate as to what type of mental 
illness he suffered from. Iban replied "no sir." I once again asked Iban if he could elaborate to what type of mental illness he 
suffered from and he replied, "no sir." 
 
I asked Iban if he had any problems with his eyes or ears. Iban replied "yes sir." I asked Iban what type of problems he 
suffered from. Iban replied "I can't elaborate." 
 
I asked Iban if he was taking any medications. Iban stated "yes sir." I asked Iban what medications he was taking he replied, "I 
can't elaborate." 
 
I asked Iban if he heard a warning the dog would be sent or an order to surrender. Iban replied "I did not know." I asked Iban 
what he did not know. Iban stated "I did not know the dog would be sent." I asked Iban if he heard the announcements a 
police dog would be used. Iban replied "no sir." 
 
I asked Iban why he did not comply with officers. Iban stated "I didn't hear anything." I explained to Iban, I believed they were 
possibly using a PA system to make announcements. I asked Iban if he still did not hear the announcements. I once again 
asked Iban if he heard the announcements a police dog would be used. Iban once again replied "no sir." 
 
I asked Iban how long the police dog had bit him. Iban replied "I can't recall."  
 
I asked Iban if he could tell me where the police dog had bit him. Iban stated "Obviously, you can see." I asked Iban to explain 
to me where he had been bit. "Well, you can see." I observed Iban had been contacted on the inner bicep of his right arm. I 
asked Iban if that was correct, and he stated "whatever." 
 
I asked Iban if he could explain to me how the police dog was taken off him. Iban replied "you saw it." I explained to Iban I was 
not at the scene. Iban stated "well then your partner saw." I asked Iban if he could explain to me how the police dog was 
removed. Iban replied "no sir." 
 
I asked Iban if there was anything about the use of the police dog, he wanted to tell me. Iban replied "excessive", I asked Iban 
if he could elaborate, he once again stated "excessive, yes sir, yeah put the dog down." I asked Iban if he felt the use of the 
police dog was excessive and he replied, "yes sir."  
 
I asked Iban if there was anything else he wanted to add. Iban replied "not at the moment." 
 
I completed my interview with Zachariah Iban at 2002 hours.  
 
 
EVIDENCE: 
 
1. Interview with Zachariah Iban was placed on a compact disc and logged into evidence at the Lakeside Station.  
 
 
INJURIES: 
 
See Deputy Balinger's report for details on Iban's injuries. 
 
PROPERTY DAMAGE: 
 
None.

Detective Gragg and has yet to be reviewed.
Summary of Incident:
On 10/01/23 at approximately 0741 hours, Community Service Officer (CSO) Graham was in the area
of 3rd Street and A. Street, Antioch, when he located a vehicle (White Chevrolet Monte Carlo
) he believed was possibly stolen. lt should be known Community Service Officers are
unarmed lt should also be noted, CSO Graham was the officer who imlial/y took the report for the
stolen vehicle he located on this morning. The vehicle was parked under an apartment carport and
had a tarp concealing a majority of the vehicle. Next to the Chevrolet Monte Carlo was a blue colored
van parked backwards in the parking stall directly next to and west of the stolen vehicle. A record
check confirmed the vehicle
) was stolen on 9/26123 APD#23-7303. CSO Graham recalled
a blue van was captured on video surveillance being used topush the stolen vehicle out ofthe storage
yard CSO Graham reviewed this video captured on his BWC which he uploadedto evidence.com and
determined the van appearedsimilarto the van usedto stealthe Monte Carlo on 9/26/23.
CSO Graham requested APO uniformed officers respond and assist in the investigation.
When uniformed officers arrived, they peered inside the van from the outside and discovered a subject
was sleeping in the back area of the van with a gun next to him. Officer Marques reported the
discovery over the radio and backed off the vehicle to a safe area. While assessing the scene for a
few minutes from a short distance, the subject awoke, got into the driver's seat of the van, and
accelerated forward, narrowly missing Ofc. Marques' vehicle. lt should be noted, Ofc. Marques was
standing in the area of his open driver's side door, and quickly retreated to the rear of his vehicle as
the suspect prepared to drive forward. Prior to retreating, Ofc. Marques and Ofc. Dibble yelled to the
suspect to not move and announced themselves as "Antioch Police". The suspect, later identified as O
aniel MACKIN, disregarded officers' commands and recklessly drove his vehicle forward with his
head below the dashboard, presumably unable to see what was forward of him and in his path.
MACKIN drove the vehicle forward through the small apartment complex parking lot, drove over a
small median, collided with a utility box and became stuck. MACKIN continued to accelerate,

attempting to free his vehicle but was unsuccessful. As MACKIN was attempting to continue to flee in
his vehicle, Ofc. Mulholland utilized the 40mm less lethal launcher in an attempt to break a window(s)
for the purpose of de-escalation and/or disarm MACKIN. The 40mm was deployed five times but
yielded no effect other than breaking the driver's side mirror. Four 40mm fired cartridges were later
locatedby the Contra Costa County Crime Laboratory. The 40mm fired cartridges were photographed
and collectedas evidence.
As officers continued to yell verbal commands to MACKIN (approximately five and a half minutes) to
elicit a safe surrender, he opened the sliding passenger side door of the van and ran from the vehicle,
with a gun in his right hand. As MACKIN ran eastbound on A. Street, Ofc. Marques deployed his K9,
but the K9 redirected to MACKIN's dog which was running with/alongside him. The K9 deployment
was unsuccessful. During the short foot pursuit, MACKIN on at least two occasions (according to
BWC footage), partially turned his body/face to officers and leveled his gun in their direction. Officers
fired several shots at MACKIN, striking him at least one time which caused him to initially fall to the
ground. MACKIN with the gun still in his hand, got to his feet and continued to run eastbound. Officers
fired additional shots toward MACKIN before MACKIN pitched the gun to his left before collapsing to
the ground. After MACKIN discarded his weapon, no officers fired their weapons. Officers quickly
placed him in custody and rendered medical aid. According to hospital staff at JMMC, MACKIN
sustained one gunshot wound which passed through both lungs and exited his body. At the time of
this writing his medical record(s) has not been obtained.
According to officers, MACKIN did not speak or acknowledge them the entirety of the incident.
Investigators located the firearm pitched by MACKIN, on the northern sidewalk of A. Street and in the
area of his flight path. The firearm (Serial # AEP3646) was discovered to be a Smith and Wesson .38
revolver. The revolver was fully loaded with six unfired rounds in the cylinder. The firearm appeared to
be operational. The Contra Costa County Forensics Laboratory laterprocessed the firearm for latent
prints and DNA. No latentprints were recoveredfrom the firearm. DNA swabs werepreservedforlater
testing upon request The firearm hadno record ofregistered owner. The CCCDA performeda trace
ofthe firearm, howeverat the time ofthis writing, results are not available.
The Contra Costa County Crime Laboratory located/collected thirty (30) fired 9mm casings. Refer to
their report for further details.
A record check of Daniel Mackin revealed he had an outstanding PRCS warrant and a Ramey
Warrant for his arrest. The charges listed on the Ramey warrant were for PC187 (APD#23-003219).
A criminal history check revealed prior felony convictions prohibiting him from owning/possessing a
firearm/ammunition.
A preliminary search of the suspects' van was conducted after a search warrant was granted. During
the preliminary search, a license plate from the stolen vehicle was located wedged between the back
of the driver's seat and pet kennel.
The incident was captured on BWC and Dash Camera video.

Notification:
On October 1st, 2023, at approximately 0830 hours,
I was notified while off-duty and at my home by
Investigations Lieutenant Martin of an officer involved shooting. Lt. Martin requested all available
investigators respond to the Antioch Police Department immediately. At this time,
I was assigned to
the Investigations Bureau, Violent Crime Unit.
Investigation Briefing:
After arriving at the Antioch Police Department Investigations Bureau, a briefing of the incident was
conducted. ln the meeting were several Senior Inspectors (S.I.) from the Contra Costa County District
Attorney's Office per the county LEIF! Protocol invocation.
During the briefing
I learned of four (4) involved shooting officers: APO Ote. T. Borg, APO Ote. D.
Dibble, APO Ote. K. Armstrong and APO Ote. S. Marques. lt was decided to allow the shooting
officers to go off-duty for the day, after being photographed and having a round-count conducted. lt
was further decided the four involved shootings officers would be interviewed in the following days by
myself and CCCDA S.I. K. Sullivan.
ln addition to the shooting officers, there were four (4) witness officers of the incident who were
interviewed by CCCDA S.I. Lewellyn and APO Detective Palma. The witness officers were APO Lt., J.
Fortner, APO Ofc. M. Mulholland, APO Ofc. J. Posey and APO eso A. Graham.
During the briefing
I learned the suspect, Daniel Mackin, was transported to John Muir Medical Center
in Walnut Creek after sustaining a gunshot wound. lt should be known, Detective Gragg stated Daniel
Mackin was a person of interest in a homicide he was investigating and had a Probable Cause
"Ramey" Warrantforhis arrestforPC181.

County Crime Laboratory staff.

APO Detective Palma. CCCDA S.I. Barbara and APO Detective Gragg.

SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT 23-007441
OFFICER B. BUSHBY #5961
SUMMARY:
On 10/01/2023 at approximately 0945 hours I, Officer Bushby, was notified of an investigations call-
out for an officer involved shooting.
I responded shortly after being notified.
INVESTIGATION:
Upon my arrival at the station,
I was briefed on the incident.
I was tasked by Sergeant Colley to
respond to the scene and provide scene security to ensure nobody touched the firearm that was on
the sidewalk.
I arrived at the scene at approximately 1300 hours.
I remained in the scene near the discarded firearm
until the Contra Costa County Sheriff Crime Lab personnel collected it at approximately 1425 hours.
During my time on scene, nobody touched the firearm on the sidewalk prior to it being processed and
collected for evidence.
I cleared the scene and took no further action.
OPINION AND RECOMMENDATIONS:
None.

Supplemental Report 23-7441
Detective J. Jeong #3992
On 10/01/2023, at approximately 0830 hours,
I was notified by Lt. Martin that there was an officer
involved shooting incident at A St and W. 3rd St.
I responded to the Antioch Police Department and was debriefed regarding this incident.
I was
directed by Sgt. Colley to respond to the scene located at A St and W. 3rd St to wait for District
Attorney Inspector (DAI) Garcia.
I arrived on scene at approximately 1026 hours. CSO Kelley was in charge of the crime scene log.
The west end of A St was blocked off with yellow crime scene tape, marked eso van, and VIPS
vehicle at W. 3rd St and the east end at W. 6th St. The parking lot of 201 W. 3rd St was blocked off
with yellow crime scene tape. Officer Morris and Officer Hill were on scene for scene security as well.
DAI Garcia arrived at the scene and conducted a walkthrough of the scene. Several cartridge cases
on A St were marked with yellow placards by APD Patrol officers. A pool of blood was located in the
middle of A St. A silver revolver was located on the north sidewalk of A St.
A blue Dodge Ram van (Lic. Plate
was on the north median of 201 W. 3rd St. The vehicle
was facing north toward A St. The two front tires were damaged, and the right rear passenger door
was left open. A 40mm nonlethal launcher was located between two bushes approximately 40 to 50
feet east of the Dodge van.
APD Patrol vehicle 1233 was located in the parking lot of 201 W. 3rd St. APD K-9 Patrol vehicle 1204
and APD Patrol vehicle 1207 were located on A St near the pool of blood.
A white Chevy Monte Carlo was located in the carport of 201 W. 3rd St. The vehicle was partially
covered with a gray car cover, revealing the rear side of the vehicle.
I noticed there was no rear
license plate on the vehicle.
DAI Garcia and
I returned to the Antioch Police for briefing.
I was partnered with DAI Garcia to assist
the Crime Lab with processing the scene. Criminalist Kellmann and Criminalist Souza responded to

Report# 23-007441 - Supplement- 7 Report Antioch Police Department
Pg 2 of 10
the Antioch Police. Criminalist Fong was also requested to assist in this investigation and directed to
respond to John Muir Medical Center in Walnut Creek to photograph and process Daniel Mackin.
Criminalist Kellmann and Souza contacted all involved officers in the shooting. The officers were
sequestered at the administration building within the police department. The officers were
photographed and their duty pistols along with their spare magazines were collected by the Crime Lab.
DAI Garcia and
I along with Criminalist Kellmann and Souza responded to the scene. We arrived at
approximately 1256 hours.
The Crime Lab was responsible for photographing, labeling, and measuring the scene.
The Crime Lab used green placards to mark the locations of the cartridge cases, projectiles, Glock
magazine, Smith Wesson revolver, 40mm rubber projectiles, 40mm cartridge cases, and 40mm
nonlethal launcher. The Crime Lab used red placards to mark the location of the bloodstains found on
A St.
(30) 9mm cartridge cases were located at the scene and collected by the Crime Lab.
The Crime Lab checked the Smith Wesson revolver and found it was fully loaded with (6) live .38
special cartridges.
Refer to the Crime Lab report 23-3800-1 for the list of items marked with the placards.
Criminalist Fong responded to the scene to process the Chevy Monte Carlo for latent prints and DNA.
DAI Garcia contacted the owner, Alexander Jew, of the Chevy and obtained consent to search and
process the vehicle. The front license plate of the Chevy was located in the driver seat floorboard.
I looked inside of the Dodge van through the open right rear passenger door and noticed a license
plate behind the driver seat.
I could only read the last three digits of the plate and it was 438. The last
three digits matched the last three numbers of the license plate of the Chevy Monte Carlo (Lic. Plate
6SQV438).
The Crime Lab did not have a drone to take overview photographs of the scene.
I deployed my
department issued OJI Air 2S to take sequential photographs of the scene in order to create an
orthomosaic of the scene.
Once the Crime Lab personnel collected the evidence,
I had the Dodge Ram and Chevy Monte Carlo
towed to the secured parking lot of Antioch Police. eso Collazo followed the tow truck to the Antioch
Police where the two vehicles were placed at the secured parking lot.
APO Patrol vehicles at the scene were brought back to the Antioch Police. A Crime scene cleaner was
requested at the scene to clean the blood on the street.
On 10/02/2023, Detective Duffy requested to have the Dodge Ram van searched for cellular devices.
Detective Gragg obtained a search warrant for the vehicle.

On 10/1/2023, at approximately 0830 hours,
I was informed that there was an Officer involved
shooting incident that occurred at approximately 0745 hours.
I responded to the Antioch police
department and arrived at approximately 0930 hours.
After all personnel was debriefed regarding the incident,
I was assigned to conduct an area canvas for
potential witnesses.
I was partnered with Det Gragg and Contra Costa County DA inspector Andrew
Barbara.
I responded to 201 W 3rd St to contact residents at the apartment complex where the incident took
place. Below are the results of the area canvas.
Apartment #A (Nicole Findley) Nicole Findley heard approximately 10-gun shots but did not look
outside to see what took place. Findley was semi-uncooperative and refused to provide me with her
phone number or any further information.
I asked her if she heard any yelling or commands that were
given by officers. Findley stated she did not want to answer any of my questions.
Apartment #B. No answer
Apartment #C. Female answered the door and stated she was asleep when the event occurred.
Female refused to provide her name.
Apartment #D. No answer.
Apartment #E. Appears to be a vacant unit.
Apartment #F. (
Female
stated she was asleep. Unable to
locate a name match and phone number that was provided is disconnected.
Apartment #G. Female (
. Female refused to provide a full name or phone number. She stated
she was home at the time but did not hear anything.
Apartment #H. Female resident answered the door and stated she did not hear anything and refused
to provide her name.
I responded to
to contact residents at unit number
and
.

that Mackin hadbeen shot multiple times Pari ofhim wishedthat us, (the police), were goodshots. He
mentionedit was hardto saythatas a father.
He knew Mackin was notgoodto his family, andhe was notgoodto society. He lovedhis son dearly
but, his son was a 1fuckin waste"
He mentionedit was hardto deal with because allhis familyis in law enforcement, andhe turnedout
the wayhe did.
END OF STATEMENT
After my interview with
I provided him with my business card with my contact number and
escorted him to the front lobby.
I collected from dispatch the radio recordings of the communication until 1013 pertaining to APO case
(23-00744).
I later logged and stored the recording into evidence.com.
I also collected the recorded APO non-emergency call from Cube Smart where there was an
anonymous tip to Cube Smart about the stolen vehicle possibly being in the area of A St and W3rd
Street.
I uploaded this audio recording to evidence.com under APO case (23-007303).
I took no further action.

circumstances of the shooting.

investigation.

Police Department and Conta Costa County District Attorney's Office. During the briefing, the intial
facts of this case were presented to us. I, along with SIU Corporal Vanderpool and Senior Inspector
Andrew Barbara were tasked with conducting a video and witness canvass around the shooting
scene.

Michael Raney #6138
On 10/02/2023, Detective Gragg provided me with 3 cellphones and an iPad located by Detective
Jeong during a search of the Dodge Van associated with A-Mackin.
I then authored a search warrant
to perform a forensic extraction of the devices and also to obtain a DNA sample from A-Mackin. The
search warrant was signed by the honorable Judge Ed Weil on 10/02/2023.
The warrant was written for the following devices:
1) Black Motorola Moto G XT2163DL IMEI: 357852525571496; Found in the backseat pocket of the
Dodge van; powered off.
2) Black iPhone IMEI: 354398688368786; Found next to the area A-Mackin was sleeping; powered off
3) Blue One Plus Android Phone; Found in the backseat pocket of the Dodge van; powered off.
4) Apple
Ipad 9; Found in the backseat pocket of the Dodge van; Placed in airplane mode.
Evidence Collection:
On 10/03/2023,
I connected device #1 to the GrayKey extraction device.
I performed a Full File
System extraction. I, then loaded the extraction into the Magnet Axiom software which categorizes the
data for ease of analysis without altering the data.
I then connected device #2 to the Graykey extraction device and performed a Partial BFU extraction,
due to the fact the device had been powered off.
I loaded the extraction into the Magnet Axiom
software.
Next,
I connected device #3 to the Graykey extraction device and was notified, this phone was only
supported for a "consent" extraction, meaning it required the passcode.

MERCED COUNTY 
DISTRICT ATTORNEY’S OFFICE 
 
 
Nicole A. Silveira

550 W. Main Street • Merced, CA 95340 • Telephone (209) 385-7381 • Fax (209) 725-3669 • Victim Witness Telephone (209) 385-7385 
445 I Street • Los Banos, CA 95635 • Telephone (209) 710-6070 • Fax (209) 724-4066 
To: 
 
Nicole A. Silveira 
District Attorney 
 
From:  
Moses Nelson 
District Attorney Investigator 
 
Date:  
June 3, 2024 
 
RE: 
 
Officer Involved Shooting Case No. MCDA #047-587151 & 047-587153 
 
 
 
Shooting Officer(s): Merced Police Department Officers Brandon Wilkins and Saggalih  
 
 
 
 
 
Kusumo 
 
 
Suspect(s): 
 
Gilbert Garibay (DOB: 06/21/1950) 
 
 
The District Attorney’s Office has completed an independent review of the above referenced officer 
involved shooting which occurred on October 26, 2023. This memorandum serves only to address the 
issues of criminal culpability in connection with Officers Brandon Wilkins and Saggalih Kusumo 
discharge of their service weapons at the suspect, Gilbert Garibay, and does not take into account any 
issues of civil liability, tactics, training, departmental policies or procedures.  
 
The Merced County District Attorney’s Office completed the criminal investigation and reviewed 
written reports and other information including: 
 
• Merced Police Department’s (MPD) case number 2023-56604 and supplemental reports 
associated with that case number. 
• Body worn camera footage 
• Citizen video footage 
• MPD Dispatch log and recording 
• Crime scene report and diagram 
• Autopsy reports 
• Photographs 
 
 
 
Page 2 
This report details the steps taken to independently investigate this critical event and describes how the 
conclusion was reached.

Page 4 
Officer Wilkins radioed “responsible walking towards us with knife” and just 12 seconds after that radio 
transmission, Officer Wilkins radioed “shots fired, shots fired.” 
 
CRIME SCENE 
 
Merced Police Department’s Crime Scene Response Team (CSRT) completed a crime scene diagram, 
took multiple photos, and completed a report of the scene.   
 
 
 
 
 
Page 5 
Crime Scene Diagram 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Page 8 
Crime Scene Report  
 
The CSRT Supervisor Report was completed by Detective Matthew Calcagno.  Seven Speer 9 mm 
casings were located west of the southbound bike lane of M Street.  One bullet strike was found at 559 
Collins Drive, #2 (this is an upstairs apartment).  The casings and bullet fragments were logged into 
evidence by CSRT. 
 
BODY WORN CAMERA FOOTAGE  
 
Officer Wilkins and Officer Kusumo were wearing Body Worn Cameras (BWC) during this incident.  
The following is a sequence of still photos taken from Officer Wilkins’ BWC.   
 
 
 
The time of this still photo is 01:00:01.  Garibay walked towards Officer Wilkins as Officer Wilkins 
stepped out of his patrol vehicle.  Garibay had the knife in his right hand. 
 
 
 
Page 9 
Garibay opening the folding knife. 
 
 
 
Within one second of the last still photo, Officer Wilkins drew his firearm.  Officer Wilkins told Garibay 
to “Drop that, drop that knife now.”  In my estimation Garibay was within 10 feet of Officer Wilkins at 
this point.   
 
 
 
Page 10 
 
At 01:00:14, Garibay said, “Shoot me” and advanced towards Officer Kusumo. 
 
Garibay changed his advancement towards Officer Wilkins.  By this time Officer Wilkins had ordered 
Garibay to “drop the knife” seven times.  Officer Kusumo told Garibay to “drop it” five times and “drop 
the knife” two additional times.   
 
 
 
Page 11 
 
Garibay told the officers “Shoot me” three separate times.  Officer Wilkins and Officer Kusumo 
continued to tell Garibay to “drop the knife.”   
 
 
At 01:00:44, Officer Wilkins announced, “You’re going to get shot, stop.”  In my assessment Garibay 
was steadily walking faster towards Officer Wilkins and an eminent threat to stab Officer Wilkins.    
 
 
 
Page 12 
 
At 01:00:46, Garibay fell to the ground after Officer Wilkins fired four shots and Officer Kusumo fired 
three shots in Garibay’s direction.     
 
 
When Officer Wilkins moved Garibay to provide medical aid, the handle of the knife could be seen. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Page 14 
 
Officer Kusumo fired her first shot; muzzle flash can be seen at 01:00:43. 
 
 
Officer Kusumo fired her second shot and muzzle flash can be seen.  Garibay can be seen falling 
forward.  The BWC does not clearly show Officer Kusumo’s third shot, however it can be heard.

 held his cell 
phone outside the driver’s side window of his vehicle and filmed the incident.  Both Officer Wilkins and

DOJ PHYSICAL EVIDENCE EXAMINATION 
 
At the date of this report, physical evidence examination from the Department of Justice is still pending.  
Evidence items such as bullets, officers’ pistols, spent casings, Garibay’s knife, and a DNA card were 
sent by Detective Rocha to the Department of Justice.  The outcome of the examination will not affect 
the analysis in this report.   
 
INVOLVED OFFICER STATEMENTS  
 
Officer Brandon Wilkins and Officer Kusumo declined to give voluntary statements to MPD detectives.   
 
OFFICER WILKINS’ ROUND COUNT 
 
On October 26, 2023, at 0323 hours, Detective Rocha and Detective Lupian conducted a round count of 
Officer Wilkins’ firearm.  Officer Wilkins had a Sig Sauer P320 9mm (serial number 58H267387).  
There were 17 live rounds in magazine #1 and 1 live round chambered for a total of 18 rounds.  The 
capacity of magazine #1 is 21 rounds.  Fully loaded, Officer Wilkins’ firearm holds 22 rounds. The 
number of rounds remaining in the firearm is consistent with the evidence showing he fired at Garibay a 
total of four times. No rounds were missing from Officer Wilkins’ remaining two magazines.    
 
OFFICER KUSUMO’S ROUND COUNT 
 
On October 26, 2023, at 0353 hours, Detective Rocha and Detective Lupian conducted a round count of 
Officer Kusumo’s firearm.  Officer Kusumo had a department issued Simth and Wesson M&P 9mm 
(serial number HDW1855).  There were 14 live rounds in magazine #1 and 1 live round chambered for a 
total of 15 rounds.  The capacity of magazine #1 is 17 rounds.  Fully loaded, Officer Kusumo’s firearm 
holds 18 rounds. The number of rounds remaining in the firearm is consistent with the evidence showing 
she fired at Garibay a total of three times. No rounds were missing from Officer Kusumo’s remaining 
two magazines.    
 
WITNESS STATEMENTS 
 
Gilbert Garibay’s grandson, 
 told MPD Officer Chavez that Gilbert left their house 
around 0100 hours.  
 went to look for Garibay around 0130 hours, because he had not come 
home.  
 found the officers on M Street and told Officer Chavez that his grandfather was diabetic.  
Officer Chavez did not tell 
 that his grandfather was shot by officers.     
 
Gilbert Garibay’s daughter, 
 told Detective Rocha that her father never gets up to take a 
walk.  
 explained that her father took blood thinners, had a stint, and had a balloon in his heart

from a prior heart attack.  
 did state that she lived in a separate house from her parents.  Gilbert’s 
wife, 
 was also present while 
 spoke to Detective Rocha.  
 stated Gilbert had 
woken up two nights prior and stated, “somebody was coming to get him.”  
 said Gilbert also said 
somebody in the family was going to “get him” and “everybody knew about it.”  
 did not know 
what Gilbert was talking about.  Both 
 and 
 explained that Gilbert lived in fear. 
 
 said since Gilbert’s change in behavior he felt he needed to have a weapon.  
 told Detective 
Rocha that Gilbert had a lot of knives.  On the night of this incident, Gilbert gave 
 all his money 
and debit card before they went to bed together.  Detective Rocha asked 
 if Gilbert had ever given 
her his money and debit card before and 
 said, “No.”  None of the family members interviewed said

AUTOPSY 
 
On October 27, 2023, Forensic Pathologist Sam Andrews with NAAG Forensic PC performed an 
autopsy on Gilbert Garibay at the Merced County Sheriff’s Office Coroners Facilility.  Dr. Andrews 
determined the cause of the death to be “gunshot wounds.”  In addition, the other significant 
contributory cause(s) of death were “atherosclerotic and hypertensive cardiovascular disease.”   
 
Garibay had gunshot wounds to his neck, two to the right side of this chest, right shoulder, right thigh, 
lower right leg, lower left leg, and a graze gunshot wound to the right side of his face.  The gunshot 
wound to Garibay’s neck caused major injuries to the thyroid gland, trachea, esophagus, spinal cord, 
thoracic vertebrae, and left lung.  The gunshot wounds to Garibay’s upper right chest caused injuries to 
his right lung, right clavicle, right ribs, and right arm.  The gunshot wounds to Garibay’s legs were soft 
tissue injuries only. 
 
Dr. Andrews’s incidental findings revealed enlargement of the heart; “moderate hardening and 
narrowing in the stented region of the blood vessels that supply blood to the heart muscle, a single 
gallstone, and “enlargement and nodularity of the prostate gland.”   
 
TOXICOLOGY 
 
Toxicology tests revealed Garibay’s blood was negative for ethanol and drugs.   
 
CONTACT WITH LAW ENFORCEMENT 
 
No prior law enforcement contacts were located.  Furthermore, there was no exact match found when 
running a criminal history on Gilbert Garibay. 
 
INVESTIGATOR NELSON’S TRAINING AND EXPERENCE WITH EDGED WEAPONS 
 
Throughout my 25 years as a law enforcement officer, I have received ongoing firearm and defensive 
tactic training.  It has been consistently taught to me that edged weapon attacks are highly fatal.  In 
addition, a subject with an edged weapon has the ability to close the distance of 21 feet before I can 
identify the threat, make a decision and react properly with deadly force.      
 
 
 
 
 
Page 17 
APPLICABLE LAW 
 
California Penal Code, Section 196 details the circumstances when a public officer’s intentional killing of 
another is justified.  CALCRIM 507, a jury instruction, uses plain language to describe the elements of 
Penal Code, Section 196, stating:  
 
. . . if he killed someone while acting as a public officer. . . [s]uch a killing is justified, and 
therefore not unlawful, if: 
1.  The [person who killed another] was a public officer; 
2.  The killing was committed while overcoming actual resistance to some legal process or 
while performing any other legal duty; 
3.  The killing was necessary to accomplish one of those lawful purposes; 
 
AND 
 
4.  The [public officer] had probable cause to believe that the decedent posed a threat of 
death or great bodily injury, either to the [public officer] or to others or that [the 
decedent] had committed (insert applicable crime here) and that crime threatened the 
[public officer] or others with death or great bodily injury. 
 
A person has probable cause to believe that someone poses a threat of death or great bodily 
injury when facts known to the person would persuade someone of reasonable caution that 
the other person is going to cause death or great bodily injury to another. 
* * * 
Great bodily injury means significant or substantial physical injury.  It is an injury that is 
greater than minor or moderate harm. 
 
The People have the burden of proving beyond a reasonable doubt that the killing was not 
justified.  If the People have not met this burden, [a jury] must find the [public officer] not 
guilty of murder or manslaughter.  (As was intended by the authors, the language above 
was modified or removed to correspond to the circumstances of this case.  Changes are 
shown in [brackets].  The full text of CALCRIM 507 is attached in the appendix.)  
 
A peace officer who has reasonable cause to believe a person has committed a public offense or is a danger 
to others may use reasonable force to detain or arrest the person, to prevent the person’s escape, or to 
overcome the person’s resistance.  (California Penal Code, Section 835a; CALCRIM 2670.)  An officer 
who detains or arrests a person does not need to retreat or stop his or her efforts if the person resists or 
threatens resistance.  Moreover, using reasonable force does not make the officer an aggressor or cause 
him or her to lose the right to self-defense.  (California Penal Code, Section 835a.)  The person being 
detained or arrested has a duty to permit himself or herself to be detained, and the person must refrain 
from using force or any weapon to resist arrest.  (People v. Allen (1980) 109 Cal.App.3d 981, 985; 
California Penal Code, Section 834a; CALCRIM 2670, 2671, 2672.) 
A peace officer may use deadly force under circumstances where it is reasonably necessary for self-
defense or defense of another.  (California Penal Code, Sections, 196 and 197.)  California law permits 
the use of deadly force if the person actually and reasonable believed he/she or another was in imminent 
danger of death or great bodily injury.  It is the reasonable appearance of danger to the officer and his/her 
 
 
Page 18 
honest belief in that danger which is controlling.  If an officer actually believes that deadly force is 
necessary and that belief is reasonable under the circumstances, the officer’s actions are lawful even if it 
is later determined that the danger did not actually exist.  (CALCRIM 505, 507; People v. Toledo (1948) 
85 Cal.App.2d 577; People v. Jackson (1965) 233 Cal.App.2d 639.)  Further, the officer need not prove 
that he/she had the right to use deadly force. Rather, it is the prosecution which must prove that the officer 
did not have that right.

advised that this was causing a hematoma to set in and push the severe bruising to make his eyes purple and 
swollen shut. The CT scan also revealed Ernesto's nose to have a fracture. Bayardo stated that Ernesto would need 
be airlifted to CRMC for critical care immediately. Airlift was denied due to weather conditions.

Report # 23-0002747 - Supplemental - B Report
NARRATIVE
REASON FOR STOP: Call for service wanted felon.
SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTIGATION: On August 19, 2023 at approximately 2149 hours, I was on routine patrol as the 
on-duty Sergeant. My uniform consisted of a Navy-blue long sleeve shirt with a “City of Reedley Police” patch and 
blue/gold chevrons on each arm. On the left breast of my shirt is a gold-colored badge and the right is a gold name 
tag and a department issued body worn camera (BWC). I was wearing a pair of clear prescription glasses. I was 
wearing a black leather duty belt, navy blue pants and black boots. I was driving Reedley PD unit 713, which has a 
traditional black and white color pattern and is fully marked with red and blue emergency lights.
Officers were dispatched to 
 
 for a reporting party stating that they were advised to 
call police if Ernesto Carrillo (9/17/86) returned to the residence. Ernesto was last seen wearing a gray shirt, blue 
jeans and a red baseball hat. I recalled being briefed at the start of my shift, which occurred around 1900 hours, that 
Ernesto had vandalized his girlfriend’s vehicle and fled prior to officers arriving. I was further advised that he had an 
active and confirmed felony warrant for PC 273.5 and PC 236, and was yet to be arrested. I recalled a specific case 
from about a month earlier where Ernesto had assaulted his girlfriend at the Edgewater Inn in Reedley. I 
remembered that incident due to the numerous times he was arrested for felony and misdemeanor domestic violence 
and for violating restraining orders. I was able to see his criminal history when I was reviewing the officers report 
from the assault at the Edgewater Inn. I could not remember the last time I had seen so many arrests for domestic 
violence by one person. I believed that Ernesto had a propensity for violence based off of his criminal history and 
based off of his habitual drug use.
Prior to responding, I called dispatch via phone and confirmed the felony warrant was active. Shortly after hanging 
up, I received a photograph of Ernesto from dispatch.
I activated my department issued BWC prior to arriving on scene. When I arrived on scene, prior to exiting my patrol 
vehicle, I heard officers advise that Ernesto had left the apartment prior to our arrival. State Center Community 
College District (SCCCD) Police Officer Serrano asked over the Reedley PD radio channel to confirm the subjects 
name of who we were looking for. Officer Serrano was advised it was Ernesto Carrillo and he stated that he had just 
contacted him in the Reedley College parking lot, for further refer to SCCCD report number 23-564.
While responding to the area Officer Serrano stated that Ernesto was in the front yard of a residence with a white 
picket fence on Reed Ave. in the area of Kip Patrick Ave. As I was driving towards that intersection, Officer Serrano 
advised that Ernesto was south of Kip Patrick Ave. on Reed Ave. I believed that Ernesto was still going to be on the 
east side of Reed Ave. when either myself or another officer would contact him. I requested an officer go to 
Riverview Ave. south of Kip Patrick Ave. in case Ernesto ran east bound from Reed Ave. I believed that Ernesto 
would run based off a prior radio transmission from Officer Cardinalle regarding Ernesto running and the severity of 
the warrant for his arrest. I wanted a perimeter set up quickly in case he fled, because I did not want him to escape. I 
feared that if he escaped, the female who was the victim of the felony assault and false imprisonment, may be at risk 
of retaliation from Ernesto if she called.

Officer Serrano asked for a Reedley Unit to drive south on Reed Ave. to contact Ernesto. When I turned southbound, 
I observed a moderate amount of traffic on the roadway. Along the roadway are streetlights that artificially light the 
area. Some areas are dimly lit and others are moderately lit. I drove approximately 50 yards and Officer Serrano 
advised me that Ernesto was to the left of my unit.
I briefly stopped and turned to contact a subject on the east sidewalk of Reed Ave. and did not recognize the subject 
from the photograph as Ernesto. Officer Serrano stated that subject I was going to contact was not Ernesto. As I 
turned and drove my unit south on Reed Ave. Officer Serrano advised he had his spotlight on Ernesto and he was 
running south bound. I observed Ernesto running southbound approximately 50 yards south of me on the east 
sidewalk of Reed Ave.. I activated my overhead emergency code 3 lights and my siren. My patrol vehicle was in the 
north and southbound lane of Reed Ave and approximately 25 yards from Ernesto. Ernesto hands were swinging 
from front to back above his waist as he was running. I observed his right hand to be empty. As his left hand was 
brought back, as he was running, his left hand had a silver somewhat reflective object protruding from his hand. At 
the time, I believed the object could possibly be a firearm or knife. While he was running Ernesto was illuminated by 
passing vehicles headlights and turning his head over his right shoulder looking in my direction.
I passed at least one, possibly two vehicles and drove almost parallel to Ernesto along the east curb of S. Reed Ave. 
As Ernesto was running, I could clearly see he was wearing baggy clothing that could easily conceal a weapon and 
he was grabbing at his left pocket. I wanted to pull nearly parallel to Ernesto because I did not want him to run into 
oncoming traffic, endangering himself and/or motorists. I had this in my mind at the time because of two separate 
body cameras I had seen in the last month of subjects being hit by oncoming traffic while fleeing police. I rolled down 
the driver side window of my patrol vehicle. My driver side mirror was approximately 3 yards behind Ernesto and 3 
yards from his right side. I unholstered and activated my department issued Conducted Energy Device (CED). I told 
Ernesto in a loud clear voice “Stop Police” but he continued running and looked over his shoulder and directly at me. 
I pointed my CED at Ernesto at some point after I rolled my driver side window down. I once again said, “Stop Police” 
in a loud clear voice and Ernesto continued running. At this point the area was dimly lit to me and I could not have a 
clear and uninterrupted view of Ernesto’s hands. I warned him "You're gonna get tased", and he did not stop. I 
deployed my department issued CED and Ernesto’s feet came fully of the ground and he landed on the concrete with 
his face and upper chest area.
I stopped, put my patrol vehicle in park and exited my patrol vehicle as my department issued CED was completing 
its pre-set five second cycle. Once the CED was finished cycling, Ernesto sat up and I saw a large amount of blood 
dripping from his face and covering the sidewalk. I yelled at Ernesto to show me his hands, twice, which he did not 
comply. I chose not to activate the CED again because of Ernesto’s injuries. As officers ran up to place Ernesto in 
handcuffs, I requested EMS code 3 for Ernesto before the handcuffs were fully applied to his wrists. I requested EMS 
code 3 due to Ernesto’s injuries to his head. Ernesto was making groaning noises, which I believed to be from pain 
he was feeling. Within minutes Ernesto was talking to officers about the handcuffs being tight. During a search of 
Ernesto, I observed officer Nava remove an object from Ernesto’s left pocket or waistband area. The object had a 
black handle approximately four inches long and a silver piece of metal that protrude from the tool. When the object 
was removed, I initially thought it was a “Zip gun”. A zip gun is a personally manufactured firearm from common 
items. I then realized it was a “window punch”, which is a tool used to break car windows. I believe this item may 
have been what Ernesto was running with but can not be certain, as I did not have a view of his left hand during the 
entire contact.
I was also advised that Ernesto had a knife on him. I advised officers to place Ernesto on his side, to prevent him 
from aspirating blood from the facial trauma. Ernesto sat up and I believed allowing him to be in a position of comfort 
would be most beneficial for him. I did instruct officers not to allow him to lay on his back. I was able to see that one 
probe from the CED struck Ernesto on the back of his upper neck and the other on the right side of his lower back. 
During the call I photograph Ernesto and provided them to Officer Renteria to be attached to this report.

NARRATIVE
SUPEMENTAL REPORT:
On 08/18/2023 at approximately 2149 hours during uniform patrol and driving a marked patrol vehicle, I assisted 
Officer Renteria on a unwanted subject call for service. The location provided for 
 
 Reedley 
PD dispatch advised the subject's name is Ernesto Carrillo and he had an active Felony warrant.
I worked the night before and was aware of Ernesto's warrant. The night before Ernesto was involved in a vandalism 
(for further information regarding the vandalism see case number 23-2741). I have had prior contacts with Ernesto 
for felony domestic violence.
I advised assisting officers over the radio that he had priors for felony domestic violence.
I arrived on scene and started a perimeter at the apartments to the north.
Assisting officers arrived on scene to contact Ernesto. Officer Renteria advised over the radio that the reporting party 
(RP) stated Ernesto left the scene. Officer Renteria advised he was last seen wearing a gray shirt and blue jeans.
Officer Serrano from State Center Community College District (SCCCD) advised over the radio that a male matching 
the description was on Reed Ave walking southbound. Officer Serrano stated over the radio that it was Ernesto, and 
he was now running southbound Reed Ave.
I drove southbound in the 1200 block N. Reed Ave east alleyway in case Ernesto ran eastbound.
Sgt. Puryear advised over the radio that he was contacted Ernesto and he was actively running. Shortly after Sgt. 
Puryear asked for EMS to respond with lights and sirens.
I arrived on scene and observed Officer Renteria standing by Ernesto while Ernesto was handcuffed and sitting on 
the curb. I walked up with my medical bag and notice Ernesto was bleeding from his nose. I did not want to make it 
difficult for Ernesto to breath so I tried to keep him leaned forward so he would not choke from his blood.
Ernesto kept trying to get up so I told him multiple times to stay seated. He would move around so I tried to keep him 
still to avoid any further injuries.
Officer Renteria stood by Ernesto so I could stay available for any other calls for service.

SYNOPSIS: 
On August 19, 22023 at approximately 2148 hours, Officers were dispatched to 
regarding a domestic disturbance. Officers were made aware that the 
male subject involved, Ernesto Carrillo (9/17/86) had an active felony warrant for PC 
273.5(a) (Domestic Violence) and PC 236 (False Imprisonment). Sergeant Puryear and 
other Officers were aware that Carrillo has a very lengthy history of being involved 
in 
domestic disturbances which included multiple felony charges. 
  
As Officers were arriving in the area, they received information that Carrillo had fled the 
area on foot. Officers were checking in the area in an attempt to locate Ernest Carrillo 
when State Center College Police Officer Gerrardo Serrano advised Reedley Officers that 
he had located a male subject matching Carrillo’s description. Officer Serrano gave an 
update stating this male subject was on Reed Ave. walking south bound from Kip Patrick 
Ave.
Multiple Officers were responding to the area when Sergeant Puryear located Carrillo 
walking south bound on the east side of Reed Ave. in front of Reedley College. 
Sergeant Puryear activated his emergency overhead lights and siren and was attempting 
to get Carrillo to stop. Carrillo was now running south bound and Sergeant Puryear 
observed something silver in Carrillo’s left hand. Sergeant Puryear believed this could be 
a firearm or a knife. Sergeant Puryear yelled “Stop Police” twice and Carrillo continued 
running while looking over his shoulder at Sergeant Puryear. 
Sergeant Puryear then yelled stop or you are going to get tased. Carrillo continued to run 
and Sergeant Puryear deployed his department issued Conducted Energy Device (CED). 
Mr. Carrillo fell forward on the concrete sidewalk causing visible facial injuries. Sergeant 
Puryear requested E.M.S. respond to his location Code 3 to render medical aid to Carrillo. 
E.M.S. 
responded 
code 
3 
and 
arrived 
approximately 
four 
minutes 
later. 
E.M.S. 
transported Carrillo to Adventist Health Hospital in Reedley. After receiving medical care 
at Adventist Health, doctors decided Carrillo needed better trauma care and ordered him 
to be transported to CRMC in Fresno. 
A short time later, Carrillo was transported to CRMC by ambulance with a Reedley Police 
Officer following in 
a marked Reedley Police vehicle. 
Early the next morning, Sergeant Puryear received information that Carrillo was in critical 
but stable condition.
SUMMARY 
There are two department policy violations alleged in this investigation and all are related 
to conduct. 
ALLEGATION 
1 
- Excessive Force (Section 300.3 
in 
part, of our Use of Force 
Policy)- Officers shall use only that amount of force that reasonably appears 
necessary given the facts and totality of the circumstances known or perceived by 
the officer at the time of the event to accomplish a legitimate law enforcement 
purpose. Exonerated 
Sergeant Puryear was responding to a call for service where the suspect (Carrillo) has a 
history of domestic violence and had a confirmed felony warrant for PC 273.5 (A) and PC 
236. Carrillo was running from police and had something in his left hand that appeared to 
be a weapon. This item was later determined to be a metal “window punch” which 
is 
commonly used to break vehicle windows. 
The findings of this allegation are Exonerated based on a report from Sergeant Puryear, 
statements from other Officers, Body worn camera footage and police reports. 
ALLEGATION 
2 - Excessive Force (Conducted Energy Device) Policy Section 
309.5.1) The CED may be used, when the circumstances reasonably perceived by 
the officer at the time indicate that such application reasonably appears necessary 
to 
control 
a 
person 
who: 
(a) 
is 
violent 
or 
is 
physically 
resisting. 
(b) 
has 
demonstrated, by words or action, an intention to be violent or to physically resist, 
and reasonably appears to present the potential to harm officer, themselves, or 
others. Exonerated 
Sergeant Puryear was aware of Carrillo's history of domestic violence. Sergeant Puryear 
also believed that if Carrillo had escaped, the female victim of the felony assault may be 
in danger if Carrillo believed it was her that called police. Sergeant Puryear also believed 
Carrillo may have had a weapon in his left had as he was running. The item in his hand

Reedley Police Department 
300 
Reedley PD Policy Manual 
  
  
Use of Force 
300.1 
PURPOSE AND SCOPE 
This policy provides guidelines on the reasonable use of force. While there is no way to specify 
the exact amount or type of reasonable force to be applied in any situation, every member of 
this department is expected to use these guidelines to make such decisions in a professional, 
impartial, and reasonable manner (Government Code § 7286). 
In addition 
to those methods, techniques, and tools set forth below, the guidelines for the 
reasonable application of force contained 
in this policy shall apply to 
all policies addressing 
the potential use of force, including but not limited to the Control Devices and Techniques and 
Conducted Energy Device policies. 
Retaliation prohibitions for reporting suspected violations are addressed in the Anti-Retaliation 
Policy. 
300.1.1 
DEFINITIONS 
Definitions related to this policy include: 
Deadly force - Any use of force that creates a substantial risk of causing death or serious bodily 
injury, including but not limited to the discharge of a firearm (Penal Code § 835a). 
Feasible 
- Reasonably capable 
of being done 
or carried out under the circumstances 
to 
successfully achieve the arrest or lawful objective without increasing risk to the officer or another 
person (Government Code § 7286(a)). 
Force - The application of physical techniques or tactics, chemical agents, or weapons to another 
person. 
It is not a use of force when a person allows him/herself to be searched, escorted, 
handcuffed, or restrained. 
Serious bodily injury - A serious impairment of physical condition, including but not limited to 
the following: loss of consciousness; concussion; bone fracture; protracted loss or impairment 
of function of any bodily member or organ; a wound requiring extensive suturing; and serious 
disfigurement (Penal Code § 243(f)(4)). 
Totality of the circumstances - All facts known to the officer at the time, including the conduct 
of the officer and the subject leading up to the use of force (Penal Code § 835a). 
300.2 
POLICY 
The use of force by law enforcement personnel is a matter of critical concern, both to the public 
and to the law enforcement community. Officers are involved on a daily basis in numerous and 
varied interactions and, when warranted, may use reasonable force in carrying out their duties. 
Officers must have an understanding of, and true appreciation for, their authority and limitations. 
This is especially true with respect to overcoming resistance while engaged in the performance 
of law enforcement duties.

The Agency recognizes and respects the value of all human life and dignity without prejudice to 
anyone. Vesting officers with the authority to use reasonable force and to protect the public welfare 
requires monitoring, evaluation and a careful balancing of all interests. 
300.2.1 
DUTY TO INTERCEDE 
Any officer present and observing another law enforcement officer or an employee using force 
that is clearly beyond that which is necessary, as determined by an objectively reasonable officer 
under the circumstances, shall, when in a position to do so, intercede (as defined by Government 
Code § 7286) to prevent the use of unreasonable force. 
When observing force used by a law enforcement officer, each officer should take into account 
the totality of the circumstances and the possibility that other law enforcement officers may have 
additional information regarding the threat posed by the subject (Government Code § 7286(b)). 
300.2.2 
FAIR AND UNBIASED USE OF FORCE 
Officers are expected to carry out their duties, including the use of force, in 
a manner that is fair 
and unbiased (Government Code § 7286(b)). See the Bias-Based Policing Policy for additional 
guidance. 
300.2.3 
DUTY TO REPORT EXCESSIVE FORCE 
Any officer who observes a law enforcement officer or an employee use force that potentially 
exceeds what the officer reasonably believes to be necessary shall immediately report these 
observations to a supervisor (Government Code § 7286(b)). 
As used in this subsection, "immediately" means as soon as it is safe and feasible to do so. 
300.2.4 
FAILURE TO INTERCEDE 
An officer who has received the required training on the duty to intercede and then fails to act to 
intercede when required by law, may be disciplined in the same manner as the officer who used 
force beyond that which is necessary (Government Code § 7286(b)). 
300.3 
USE OF FORCE 
Officers shall use only that amount of force that reasonably appears necessary given the facts 
and totality of the circumstances known to or perceived by the officer at the time of the event to 
accomplish a legitimate law enforcement purpose (Penal Code § 835a). 
The reasonableness of force will be judged from the perspective of 
a reasonable officer on the 
scene at the time of the incident. Any evaluation of reasonableness must allow for the fact that 
officers are often forced to make split-second decisions about the amount of force that reasonably 
appears necessary in a particular situation, with limited information and in circumstances that are 
tense, uncertain, and rapidly evolving. 
Given that no policy can realistically predict every possible situation an officer might encounter, 
officers are entrusted to use well-reasoned discretion in determining the appropriate use of force in 
each incident. Officers may only use a level of force that they reasonably believe is proportional to

Published with permission by Reedley Police Department

Use of Force 
  
the seriousness of the suspected offense or the reasonably perceived level of actual or threatened 
resistance (Government Code § 7286(b)). 
lt is also recognized that circumstances may arise in which officers reasonably believe that 
it 
would be impractical or ineffective to use any of the approved or authorized tools, weapons, or 
methods provided by the Agency. Officers may find 
it more effective or reasonable to improvise 
their response to rapidly unfolding conditions that they are confronting. In such circumstances, the 
use of any improvised device or method must nonetheless be objectively reasonable and utilized 
only to the degree that reasonably appears necessary to accomplish a legitimate law enforcement 
purpose. 
While the ultimate objective of every law enforcement encounter is to avoid or minimize injury, 
nothing in this policy requires an officer to retreat or be exposed to possible physical injury before 
applying reasonable force. 
300.3.1 
USE OF FORCE TO EFFECT AN ARREST 
Any peace officer may use objectively reasonable force to effect an arrest, to prevent escape, 
or to overcome resistance. A peace officer who makes or attempts to make an arrest need not 
retreat or desist from his/her efforts by reason of resistance or threatened resistance on the part 
of the person being arrested; nor shall an officer be deemed the aggressor or lose his/her right to 
self-defense by the use of reasonable force to effect the arrest, prevent escape, or to overcome 
resistance. Retreat does not mean tactical repositioning or other de-escalation techniques (Penal 
Code § 835a). 
300.3.2 
FACTORS USED TO DETERMINE THE REASONABLENESS OF FORCE 
When determining whether to apply force and evaluating whether an officer has used reasonable 
force, 
a number of factors should be taken into consideration, as time and circumstances permit 
(Government Code § 7286(b)). These factors include but are not limited to: 
(a) 
The apparent immediacy and severity of the threat to officers or others (Penal Code 
§ 835a). 
(b) 
The conduct of the individual being confronted, as reasonably perceived by the officer 
at the time (Penal Code § 835a). 
(c) 
Officer/subject factors (age, size, relative strength, skill level, injuries sustained, level 
of exhaustion or fatigue, the number of officers available vs. subjects). 
(d) 
The conduct of the involved officer leading up to the use of force (Penal Code $ 835a). 
(e) 
The effects of suspected drugs or alcohol. 
(f) 
The individual's apparent mental state or capacity (Penal Code $ 835a). 
(g) 
The individual's apparent ability to understand and comply with officer commands 
(Penal Code $ 835a). 
(h) 
Proximity of weapons or dangerous improvised devices.

(i) 
| The degree to which the subject has been effectively restrained and his/her ability to 
resist despite being restrained. 
(j) 
The 
availability 
of 
other 
reasonable 
and 
feasible 
options 
and 
their 
possible 
effectiveness (Penal Code $ 835a). 
(k) 
Seriousness of the suspected offense or reason for contact with the individual prior 
to and at the time force is used. 
(l) 
Training and experience of the officer. 
(m) 
Potential for injury to officers, suspects, bystanders, and others, 
(n) 
Whether the person appears to be resisting, attempting to evade arrest by flight, or 
is attacking the officer. 
(o) 
The risk and reasonably foreseeable consequences of escape. 
(p) 
The apparent need for immediate control of the subject or a prompt resolution of the 
situation. 
(q) 
Whether the conduct of the individual being confronted no longer reasonably appears 
to pose an imminent threat to the officer or others. 
(r) 
Prior contacts with the subject or awareness of any propensity for violence. 
(s) 
Any other exigent circumstances. 
300.3.3 
PAIN COMPLIANCE TECHNIQUES 
Pain compliance techniques may be effective 
in controlling 
a physically or actively resisting 
individual. Officers may only apply those pain compliance techniques 
for which they have 
successfully completed department-approved training. Officers utilizing any pain compliance 
technique should consider: 
(a) 
The degree to which the application of the technique may be controlled given the level 
of resistance. 
(b) 
Whether the person can comply with the direction or orders of the officer. 
(c) 
Whether the person has been given sufficient opportunity to comply. 
The application 
of any 
pain compliance technique 
shall 
be discontinued once 
the 
officer 
determines that compliance has been achieved. 
300.3.4 
RESTRICTIONS ON THE USE OF CAROTID CONTROL HOLD 
Officers of this department are not authorized to use a carotid restraint hold. A carotid restraint 
means a vascular neck restraint or any similar restraint, hold, or other defensive tactic in which 
pressure is applied to the sides of a person’s neck that involves a substantial risk of restricting 
blood flow and may render the person unconscious in order to subdue or control the person 
(Government Code § 7286.5).

300.3.5 
USE OF FORCE TO SEIZE EVIDENCE 
In general, officers may use reasonable force to lawfully seize evidence and to prevent the 
destruction of evidence. However, officers are discouraged from using force solely to prevent 
a person from swallowing evidence or contraband. In the instance when force is used, officers 
should not intentionally use any technique that restricts blood flow to the head, restricts respiration 
or which creates a reasonable likelihood that blood flow to the head or respiration would be 
restricted. Officers are encouraged to use techniques and methods taught by the Reedley Police 
Department for this specific purpose. 
300.3.6 
ALTERNATIVE TACTICS - DE-ESCALATION 
As time and circumstances reasonably permit, and when community and officer safety would 
not be compromised, officers should consider actions that may increase officer safety and may 
decrease the need for using force: 
(a) 
Summoning additional resources that are able to respond 
in 
a reasonably timely 
manner. 
(b) 
Formulating a plan with responding officers before entering an unstable situation that 
does not reasonably appear to require immediate intervention. 
(c) 
Employing other tactics that do not unreasonably increase officer jeopardy. 
In addition, when reasonable, officers should evaluate the totality of circumstances presented at 
the time in each situation and, when feasible, consider and utilize reasonably available alternative 
tactics and techniques that may persuade an individual to voluntarily comply or may mitigate the 
need to use a higher level of force to resolve the situation before applying force (Government 
Code § 7286(b)). Such alternatives may include but are not limited to: 
(a) 
Attempts to de-escalate a situation. 
(b) 
If reasonably available, the use of crisis intervention techniques by properly trained 
personnel. 
300.3.7 
RESTRICTIONS ON THE USE OF A CHOKE HOLD 
Officers of this department are not authorized to use a choke hold. A choke hold means any 
defensive tactic or force option in which direct pressure is applied to a person’s trachea or windpipe 
(Government Code § 7286.5). 
300.3.8 
ADDITIONAL RESTRICTIONS 
Terms such as "positional asphyxia," "restraint asphyxia," and "excited delirium" continue to 
remain the subject of debate among experts and medical professionals, are not universally 
recognized medical conditions, and frequently involve other collateral or controlling factors such 
as narcotics or alcohol influence or pre-existing medical conditions. While it is impractical to restrict 
an officer's use of reasonable control methods when attempting to restrain a combative individual, 
officers are not authorized to use any restraint or transportation method which might unreasonably 
impair an individual's breathing or respiratory capacity for 
a period beyond the point when the 
individual has been adequately and safely controlled. Once the individual is safely secured, officers

should promptly check and continuously monitor the individual's condition for signs of medical 
distress (Government Code § 7286.5). 
300.4 
DEADLY FORCE APPLICATIONS 
Where feasible, the officer shall, prior to the use of deadly force, make reasonable efforts to identify 
themself as a peace officer and to warn that deadly force may be used, unless the officer has 
objectively reasonable grounds to believe the person is aware of those facts (Penal Code § 835a). 
If an objectively reasonable officer would consider it safe and feasible to do so under the totality 
of the circumstances, officers shall evaluate and use other reasonably available resources and 
techniques when determining whether to use deadly force. To the extent that 
it is reasonably 
practical, officers should consider their surroundings and any potential risks to bystanders prior to 
discharging a firearm (Government Code § 7286(b)). 
The use of deadly force is only justified when the officer reasonably believes it is necessary in the 
following circumstances (Penal Code § 835a): 
(a) 
An officer may use deadly force to protect themself or others from what the officer 
reasonably believes is an imminent threat of death or serious bodily injury to the officer 
or another person. 
(b) 
An officer may use deadly force to apprehend a fleeing person for any felony that 
threatened or resulted 
in death or serious bodily injury, 
if the officer reasonably 
believes that the person will cause death or serious bodily injury to another unless 
immediately apprehended. 
Officers shall not use deadly force against a person based on the danger that person poses to 
themself, if an objectively reasonable officer would believe the person does not pose an imminent 
threat of death or serious bodily injury to the officer or to another person (Penal Code § 835a). 
Additionally, an officer should not use deadly force against a person whose actions are a threat 
solely to property. 
An "imminent" threat of death or serious bodily injury exists when, based on the totality of the 
circumstances, a reasonable officer in the same situation would believe that a person has the 
present ability, opportunity, and apparent intent to immediately cause death or serious bodily injury 
to the officer or another person. An officer's subjective fear of future harm alone is insufficient as 
an imminent threat. An imminent threat is one that from appearances is reasonably believed to 
require instant attention (Penal Code § 835a). 
300.4.1 
SHOOTING AT OR FROM MOVING VEHICLES 
Shots fired at or from a moving vehicle are rarely effective and involve considerations and risks 
in addition to the justification for the use of deadly force. When feasible, officers should take 
reasonable steps to move out of the path of an approaching vehicle instead of discharging their 
firearm at the vehicle or any of its occupants. An officer should only discharge a firearm at 
a moving 
vehicle or its occupants when the officer reasonably believes there are no other reasonable means

available to avert the imminent threat of the vehicle, or if deadly force other than the vehicle is 
directed at the officer or others (Government Code § 7286(b)). 
Officers should not shoot at any part of a vehicle in an attempt to disable the vehicle. 
300.4.2 
DISPLAYING OF FIREARMS 
Given that individuals might perceive the display of a firearm as a potential application of force, 
officers should carefully evaluate each tactical situation and use sound discretion when drawing 
a firearm in public by considering the following guidelines (Government Code § 7286(b)): 
(a) 
If the officer does not initially perceive 
a threat but reasonably believes that the 
potential for such threat exists, firearms should generally be kept in the low-ready or 
other position not directed toward an individual. 
(b) 
If the 
officer reasonably believes 
that 
a threat exists 
based 
on 
the 
totality 
of 
circumstances presented 
at the time 
(e.g., 
high-risk stop, 
tactical 
entry, armed 
encounter), firearms may be directed toward such threat until the officer no longer 
perceives such threat. 
Once it is reasonably safe to do so, officers should carefully secure all firearms. 
300.5 
REPORTING THE USE OF FORCE 
Any use of force by 
a member of this department shall be documented promptly, completely, 
and accurately in an appropriate report, depending on the nature of the incident. The officer 
should articulate the factors perceived and why he/she believed the use of force was reasonable 
under the circumstances. To collect data for purposes of training, resource allocation, analysis, 
and related purposes, the Agency may require the completion of additional report forms, as 
specified in department policy, procedure, or law. See the Report Preparation Policy for additional 
circumstances that may require documentation. 
300.5.1 
NOTIFICATION TO SUPERVISORS 
Any use of force by an officer shall be reported immediately to a supervisor, including but not 
limited to the following circumstances (Penal Code § 832.13): 
(a) 
The application caused a visible injury. 
(b) 
The application would lead a reasonable officer to conclude that the individual may 
have experienced more than momentary discomfort. 
(c) 
The individual subjected to the force complained of injury or continuing pain. 
(d) 
The individual indicates intent to pursue litigation. 
(e) 
Any application of 
a conducted energy device or control device. 
(f) 
| Any application of a restraint device other than handcuffs, shackles, or belly chains. 
(g) 
The individual subjected to the force was rendered unconscious. 
(h) 
An individual was struck or kicked.

(i) 
An individual alleges unreasonable force was used or that any of the above has 
occurred. 
As used in this subsection, "immediately" means as soon as it is safe and feasible to do so. 
300.5.2 
REPORTING TO CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE 
Statistical data regarding 
all officer-involved shootings and incidents involving use 
of force 
resulting in serious bodily injury is to be reported to the California Department of Justice as required 
by Government Code § 12525.2. See the Records Center Policy. 
300.5.3 
REPORT RESTRICTIONS 
Officers shall not use the term "excited delirium" to describe an individual in an incident report. 
Officers may describe the characteristics of an individual's conduct, 
but shall not generally 
describe the individual's demeanor, conduct, or physical and mental condition at issue as "excited 
delirium" (Health and Safety Code § 24402). 
300.6 
MEDICAL CONSIDERATIONS 
Once 
it is reasonably safe to do so, properly trained officers should promptly provide or procure 
medical assistance for any person injured or claiming to have been injured in a use of force incident 
(Government Code § 7286(b)). 
Prior to booking or release, medical assistance shall be obtained for any person who exhibits signs 
of physical distress, who has sustained visible injury, expresses a complaint of injury or continuing 
pain, or who was rendered unconscious. Any individual exhibiting signs of physical distress after 
an encounter should be continuously monitored until the individual can be medically assessed. 
Based upon the officer's initial assessment of the nature and extent of the subject's injuries, 
medical assistance may consist of examination by fire personnel, paramedics, hospital staff, or 
medical staff at the jail. 
If any such individual refuses medical attention, such a refusal shall be 
fully documented in related reports and, whenever practicable, should be witnessed by another 
officer and/or medical personnel. 
If a recording is made of the contact or an interview with the 
individual, any refusal should be included in the recording, if possible. 
The on-scene supervisor or, if the on-scene supervisor is not available, the primary handling officer 
shall ensure that any person providing medical care or receiving custody of a person following any 
use of force is informed that the person was subjected to force. This notification shall include a 
description of the force used and any other circumstances the officer reasonably believes would 
be potential safety or medical risks to the subject (e.g., prolonged struggle, extreme agitation, 
impaired respiration). 
Persons who exhibit extreme 
agitation, violent irrational behavior accompanied 
by profuse 
sweating, extraordinary strength beyond their physical characteristics and imperviousness to pain, 
or who require a protracted physical encounter with multiple officers to be brought under control, 
may be at an increased risk of sudden death. Calls involving these persons should be considered 
medical emergencies. Officers who reasonably suspect a medical emergency should request 
medical assistance as soon as practicable and have medical personnel stage away if appropriate.

In the event that a supervisor is unable to respond to the scene of an incident involving the reported

300.7.1 
WATCH COMMANDER RESPONSIBILITY 
The Watch Commander shall review each use of force by any personnel within his/her command 
to ensure compliance with this policy.

300.8 
TRAINING 
Officers, investigators, and supervisors will receive annual training on this policy and demonstrate 
their knowledge and understanding (Government Code § 7286(b)). 
300.8.1 
TRAINING REQUIREMENTS 
Required annual training shall include: 
(a) 
Legal updates. 
(b) 
De-escalation tactics, including alternatives to force. 
(c) 
The duty to intercede. 
(d) 
The duty to request and/or render medical aid. 
(e) 
Warning shots (see the Firearms Policy). 
(f) 
All other subjects covered in this policy (e.g., use of deadly force, chokeholds and 
carotid holds, discharge of a firearm at or from a moving vehicle, verbal warnings). 
(g) 
Training courses required by and consistent with POST guidelines set forth in Penal 
Code $ 13519.10. 
See the Training Policy for restrictions relating to officers who are the subject of a sustained use 
of force complaint. 
300.8.2 
STATE-SPECIFIC TRAINING REQUIREMENTS 
Required 
state-specific 
training 
shall 
include 
guidelines 
regarding 
vulnerable 
populations, 
including but not limited to children, elderly persons, pregnant individuals, and individuals with 
physical, mental, and developmental disabilities (Government Code $ 7286(b)). 
300.9 
USE OF FORCE ANALYSIS 
At least annually, the Operations Division Commander should prepare an analysis report on use 
of force incidents. The report should be submitted to the Chief of Police. The report should not 
contain the names of officers, suspects or case numbers, and should include: 
(a) 
The identification of any trends in the use of force by members. 
(b) 
Training needs recommendations. 
(c) 
Equipment needs recommendations. 
(d) 
Policy revision recommendations. 
300.10 
USE OF FORCE COMPLAINTS 
The recejpt, processing, and investigation of civilian complaints involving use of force incidents 
should be handled in accordance with the Personnel Complaints Policy (Government Code 8 
7286(b)).
