the man, Tovar entered his home through a rear door and went to the kitchen. Berta and Ernesto 
didn’t know where Tovar went thereafter he was in the kitchen. 
 
Tovar’s medications:  
Inside Tovar’s home, on a kitchen shelf, I observed multiple medication containers, three of which 
had labels from the CVS pharmacy located at 110 Laurel Drive, Salinas, CA 93906. The labels 
indicated that the medications were prescribed to Tovar by doctors K. Routiher or M. Garuba.  
 
The label on the first container was dated June 10, 2023, and read “15 mg Mirtazapine  tablet” and  
“Take 1 tablet by mouth every day at bedtime.” The prescription was for 30 tablets and the 
container held 29 tables labeled  “0 8 A”  which I verified on the drugs.com website as the imprint 
for Mirtazapine, an antidepressant. The following two images are photographs of this medication: 
 
The label on the second container, dated October 21, 2021, indicated a prescription for 60 
Buspirone Hydrochloride 15 mg pills. The label read, “1 tab by mouth twice daily.” The container 
held 57 intact tables labeled  “5 5 5 TV 1003”  and four half- tablets of the same medicine. The 
drugs.com website indicated that the imprint on the pills matched the container label. The image 
below is a photograph of this medication: 
 
The label on the third container, dated July 20, 2022,  indicated a prescription for 30 Olanzapine  
5 mg tablets. The label read, “take 1 tablet every day at bedtime.” The container held 26 intact 
tables labeled  “CL 40.” The drugs.com website indicated that the imprint on the pills matched the 
container label. The following image is a photograph of this medication:

Conversation with Victim 2: 
On August 9, 2023, at approximately 1423 hours, DAI Hunsaker and I spoke with Victim 2 at her 
father-in-law’s home. Present during our conversation was her husband, Victim 1. I recorded our 
conversation using a digital device (Item LG04) and I transferred the audio file to Evidence.com. 
 
Victim 2 stated that she resided at her home with her daughter (Victim 3) and her husband. On the 
date of the OIS she was at home with her daughter. Victim 1 arrived home from work  at 
approximately 1500 hours to eat, and he returned to work at approximately 1600 hours. 
 
At approximately 2030 hours, someone knocked on her front door, which was closed but unlocked. 
Victim 2 believed that the person at the door was her husband, so she approached the door, looked 
through the door glass, and noticed that the person outside was not her husband, but a young man 
(Tovar) with a small dog. Tovar was wearing a hoodie, sweatpants and a gray or black item over 
his face. Tovar made eye contact with Victim 2, hand signaled for her to open the door and 
remained there for five or ten minutes. Victim 2 panicked and did not open the door. 
 
Victim 2 took her daughter to her master bedroom, stayed there some time, called Victim 1 and 
told him that a stranger was knocking at the front door. Victim 1 told Victim 2 that he was coming 
home and would arrive in ten minutes. Tovar stopped knocking on the front door for approximately 
three minutes and began knocking on the side door that was located on the home’s north side, 
between the kitchen and Victim 3’s room. This door led from the kitchen to the driveway. 
 
Victim 2 called Victim 1 a second time and he tried to talk to Tovar via their front door camera, 
but the device was not working. Victim 1 also told Victim 2 that he was driving home and would 
be there soon. When he arrived, Victim 1 told Victim 2 that, based on what he saw through the

front door camera, he believed Tovar was one of their neighbors. Victim 1 also told Victim 2 that 
he was going to go talk to that neighbor (Tovar) to see what he needed or wanted. 
Victim 1 walked to Tovar’s home, which was located in an alley perpendicular to the victim’s  
street.  After speaking to Tovar, Victim 1 returned home and told Victim 2 that Tovar had gone to 
their home looking for a dog. After talking to Tovar, Victim 1 returned to his residence, and 
approximately ten minutes later, Tovar returned to the porch of the victim’s residence, while 
Victim 1 was taking his work clothes off to get in the shower. 
 
Victim 1 went outside and talked to Tovar, leaving his front door ajar. Tovar ran inside the victims’ 
residence, stood approximately 10 feet away from the front door and produced a knife, while 
Victim 1 stood at the door. When Tovar entered the home, Victim 2 was in the kitchen and her 
daughter was sitting at the kitchen counter, close to the dining room. 
 
Tovar told Victim 1 to close the front door and made incoherent statements, demanding that Victim 
1 help him get his family members and his daughter out of prison. Victim 1 told Tovar to go outside 
with him and let his wife and daughter go. 
 
At some point, Tovar moved closer to Victim 1  (farther away from the child), so Victim 2 took 
advantage of this opportunity to run and pick up Victim 3 from the counter area. She held the child 
in her arms and brought her to the kitchen, behind the counter, near the stove, and away from 
Tovar. Victim 2 grabbed her cellular telephone to call 911 but Tovar told her not to call the police. 
 
While Tovar was making his incoherent demands, Victim 2 attempted to escape with her daughter 
through the aforementioned kitchen side door. Victim 2 held the child with her left arm against her 
chest and handled the door knob with her right hand, but she was unable to open it. 
 
When Victim 2 was facing the side door and struggling to open it, Tovar approached her, stood 
behind her, and prevented her escape by wrapping his left arm across her chest and putting his

knife, with his right hand, against the right side of her neck. Victim 2 felt the blade against her

I asked Victim 2 if she could re-enact this frightening event and she demonstrated Tovar’s actions  
by standing behind Victim 1, wrapping her left arm across his chest and placing her right hand 
against the right side of his neck. 
 
When Tovar held Victim 2 and her daughter hostage in the kitchen, Victim 1 had his cellphone in 
his hands, and Tovar told him not to call the police. Tovar then turned Victim 2 and her daughter 
around 180 degrees, away from the side door and made them face the kitchen refrigerator. Tovar 
then turned Victim 2 and her daughter ninety degrees to the left of the refrigerator and pushed 
them with force, against their will away from the kitchen, towards the child’s bedroom, which was 
located to the east of the kitchen, down a short and narrow hallway.  
 
Tovar kidnapped the Victim2 and Victim 3, closed the child’s bedroom door behind him and also 
closed the bedroom’s window curtain. Tovar ordered Victim 2 to sit at the foot of the bed, which 
she did, as she held her daughter close to her chest with both arms. Tovar began pacing along a 
dresser that was located to the right of the bedroom door, along the bedroom’s west wall. 
 
Tovar then handed Victim 2 his cellular telephone and told her to dial Victim 1’s number. Victim 
2 complied and handed the phone back to Tovar, who continued walking around the room. Victim 
2 did not know if Tovar was able to talk to Victim 1, but eventually Tovar placed his phone on a 
dresser and told Victim 2 that nothing was going to happen to her or her daughter. 
 
Tovar pulled all the dresser drawers out, looking for a gun and he asked Victim 2 if there was a 
gun in her house. Victim 2 told him that there were no guns at her home. Sometime thereafter, 
Victim 2 and Tovar heard sirens, and Tovar told her in Spanish, “I told your husband not to call 
the police, now all of us are going to get fucked.”

Tovar then told Victim Guzmán to put down and let go of her daughter but she refused and  
continued holding the child with both arms against her chest, while sitting at the foot of the child’s 
bed. Tovar removed his belt from his pants, threw it somewhere and unbuttoned his pants.  
 
Tovar, holding his knife in one of his hands, used his other hand to pull down Victim 2’s leggings. 
Tovar grabbed the leggings and pulled them down with force from the waist area two or three 
times. While describing this horrible ordeal, Victim 2 used her hands to re-enact her and Tovar’s 
actions. Victim 2 moved her left arm away from her daughter, continued holding her against her 
chest with her right arm, and swiftly grabbed the top of her leggings near the area where Tovar 
was trying to pull them down and she prevented him from taking her clothes off. Victim 2 told 
Tovar that she would ask Victim 1 not to let the police inside the room and she asked him to not 
do anything to her. 
 
Tovar continued pulling Victim 2’s clothing with such force that he ripped her underwear and 
pulled Victim 2 and her daughter off the bed. Victim 2 remained on the bedroom floor, holding 
her daughter. 
 
While describing the frightening assault, Victim 2 instinctively pulled her leggings down and 
showed DAI Hunsaker and I the hole in her underwear, which she was still wearing. At the 
conclusion of the interview, Victim 2 handed me her ripped underwear, which I delivered to DAI 
Hunsaker for booking at the Monterey County District Attorney’s Office (Item LG01). 
 
Victim 2 believed that Tovar was going to sexually assault her. She feared for her life and 
expected Tovar to stab her with the knife at any time because she had already felt the blade against 
her neck. Victim 2 told Tovar that she would ask Victim 1 not to let the police come inside the 
room and she asked  him to not do anything to her. She also repeatedly yelled at Victim 1 not to 
let the police enter the room, as Tovar had told her that he did not want law enforcement

SYNOPSIS: 
On 08/08/2023, an Officer-Involved Shooting (OIS) occurred at 404 Hyland Dr. in Salinas. 
Decedent Anthony Tovar forced his way into the residence, grabbed a female adult and placed a 
knife to her neck while the adult female was holding her 2-year-old daughter. After Tovar

NARRATIVE: 
On 08/11/2023 at approximately 0940 hours, DAI Torres and I conducted an interview with MCSO 
Acting Sergeant/Detective David Gonzalez who was involved in the OIS. The interview was 
conducted at the Monterey County District Attorney’s Office in Salinas. Also in attendance was 
Sgt. Gonzalez’s legal counsel, Terry Leoni. It should be noted that I audio-recorded the interview 
with Sgt. Gonzalez with my department-issued digital recorder (Item KH 5). The following is a 
summary of my interview with Sgt. Gonzalez.

for the interview and he had spoken with his attorney prior to the interview. I also informed Sgt. 
Gonzalez he could end the interview at any point and request any needed breaks. Two breaks were 
taken and the audio recording was paused during each break. I obtained the following information 
about Sgt. Gonzalez:

After obtaining the information as noted above, I asked Sgt. Gonzalez to describe in detail the 
incident that occurred on 08/08/2023 at 404 Hyland Dr. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he was near the west 
end of Boronda Rd. near Hwy. 183 prior to the OIS. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he was informed by 
dispatch that a male subject had entered a residence with a knife. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he made 
sure the responding deputies were using their emergency lights and sirens enroute to Hyland Dr. 
Sgt. Gonzalez advised dispatch he was near Hyland Dr. and stated he had not activated his 
emergency lights and sirens to respond. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he was going to stage in the area 
when he was advised the male subject had a knife and was with the reporting party’s (RP) wife 
and child. Sgt. Gonzales stated he thought this situation was “a hostage/rescue kind of ordeal.”  
 
Sgt. Gonzalez arrived at El Rancho Way and Hyland Dr. and was approached by the RP (Victim 
1). Sgt. Gonzalez advised dispatch of his contact with the RP and that the RP had informed Sgt. 
Gonzalez the suspect was in a rear bedroom with a knife along with the RP’s wife and child. Sgt. 
Gonzalez observed another deputy behind him and told the deputy, “Let’s go. We’re going to make 
entry into the house.” Sgt. Gonzalez entered the residence at 404 Hyland Dr. and was told by the 
RP the suspect was in the back room and gave permission for Sgt. Gonzalez to kick down the 
interior bedroom door. Sgt. Gonzalez kicked the bedroom door once and observed the door had 
been barricaded by a “heavy object.” Sgt. Gonzalez stated when he noticed the barricade, “That 
kind of like triggered in me like a different feeling. Like, this is serious and there is a lot of truth 
to what this guy’s saying that there’s going to be, we’re going to open the door and we’re going to 
be faced with some kind of scenario.”  
 
Sgt. Gonzalez kicked the bedroom door harder a second time near the door handle breaking the 
door panel. Sgt. Gonzalez was able to open the bedroom door approximately 1 – 1 ½ feet to look 
inside the bedroom. When Sgt. Gonzalez kicked the bedroom door, Deputy Cristian Pantoja was

on Sgt. Gonzalez’s left side while Deputy Josue Ramirez was behind Sgt. Gonzalez and Deputy 
Pantoja. Sgt. Gonzalez looked into the bedroom and saw a lady and child, later identified as Victim 
2 and Victim 3 respectively, sitting on the floor of the bedroom in “the northeast corner.” Victim 
2 was crying and holding Victim 3. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he observed the suspect, later identified 
as Decedent Tovar, standing approximately five feet away from the female and child. Tovar was 
facing toward Sgt. Gonzalez but was holding and pointing a knife at the female and child. It was 
then requested to take a break in the interview. 
 
After the break, Sgt. Gonzalez continued with his statement. Sgt. Gonzalez described the bedroom 
as a small room. After kicking the bedroom door, Tovar was looking at Sgt. Gonzalez and Deputy 
Pantoja. Sgt. Gonzalez saw the knife in Tovar’s hand which Sgt. Gonzalez described as a “kitchen 
knife, 9 inches, he was holding it by the handle, pointing it at the lady and the child.” Sgt. Gonzalez 
gave verbal commands to Tovar to drop the knife. Tovar looked at Sgt. Gonzalez before returning 
his gaze towards the female and child. Sgt. Gonzalez then fired one round at Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez 
said he had previously drawn his pistol upon entering the home and his pistol was kept at “low 
ready” until he encountered Tovar.   
 
Sgt. Gonzalez recognized the object blocking the bedroom door as a clothes dresser approximately 
3 – 4 feet tall and the dresser did not allow the door to be fully opened. Sgt. Gonzalez also observed 
a closet behind Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez stated, “What was going through my head at that point was 
if he gets an opportunity, and he lunges at them with the knife, was that he was going to harm the 
child or the lady, and if he came at us, I would get stabbed or my partner would get stabbed. And 
so as soon as he turned to look at the lady, that’s when I fired my first shot.” Sgt. Gonzalez said 
the shot struck Tovar in the front torso. Sgt. Gonzalez stated Tovar returned to “an aggressive 
stance” and Tovar continued to hold the knife in his right hand. Sgt. Gonzalez ordered Tovar to 
drop the knife and heard Deputy Pantoja also order Tovar to drop the knife.

Sgt. Gonzalez described Tovar as 5’ 6” to 5’ 8” with short hair and thin build. After the first shot,  
Sgt. Gonzalez said Tovar again looked at Sgt. Gonzalez before returning his gaze toward the 
female in the room. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he then fired three additional rounds striking Tovar at 
least twice. Sgt. Gonzalez noticed a spent shell casing in the air and deduced Deputy Pantoja fired 
his pistol as well. After being struck, Tovar fell to the floor. Sgt. Gonzalez heard someone state 
that Tovar still had the knife. Another deputy removed the knife from Tovar and Sgt. Gonzalez 
removed the female and child from the room. Sgt. Gonzalez turned over the female and child to 
Deputy Perez and Sgt. Gonzalez returned to the bedroom where he observed the knife was on the 
floor between Tovar and the female’s location prior to her removal from the room.  
 
Sgt. Gonzalez provided his handcuffs to Deputy Ramirez who handcuffed Tovar. First aid was 
then administered to Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez cleared the remainder of the home and cleared medical 
personnel to enter the residence to continue to administer first aid to Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez directed 
Deputy Perez to separate the female and the RP into separate vehicles. Sgt. Gonzalez assisted in 
directing the set up of the crime scene and making the appropriate notifications of the OIS to 
dispatch. Sgt. Gonzalez directed photographs be taken of the crime scene and the victims. Sgt. 
Gonzalez then returned to MCSO. Sgt. Gonzalez said the RP indicated Tovar was a neighbor and 
Sgt. Gonzalez could not state if he knew the suspect by sight from any previous encounters.  
 
When I asked, Sgt. Gonzalez stated he did announce “Sheriff’s Office” after entering the residence. 
Sgt. Gonzalez stated he did not attempt to force the door open further after kicking the door the 
second time as he and Deputy Pantoja were able to see Tovar through the established opening. Sgt. 
Gonzalez confirmed Tovar held the knife in his right hand. Sgt. Gonzalez was not given a 
description of Tovar prior to encountering Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he ordered Tovar to drop 
the knife 3 – 4 times.

Sgt. Gonzalez did not believe he had any additional options available regarding his use of force 
given the circumstances of the call. Sgt. Gonzalez stated, “At that point with what we were 
addressing, we were presented with a deadly force situation where there was no time to react for a 
Taser because a Taser could be ineffective.” Sgt. Gonzalez stated Tovar appeared to be unaffected 
by the first gunshot. Sgt. Gonzalez said, “In my mind, there was no other option.” Sgt. Gonzalez 
explained the use of a Taser had several drawbacks including agitating Tovar causing Tovar to 
lunge at Sgt. Gonzalez or the female or child.  
 
DAI Torres asked Sgt. Gonzales what was going through his mind when he fired the second volley. 
Sgt. Gonzalez stated Tovar was still “looking for a target because the knife was, like he’s ready to 
go, he’s looking to see, he looked at me and then he looked at the lady and that’s kind of where, 
and the knife was so close to them where it would take one step, one half second, and he could 
have injured like whether it’s fatally or not fatally, and that’s kind of where I thought that he was 
going to take action with the knife.” Sgt. Gonzalez clarified “take action” to mean stabbing the 
victims. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he constantly addressed Tovar and did not give commands to the 
other deputies inside the residence.  
 
Sgt. Gonzalez also clarified that when Tovar looked at Sgt. Gonzalez, Tovar was “scanning for an 
option to attack” and that was the basis for Sgt. Gonzalez’s first shot. Sgt. Gonzalez estimated the 
distance between himself and Tovar to be approximately five feet and Tovar was also 
approximately five feet away from the female and child who were on the floor. Sgt. Gonzalez 
stated Tovar was standing, holding the knife while “scanning and looked like he was thinking 
about what he was going to do. So if he had lunged at the lady, in my head, I thought we would 
not be able to shoot because she would be part of the backdrop. I didn’t want to give him that 
opportunity. Whereas if he had lunged at us, we would still have a clear shot.” Sgt. Gonzalez stated 
other than his commands to Tovar to drop the knife, he did not have time to attempt any other 
forms of de-escalation. Additionally, Sgt. Gonzalez stated he did not have time to discuss the use 
of less than lethal options prior to entering the residence.

Sgt. Gonzalez estimated 1 – 2 minutes elapsed from the time he entered the residence until the 
shots were fired. Sgt. Gonzalez stated Tovar did not say anything during the encounter. Sgt. 
Gonzalez stated had there been ample time to retrieve the less than lethal shotgun, it could have 
been feasible to use. Sgt. Gonzalez stated the call from dispatch, the information he obtained from 
the RP, and the fact the bedroom door was barricaded, confirmed his belief Tovar was the intruder. 
Sgt. Gonzalez said the female was seated on the floor and was “sheltering” the child by holding 
the child with both arms.  While both were crying, neither victim made any comments during the 
incident.  
 
I asked Sgt. Gonzalez what he believed Tovar’s intent was when he first observed Tovar standing 
in the room with the knife. Sgt. Gonzalez said, “To inflict like serious bodily harm on someone.” 
Sgt. Gonzalez believed Tovar was intent on injuring somebody. Another break in the interview 
was taken at this time.  
 
After this break, I asked Sgt. Gonzalez several follow-up questions. I asked Sgt. Gonzalez to 
describe the female’s position on the floor while holding the child. Sgt. Gonzalez stated the female 
was sitting on the floor with her feet near her buttocks providing shelter for the child. Sgt. Gonzalez 
estimated the child to be approximately 2 – 3 years old. Sgt. Gonzalez estimated the female to be 
in her mid-20s. The female had her arms wrapped around the child. Sgt. Gonzalez said the female 
and child were chest-to-chest facing each other. Sgt. Gonzalez stated the female appeared to be “in 
fear for her life” as she was crying. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he believed the female was in fear of her 
life because she was crying and she was sheltering the child from Tovar by wrapping her arms 
around the child. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he thought Tovar was going to stab either the female or the 
child with the knife because of the way Tovar was holding the knife and the way Tovar “target 
scanned” by looking at Sgt. Gonzalez and then returning his gaze toward the victims attempting 
to ascertain which target would be the easiest to stab. Sgt. Gonzalez estimated the knife was 
approximately three feet away from the female and her child.

Based on his training and experience, I asked Sgt. Gonzalez what possibilities existed with a 
suspect holding a knife three feet away from a potential victim. Sgt. Gonzalez responded, “A 
person could get stabbed. It takes less than a second.” Sgt. Gonzalez did not recall Tovar moving 
during the encounter. DAI Torres asked if the distance between Tovar and the female and child 
changed during the encounter and Sgt. Gonzalez stated, “No.” Sgt. Gonzalez stated after the first 
shot was fired, Tovar maintained the same position and the knife remained approximately three 
feet away from the female and child. Sgt. Gonzalez could not remember if Tovar moved toward 
the female and child after the first shot was fired.  
 
Sgt. Gonzalez had no additional information to provide but said, “It was just a very dramatic 
situation at the time.” When I asked Sgt. Gonzalez if he had previously encountered Tovar, he said 
he recognized Tovar’s name after reviewing the CAD (Computer Aided Dispatch) and he knew 
Tovar lived in the area. Sgt. Gonzalez said he knew Tovar, but he did not recognize Tovar during 
the encounter inside 404 Hyland Dr. Sgt. Gonzalez said Tovar had previously registered with him 
as part of Tovar’s 290 PC status.  
 
I had no additional questions for Sgt. Gonzalez and ended the interview at approximately 1045 
hours.

NARRATIVE: 
On 8/11/23 at approximately 1059 hours, Monterey County Sheriff Office (MCSO) Deputy 
Cristian Pantoja was interviewed regarding his involvement in the Officer Involved Shooting 
(OIS) that occurred on 08/08/23.  Also present during the interview was attorney Terry Leoni 
(Leoni Law Firm) representing Deputy Pantoja, and District Attorney Investigator (DAI) Kris 
Hunsaker.  The interview was audio recorded (Items TT 1 and TT 2) using my department issued 
cellular phone. Items TT 1 and TT 2 were later uploaded into digital evidence at the Monterey 
County District Attorney’s Office. 
 
Deputy Pantoja confirmed this interview was voluntary, and he was not ordered, coerced, or

Page 2 of 4 
compelled to provide a statement. Deputy Pantoja also had the opportunity to consult with his 
attorney prior to this interview.   
 
Deputy Pantoja was asked a series of questions regarding his assignment, equipment, training, and 
experience.  The following is a summary of his responses:   
 
Deputy Pantoja said he is employed with the Monterey County Sheriff’s Office and is a Deputy in 
training.  Deputy Pantoja has been in the field training program for approximately 2 ½ months.  
He has been employed with the Sheriff’s Office for 4 years and was a jail deputy prior to his 
current assignment.  Deputy Pantoja has attended the basic police academy and does not hold any 
auxiliary assignments.  Deputy Pantoja has not attended any specialized training other than the 
police academy.   
 
On the day of this interview, Deputy Pantoja was 29 years of age, and his current title is Deputy 
in training.  Deputy Pantoja is issued a Glock 17 Pistol that utilizes a 9 mm round.  Deputy Pantoja 
is also assigned a patrol rifle.  The rifle is a Colt rifle that fires a .223 round.  The pistol and rifle 
have an added department-issued flashlight attached to them.  The pistol has been issued to Deputy 
Pantoja for approximately 4 years.  The rifle has been issued to him for approximately 1 year.   
 
Deputy Pantoja does not carry a backup weapon.  Deputy Pantoja performs functions checks before 
every shift on both of his issued firearms.  Deputy Pantoja qualified with both firearms the week 
he started the field training program.   
 
On the day of the incident, Deputy Pantoja was wearing a class A uniform which consists of a shirt 
with Sheriff’s Office patches on both sleeves.  He was wearing green class A pants and a duty belt.  
Deputy Pantoja also had a badge on his left chest and a name plate on the right chest.  Deputy 
Pantoja carries two (2) pairs of handcuffs, radio, flashlight, collapsible baton, Glock 17 pistol, 
taser, OC spray and two (2) pistol magazines on his duty belt.   
 
On the day of the incident Deputy Pantoja was in a marked Sheriff’s Office patrol car.  The vehicle 
is equipped with emergency lights and siren.  The vehicle is not equipped with a camera.  Deputy 
Pantoja said the Monterey County Sheriff’s Office does not issue body worn cameras to deputies.     
 
Deputy Pantoja went on to recall the events of the day of the incident.  Deputy Pantoja said he was 
dispatched to a call that was a 911 hang up.  He was told by dispatch that a caller had said there 
was someone with a knife and then the call was disconnected.  Deputy Pantoja was finishing a 
traffic stop at the time he was contacted by dispatch.  After getting in his vehicle, a location was 
given on Hyland Drive.  Deputy Pantoja activated his emergency lights and siren and responded 
to the area.   
 
While driving to the location, additional information was being provided to Deputy Pantoja.  
Deputy Pantoja said he was told that a suspect was locked in a room armed with a knife, with a

female adult and a child.  Upon arriving, Deputy Pantoja said he saw Sgt. Gonzalez running 
towards the residence where the suspect was located.  Deputy Pantoja followed Sgt. Gonzalez into 
the residence.   
 
Deputy Pantoja said due to the severity of the information he was provided, he unholstered his 
firearm.  When he entered the residence, Deputy Pantoja saw a male adult in the living room of 
the house.  He ordered the adult to exit which he did.  Sgt. Gonzalez went down a hallway inside 
of the residence to a closed door.  Sgt. Gonzalez attempted to open the door, but it was locked.   
 
Sgt. Gonzalez told Deputy Pantoja to take a “breach position.”  Deputy Pantoja believed this meant 
they would kick the door open.  Sgt. Gonzalez kicked the door approximately two (2) times.  
Deputy Pantoja said he began to feel fear because it was unknown what was inside of the room.  
Deputy Pantoja said he knew someone had a knife and possible hostages inside of the room.  
Deputy Pantoja said the door appeared to be barricaded and it opened only slightly after being 
kicked.   
 
Deputy Pantoja said he looked inside of the room, and he could see a female adult who appeared 
to be holding a small child and was in distress.  The female was crying as was the child and they 
were on the bedroom floor.  Deputy Pantoja said the female adult appeared to be in fear for her 
life.  Deputy Pantoja said he was holding his firearm in a low ready position and was scanning the 
room.  Deputy Pantoja said he saw a Hispanic male adult holding what appeared to be a kitchen 
knife in his hand.  Deputy Pantoja said he was afraid because he did not know the suspect’s abilities 
with the knife.  Deputy Pantoja said he began to give the suspect commands such as “drop the 
knife.”   
 
Deputy Pantoja said he felt afraid for his life as well as the life of the female and child.  The suspect 
was in close proximity to the victims as well as the deputies.  Deputy Pantoja said that the suspect, 
later identified as Anthony Tovar, was not listening to any of the commands the deputies were 
giving him.  Deputy Pantoja yelled at Tovar and said, “look at me.”  Tovar looked at Deputy 
Pantoja and waived his hand in a motion that Deputy Pantoja took as “go away.”  Tovar was in a 
bladed stance and holding the knife out in front of himself.  Tovar then began to turn away from 
Deputy Pantoja and Sgt. Gonzalez towards both victims.  Deputy Pantoja said he heard 
approximately three (3) rounds go off from Sgt. Gonzalez’s pistol.  Tovar flinched and had a 
physical reaction to the shots.  Deputy Pantoja said he believed the shots had struck Tovar.   
 
Tovar then turned completely around with his back to the deputies.  He faced both the female and 
the child with the knife still in his hand.  The blade of the knife was pointed at both victims.  Deputy 
Pantoja said it was at this time he believed it was Tovar’s intention to kill both the woman and 
child.  Tovar took a step in the victims’ direction with the blade of the knife pointed directly at 
them.  Deputy Pantoja estimated Tovar was only a few feet away from the victims at this time.  
Deputy Pantoja fired a single shot at Tovar.  Tovar stopped and showed a flinch or physical

reaction to the single shot.  Tovar then collapsed with the knife still in his hand.  Tovar was on the 
floor motionless.  Deputies forced their way in the room and removed the knife from his hand.   
 
Deputies rendered basic first aid to Tovar.  Fire and AMR were also requested over the radio.  
Tovar was still breathing and had a pulse during this time.  Fire and AMR arrived and took over 
first aid efforts.  At this time Deputy Pantoja was relived from the scene.  The interview ended

SYNOPSIS: 
This report documents the contact and interview with Deputy Josue Ramirez regarding the Officer 
Involved Shooting that occurred on August 8, 2023.  Also present during the interview was 
Attorney Terry Leoni, representing Deputy Ramirez, and Monterey County District Attorney 
Investigator Justin Bell.

NARRATIVE: 
At approximately 1130 hours, I met with Monterey County Sheriff’s Office (MCSO) Deputy Josue 
Ramirez, Attorney Terry Leoni, and Monterey County District Attorney Investigator Justin Bell at 
the Monterey County District Attorney’s Office for an interview. The interview was audio 
recorded using my department issued digital recorder, and officially began at 1158 hours.  
 
It should be noted that due to a break during the interview, there are a total of two audio recordings 
for this interview.  The first interview will be labeled Interview Part 1, and the second, Interview 
Part 2.  
 
Deputy Ramirez stated that this interview was voluntary, and he was not ordered, coerced, or 
compelled to provide a statement.  He also had the opportunity to consult with his attorney prior 
to this interview.   
 
Deputy Ramirez was asked a series of questions regarding his assignment, equipment, training, 
and experience.  The following is a summary of his responses: 
 
Deputy Ramirez is currently assigned to the patrol division of the Monterey County Sheriff’s 
Office (MCSO), which was the capacity he was working at the time of the Officer Involved 
Shooting (OIS). Deputy Ramirez was also a breacher on the MCSO SWAT team, a drone operator, 
and a Field Training Officer (FTO). Deputy Ramirez has been a sworn deputy with MCSO since 
2015 (approximately 8 years).  He did not work for any other departments prior to MCSO. Deputy 
Ramirez’s badge/CAD number is R8475, and on the day of the OIS his call sign was 1Z3.  Deputy 
Ramirez is 31 years old.   
 
Deputy Ramirez has training in the police academy, CPR training, less lethal force options training 
and arrest and control techniques training. He has not yet attended CIT training for Crisis 
Intervention or Critical Incidents.

On the day of the OIS, Deputy Ramirez was carrying the following firearm: 
• Glock 17, 9mm – Primary Duty Weapon 
This firearm is department-issued.  Deputy Ramirez has had this firearm for over 5 years.  
The only modifications were a mounted flashlight and grip additions.  He last qualified 
with this weapon in March of 2023, which was also the last time he did a function check. 
The magazine was loaded to capacity (17 rounds) plus one in the chamber.   
 
Deputy Ramirez did not fire his weapon during this incident.   
 
At the time of his response to the scene, Deputy Ramirez was dressed in his patrol uniform which 
consisted of a tan shirt, green BDU uniform pants, a tan outer carrier bearing a badge, name plate, 
MCSO patches on both sleeves and a patch on the back of the carrier which read “Sheriff.” Also 
on the carrier were a flashlight, pepper spray, taser, baton, handcuffs, magazines, and an admin 
pocket with pens and a notepad. Deputy Ramirez wore a duty belt with only his firearm which was 
in a drop-down holster attached to his leg.  He also wore tactical boots.   
 
On the day of the OIS, Deputy Ramirez’s assigned vehicle was patrol unit 3089.  Deputy Ramirez 
was working in an FTO capacity the evening of the shooting, and he shared this vehicle with his 
trainee, Deputy Pantoja, who conducted an inspection on the vehicle prior to the start of the shift.  
Deputy Ramirez believed all the equipment in the vehicle was functioning. The vehicle was 
equipped with a less lethal shotgun.  Deputy Ramirez said the vehicle usually has a WRAP, which 
is a device used to restrain combative individuals. He did not know if the WRAP was in the trunk 
that evening since he did not inspect the vehicle. The vehicle was not equipped with any cameras.   
 
Deputy Ramirez was then asked to explain in his own words the circumstances surrounding this 
OIS.  The following is a summary of his statement:

Deputy Ramirez and Deputy Pantoja were on patrol and had just cleared a traffic stop in the city 
of Salinas at Boronda Road and North Main St.  Dispatch advised of a 911 hangup call where a 
reporting party (RP) reported a man was inside of his residence with a knife.  While enroute to the 
scene, dispatch updated something regarding a mother and a child; however, due to the chaos he, 
could not recall any more details.   
 
Deputy Pantoja was driving, and they headed towards the residence with lights and sirens 
activated.  Deputy Ramirez was the passenger and was talking to Deputy Pantoja making sure they 
knew where they were going and the fastest route to take.   
 
Deputy Ramirez heard Sergeant David Gonzalez advise he had arrived on scene just a few seconds 
before he and Deputy Pantoja arrived.  Deputy Ramirez saw Sergeant Gonzalez speaking with a 
male outside in front of the house.  As they were exiting the vehicle, they saw Sergeant Gonzalez 
run into the home.  Deputy Pantoja immediately ran after Sergeant Gonzalez.  Deputy Ramirez 
immediately followed Deputy Pantoja.  As he entered the home, Deputy Ramirez could see 
Sergeant Gonzalez at the right side of a door in a hallway just past the kitchen.  Deputy Pantoja 
met and stood to the left of that same door.  Sergeant Gonzalez began to kick in the door as Deputy 
Ramirez arrived and stood directly behind Deputy Pantoja.  He said the room was at the northeast 
corner of the home.   
 
As the door was kicked open, they noticed it was obstructed by an object, and they could not enter.  
Deputy Ramirez could not see inside, but he knew Deputy Pantoja and Sergeant Gonzalez were 
challenging someone as they shouted, “Drop the knife.”  As this was going on, Deputy Ramirez 
was able to see into the opposite side of the room where a mother and a child were on the floor. 
He described them as being terrified, trembling, and hugging each other.   
 
Deputy Ramirez said commands continued towards the suspect to drop the knife.  Deputy Ramirez 
said he also made commands to drop the knife even though he could not see the suspect.  Deputy 
 
MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEY’S OFFICE  
BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION 
Case #: MCDA 
23-0005 
Supplement #: 
DAI RPT.007 
 
By: D.A. Inv. Maldonado 
Page 5 of 8 
Ramirez then heard a firearm discharge followed by more commands to drop the knife.  Deputy 
Ramirez heard a firearm discharge again, and then they entered the room.  As they entered, Deputy 
Ramirez could see the suspect on the floor.  He also saw the knife. 
 
Deputy Ramirez went directly to the mother and child, got them up and escorted them out of the 
room.  Deputy Ramirez returned to the room, handcuffed the suspect, turned him over and began 
to render medical aid (refer to the audio recording for details on Deputy Ramirez’s efforts to treat 
the suspect).  AMR and fire personnel arrived a short time later and took over medical treatment 
of the suspect.   
 
Deputy Ramirez recalled that the officers present during the shooting were Sergeant Gonzalez, 
Deputy Pantoja, Deputy Perez and himself.  
 
I followed up with questions for Deputy Ramirez regarding his mindset during this incident. After 
hearing initial radio traffic, Deputy Ramirez was in fear for the mother and child.  He said he has 
two daughters himself, so this was terrifying.   
 
Deputy Ramirez said he had no prior knowledge of the suspect, and he did not know who the 
suspect was.  Deputy Ramirez said he had no interactions with the suspect prior to the shooting, 
and the only time he saw him was after deputies entered the room.  Prior to the shooting, Deputy 
Ramirez did not hear or see the suspect.  
 
Deputy Ramirez did not recall if any description of the suspect was broadcasted prior to his arrival.  
Deputy Ramirez’s mindset upon arrival was that he needed to be with his sergeant and Deputy 
Pantoja.  He said he did not know if Sergeant Gonzalez heard or saw something, but since he ran 
into the house by himself, Deputy Pantoja and Deputy Ramirez immediately followed him so they 
could go in together.   
 
 
MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEY’S OFFICE  
BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION

23-0005

By: D.A. Inv. Maldonado 
Page 6 of 8 
Deputy Ramirez said there was no plan formulated during this incident, and everything happened 
so quickly that he could only react to the other officers’ actions. Deputy Ramirez did not hear 
communication during the call amongst officers, but he was the last to walk up.  As he walked up, 
he put his hand on the shoulder of Deputy Pantoja in preparation for room entry and to alert Deputy 
Pantoja that Deputy Ramirez was behind him.  This was for tactical purposes as he was trained 
during SWAT.  Deputy Ramirez said that had they been able to enter the room at that point, he 
would have remained with Deputy Pantoja and provided him direction while dealing with the 
situation.  Due to the circumstances, Deputy Ramirez was not able to do this.  
 
Upon arrival at the scene, Deputy Ramirez recalled Sergeant Gonzalez talking to a male he 
believed to be the reporting party.  The male appeared to be in a state of panic. Deputy Ramirez 
did not hear their exchange.   
 
Deputy Ramirez did not recall anyone on scene verbally identify themselves as law enforcement.  
He said the command of “drop the knife” was given several times.  He said it was more than two. 
He could not recall any background noise that would obstruct the suspect’s ability to hear 
commands.   
 
Deputy Ramirez described the layout of the residence as a living room that feeds into the kitchen.  
The kitchen leads to a hallway where the door to the room is located.  This was where the four 
officers were positioned as they challenged the suspect.  From where he was standing in the 
hallway, Deputy Ramirez estimated he was 10 feet from the mother and child in the room.  
 
Deputy Ramirez said he did not discharge his weapon.  Sergeant Gonzalez and Deputy Pantoja 
discharged their weapons.  
 
I asked Deputy Ramirez what he thought the suspect was trying to do.  He mentioned there were 
many unknowns regarding the suspect and he was worried he would violently hurt the mother and 
 
MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEY’S OFFICE  
BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION 
Case #: MCDA 
23-0005 
Supplement #: 
DAI RPT.007 
 
By: D.A. Inv. Maldonado 
Page 7 of 8 
the little girl. He was thinking the worst based on the fact he believed the suspect was a random 
person in the home, and he was worried of a violent sexual assault.  
 
DAI Bell asked Deputy Ramirez if any information he received gave him the sense of the type of 
call this was, specifically to know whether this was a stranger or a domestic violence situation.  
Deputy Ramirez responded that he could not discern what type of call it was, nor could he know 
if there were issues with the RP. In his mind, Deputy Ramirez understood this to be a hostage 
situation based on the information he was given.  
 
Deputy Ramirez said that there were no other force options available to deal with the situation.  He 
said that everything happened very quickly and the deputies that shot had to instantly react to what 
was in front of them.  From the time they entered the home until the time of the shots, Deputy 
Ramirez estimated it was less than a minute. In his mind, when he saw the door was intentionally 
blocked by the suspect, he believed the suspect was trying to prevent anyone from entering the 
room.    
 
DAI Bell asked Deputy Ramirez about the potential danger of a person with a knife, based on his 
training and experience.  He said a knife can cause severe damage or life-threatening injuries.  It 
could take seconds for a person with a knife to severely injure someone.  In this situation, there 
was not enough time to run to a vehicle to get a less lethal option.  When they arrived, the 
immediate instinct was to be with Sergeant Gonzalez, so he was not by himself, and Deputy 
Ramirez needed to remain with Deputy Pantoja.  
 
Deputy Ramirez said that upon opening the door, it opened about a foot.  With the layout of the 
hallway and the amount of space available, they would not have been able to deploy a taser or 
other less lethal options.  Deputy Ramirez did not have a good angle or view to deploy one of these 
options.

SYNOPSIS: 
 This report summarizes the interview of witness Deputy Jason Perez. 
 
SUMMARY: 
 
On 8/11/2023 at approximately 1305 hours, Investigator Maldonado and I interviewed 
witness Deputy Jason Perez at the Monterey County District Attorney’s Office in Salinas. The 
interview was regarding the deputy involved shooting that occurred on 8/11/2023 in the city of 
Salinas. Deputy Perez was represented by his attorney, Terry Leoni from Full Service Labor & 
Employment Law Firm. I audio recorded the interview and uploaded the interview to 
evidence.com as JB-1. 
 
Deputy Perez confirmed he was present to provide a voluntary statement, and that he had 
been able to consult with his attorney prior the interview. Deputy Perez provided the following 
information about his assignment, training, equipment and uniform:

Deputy Perez told me the following in summary: 
 
Deputy Perez is normally assigned to coastal patrol, but they were short staffed in Salinas 
and he volunteered to be reassigned. Deputy Perez was with Deputy Ramirez and Deputy Pantoja 
at a traffic stop at Boronda Rd. and North Main Street. At approximately 2132, hours he received 
a dispatch call from Monterey County Communications that a male was reporting that a subject 
was in his house with a knife locked in a room. He said the details were vague at that time. 
 
Deputy Perez responded to 404 Hyland Drive with lights and sirens (code 3) behind Deputy 
Ramirez and Deputy Pantoja. He received updates that the reporting party (RP) was asking them 
to hurry, and said that the subject was in the house with his wife with a knife.  
 
Deputy Perez heard Sgt. Gonzales attach himself to the call. They received an update that 
there was a man with a knife locked in a room with the caller’s wife and child. Sgt. Gonzales 
arrived and updated over the radio that he was being flagged down by a male.  
 
Deputy Perez arrived on scene shortly after. Deputy Perez saw Deputy Pantoja and Deputy 
Ramirez running towards the front of the house. Deputy Perez started running after them then 
paused for a second and thought that he should get the less lethal shotgun out of his trunk. Deputy 
Perez saw Sgt. Gonzales “basically leap into the house” and he felt that Sgt. Gonzales had more 
information because he had arrived first and had spoken to the RP already. Based on Sgt. Gonzales’ 
actions and the information he had already received, Deputy Perez felt that the circumstances were 
so exigent that there was not time to go back and get the less lethal shotgun. Deputy Perez ran 
towards the house.  
 
Deputy Perez said based on the information he had received from dispatch told him that 
they needed to get into the house quickly. He felt that the subjects were in danger, and he felt that 
there was just no time. Based on the information he had, he felt that the suspect’s intention was to 
harm the woman and child or the responding deputies.  
 
When Deputy Perez got to the front door of the residence, he, the RP, and another male 
were standing just outside the house and he told them to get farther away. When he was inside, he 
could hear kicking “bang bang” and the voice of Sgt. Gonzales yelling “open the door, open the 
door” When Deputy Perez got to the hallway, he could see Sgt. Gonzales to the right and Deputy 
 
MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEY’S OFFICE  
BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION 
Case #: MCDA 
23-0005 
Supplement #: 
DAI RPT.008 
 
By: D.A. Inv. J. Bell 
Page 5 of 6 
Pantoja a little bit to the left. Deputy Perez was right behind Deputy Ramirez. He could see that 
the door was open 1.5 to 2 feet and appeared to be barricaded by a dresser with a mirror attached 
to it. He could see the deputies trying to push it but it would not move. At that time all he could 
see through the opening in the door was the dresser blocking the doorway and the back wall of the 
room. Deputy Perez could not see the mother and child or the suspect in the room. He then heard 
“drop the knife, drop the knife” before hearing a bang, and then another bang. He said there was 
about 5 seconds between the first bang and the second bang. 
 
I asked if there was anything going on at the time of the commands to drop the knife that 
would have prevented someone from hearing the deputies. He said there was not. I asked if he 
heard any announcements that it was the police or sheriff’s department, and he said, “no.”  
 
When Deputy Perez saw that the door was barricaded, Deputy Perez thought that meant 
that the victims were in danger. That meant that the suspect was not going to come out, and was 
going to harm the child or the mother, because he had barricaded himself in with them.  
 
Deputy Perez turned around and saw the RP behind him and had to tell him to get back 
outside. 
 
Deputy Perez had to help get the door open because it was still barricaded. He saw the 
suspect on the ground wounded and the mother and child huddled over in a fetal position crying 
with the mother bear hugging the child. They ended up breaking the door basically in half and 
climbed over the dresser to get inside the bedroom. Deputy Perez pulled the mother and child out 
of the room and checked them to make sure they were okay. A little later AMR Ambulance arrived. 
Deputy Perez put the mother and child into his patrol car, and put the husband into another patrol 
car.  
 
Deputy Perez was told to remain with Deputy Pantoja and they did not discuss anything 
about the incident.  
 
I asked, based on his training and experience, what threat someone with a knife posed. He 
said a knife could easily kill or seriously injure the victims. 
 
I asked if Deputy Perez had the less lethal shotgun upon his arrival into the house, if it 
could have changed the way the situation was handled. Deputy Perez said he did not think so. 
 
MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEY’S OFFICE  
BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION 
Case #: MCDA 
23-0005 
Supplement #: 
DAI RPT.008 
 
By: D.A. Inv. J. Bell 
Page 6 of 6 
Firstly, the less lethal shotgun has a standoff distance. Based on the fact that it was such a small 
room he would not have been able to deploy it safely. Additionally, if the less lethal shotgun was 
not effective, the suspect could have been angered and then taken out his aggression on the victims 
while they were barricaded in the room. He said that door was so effectively barricaded that it took 
the deputies substantial time and effort to get the door open even after the suspect was down. 
 
Deputy Perez also described that he could not see the suspect from his position in the 
hallway, and that he would have needed to get around and in front of the other deputies before he 
would have an opportunity to use it, and in doing so he would have removed their ability to deploy 
lethal force and have lethal cover.  
 
Deputy Perez said he did not hear any sound from inside the room prior to the shooting, 
and could not see the suspect. He did not hear any words from the suspect. He did not have any 
prior knowledge of the suspect or the residence they had entered.  
 
Deputy Perez thought that maybe 1 or 2 minutes passed between his arrival on scene and 
the shooting. He said the whole scene was so dynamic and fast, everything happened in a split-
second decision.  
 
Deputy Perez never fired his weapon. Deputy Perez said he did not render medical aid to 
the suspect because he was responsible for the victim and her child. 
 
Deputy Perez said he did not think they had any other force options based on how quickly 
the events transpired. They did not even get a chance to think about using OC or other options. He 
said OC also would not have been a good option because everyone would have been effected by 
it in such a confined space, and they would have lost control over the whole situation. 
 
He felt that if they had tried a taser, people are aware of how to defeat the taser. He felt if 
they had tried to tase the suspect and it failed, he would have been angered into action to harm the 
victim and her child. Deputy Perez said the suspect had the advantage over them the entire time. 
Based on what Deputy Perez saw once in the room, he understood the suspect was a lunge away 
from the victims and it would have taken less than a second for him to harm them.

SUMMARY:  
At the time of this investigation, I was employed as a Monterey County District Attorney’s Office 
(MCDA) Investigator (DAI). On Friday, August 11th, 2023, I was assigned to attend the autopsy 
of decedent Anthony Tovar at the Santa Cruz County Sheriff’s Office (SCSO) Coroner Autopsy 
Suite. The autopsy was conducted by Chief Forensic Pathologist Dr. Stephany Fiore, it began 
around 0900 hours and concluded at around 1500 hours. SCSO Criminalist Karyn Crawford, and 
Autopsy Technicians Michelle Novak and Isabella Rotti were assisting. Monterey County District 
Attorney Investigative Aide (DAIA) Tanya Nava and DAIA Vanessa Valle were in attendance. 
Nava, Valle, and I witnessed the autopsy from a viewing room adjoined to the autopsy suite. We 
viewed the autopsy suite directly through a glass partition and electronically via closed circuit 
television monitoring. The rooms were equipped with two-way communication via an intercom 
system. 
 
I observed the decedent in a white body bag labeled as “Anthony Tovar” and sealed with bag lock 
#85571. I witnessed Criminalist Crawford taking photographs to document the postmortem 
examination. I witnessed Criminalist Crawford and Technician Novak collect the following items 
of evidence during the autopsy:

At the conclusion of the autopsy, Dr. Fiore stated that the cause of death was two (2) gunshot 
wounds. One (1) projectile struck the left lung, the heart, and the right lung. The other projectile 
struck the T-5 vertebrae and the right lung. The death occurred “within minutes” of the injuries. 
 
On 08/18/23 I met with SCSO Evidence Clerk Emily Caterson at the SCSO Evidence Room 
located on Chanticleer Ave. in Santa Cruz and received the above listed items of evidence (CQ01-
CQ17). I transported the items to the MCDA evidence room in Salinas where I logged each item 
and placed them into intake for processing. 
 
No further information.

On 8-08-23, at approximately 2130 HRS, deputies were dispatched to-Hyland Dr, 
Salinas. The RP, 
stated there was a male subject insTcle'his residence. 
The male was in a bedroom, with 
The male was armed with 
a knife. 
At approximately 2135 HRS, SGT D GONZALEZ, FTO RAMIREZ, Deputy C PANTOJA, 
and Deputy J PEREZ arrived on scene. 
At approximately 2136 HRS, radio traffic advising "shots fired" was put out. 
Deputy SOTO and I responded from the area of Highway 1 and Merritt St, Castroville. 
We responded with emergency lights and siren. 
VVhile en route to the incident, I assumed the role of Patrol Supervisor, as the only on 
duty supervisor was involved in the incident. 
I contacted Commander N DAVIS, via cellular telephone, advised of the deputies 
involved in a shooting, and stated more information would be provided as soon as I 
arrived on scene. 
At approximately 2147 HRS, upon arrival on scene, I advised Deputy SOTO to start a 
crime scene log and establish the entry/exit point at the intersection of El Rancho Way 
and Hyland Dr, Salinas. 
I then contacted SGT GONZALEZ, who was standing out in front of the residence. 
I confirmed SGT GONZALEZ had no injuries and obtained a Public Safety Statement. 
SGT GONZALEZ stated he fired 1 round from his department-issued Glock 17M. When 
the suspect did not react to this, he fired 2, or possibly 3, more rounds from his handgun. 
SGT GONZALEZ stated there were no outstanding subjects, no other persons were 
injured, and the incident occurred in the bedroom, located to the rear of the residence.

I then entered the residence, where I found Salinas Fire personnel, as well as AMR 
Medical personnel, providing medical treatment to the male subject. 
I checked on FTO RAMIREZ and Deputy C PANTOJA. Both advised they had no 
injuries. 
FTO RAMIREZ stated he did not engage the subject, as Deputy PANTOJA and SGT 
GONZALEZ were positioned in front of him at the time of the incident. 
I then spoke with Deputy PANTOJA. 
I obtained a Public Safety Statement from Deputy PANTOJA. 
Deputy PANTOJA stated he fired 1 round from his department-issued Glock 17M. 
Deputy PANTOJA stated there were no outstanding subjects, no other persons were 
injured, and the incident occurred in the bedroom. 
After speaking with SGT GONZALEZ and Deputy PANTOJA, it was apparent there was 
no longer any threat to the residents, deputies, or the general public. The incident was 
contained to the bedroom, inside the residence. There were no outstanding suspects, 
and all involved parties were accounted for. 
Several minutes later, FTO MEILAN and Deputy M BROWN arrived on scene. 
I had them relieve FTO RAMIREZ and stand by in the bedroom for scene security. 
Deputy PANTOJA was then placed in a marked patrol vehicle with Deputy J PEREZ, 
who stated he was not involved in the incident. 
SGT GONZALEZ was placed in a marked patrol vehicle with Deputy ROMERO. 
FTO RAMIREZ was placed in a marked patrol vehicle with Deputy MORAN.

I advised the involved deputies to contact their family/significant others to tell them they 
were involved in a critical incident and that they were safe. They were advised to not talk 
to anyone about the incident, whether it was family, or other law enforcement officers. 
SGT GONZALEZ, FTO RAMIREZ and Deputy PANTOJA were then taken to the Central 
Patrol Station, Salinas. 
The mother and child had already been removed from the residence and were secured 
in a patrol vehicle. 
A short time later, Commander N DAVIS and Commander J SMITH arrived on the 
scene. 
Both were briefed and provided with as much information as possible. 
At the lime, the identity of the subject was unknown. He did look familiar, but I could not 
recall his name at the time. I did recall him being contacted while investigating a sexual 
assault at a residence across the street, down an alleyway. I could not recall the address 
but did recall contacting him while assisting with that case. 
This information was later passed on to investigators. 
None of the involved deputies were able to identify the male. 
Monterey County District Attorney's Office Investigators arrived on the scene, as well as 
detectives from the Monterey County Sheriff's Office. 
Scene security was maintained by Monterey County Sheriff's Office deputies, as well as 
Salinas Police Officers. 
The investigation was taken over by the Monterey County District Attorney's Office 
Investigators. 
Nothing further from this deputy at this lime. 
Case continued with Monterey County District Attorney's Office.

On 8-8-2023, at approximately 2136 hours, Deputy M. Brown and I responded to­
Hyland Drive in Salinas. Deputies had previously responded to the address, at about 
2130 hours, to a report of a male inside of a residence with a knife. At about 2136 hours, 
deputies on scene broadcast "shots fired". We then responded code 3 with our 
emergency lights and sirens from the area of Moss Landing on Highway 1. 
We arrived at the scene at about 2147 hours, and I saw crime scene tape had been 
placed on Hyland Drive at El Rancho Way. Deputy A Soto was maintaining the crime 
scene log and I checked in with him and then entered the scene. I entered the 
residence and moved to the back bedroom where numerous Fire Personnel from Engine 
#2 and AMR Medical Personnel from unit 48 were rendering medical aid to a male who 
was lying on the ground in the back bedroom of the residence. The subject was 
declared deceased a short time later. 
Fire and AMR personnel left the scene a short time later and Deputy Brown and I 
relieved Deputy J. Ramirez who was maintaining scene security In the bedroom. We 
then remained as scene security until relieved by Monterey County District Attorney's 
Office investigators. 
Nothing further from this Deputy. 
Case continues with the Monterey County District Attorney's Office.

On 8/8/2023, at about 2130 hours, deputies were dispatched to ■Hyland Or., Salinas 
on the report of an unknown male suspect, with a knife, inside the residence. FTO J. 
Meilan and I began to drive toward the residence. 
At about 2136 hours, deputies advised, via radio, shots were fired, and the suspect was 
shot. 
FTO Meilan and I responded with our emergency overhead lights and sirens activated 
from Highway 1 and Molera Rd. 
Upon arrival, at about 2147 hours, we were met on scene with multiple outside agencies 
to include, Salinas Police Department (SPD), Salinas Fire Department (SFD), and 
American Medical Response (AMR). The Sheriff Deputies already on scene were 
Sergeant D. Gonzalez, FTO J. Ramirez, FTO E. Schumacher, Deputy C. Pantoja, and Deputy 
A. Soto. 
I exited my patrol vehicle and I saw Sheriff's Office crime scene tape blocked off at the 
intersection of Hyland Dr., and El Rancho Wy. I entered the secured area and entered the 
residence. 
Once I was inside the residence, I saw SFD and AMR personnel treating a victim in a rear 
bedroom. At 2202 hours, SFD announced the time of death which was approved by Dr. 
_,f Natividad Medical Center (NMC). 
A short time later, I contacted - and he advised he was assigned to Medic 
Engine #2. I also contacted AMR-and he advised he was assigned to unit #48. All 
AMR and SFD personnel left the scene. 
I then took multiple digital images of the crime scene. The images were of the outside of 
the residence, inside the living room, kitchen, bedrooms, the back bedroom where the 
shooting occurred, of the decedent, and a knife. I later uploaded the digital images to 
the Monterey County Sheriff's Office Image Swap database. 
I then remained in the residence, just outside of the bedroom, with the decedent and 
the knife lying near his body to keep the scene secure. I was later relieved from the 
crime scene by Monterey County Sheriff's Detectives and Monterey County District 
Attorney's Office Investigators. 
Nothing further from this deputy.

HOPKIN SOP 
On 8/8/23, at about 2200 hours, I received a phone call from Det. Sgt. Kennedy. He 
asked me to respond to-yland Dr. in Salinas to assist with an investigation of a 
shooting. 
I arrived on scene and was informed that the Monterey County District Attorney's Office 
would be handling the investigation of the incident. I was told that they would be utilizing 
the services of the Sheriff's Office Forensic Evidence Technicians to document the 
scene and collect evidence. 
I was asked to remain on scene and assist 
s she processed the crime 
scene. 
During the investigation, a key fob with a Mercedes logo was found in the victim's 
pockets. I offered to walk the neighborhood in search of a Mercedes associated to the 
keys. 
I walked through the alley across the street from-yland Dr. with DAI Captain 
Ferreria. We located a 2001 black Mercedes (CA License Plate 7DAX938) parked in the 
alley. 
I returned to the scene and collected the key. I returned to the vehicle and the key 
unlocked the vehicle. On the front passenger seat, Cap. Ferreria found several pieces 
of mail with the name Anthony Tovar on them. 
I contacted the Monterey County Records Department and asked them to conduct a 
record check on Anthony Tovar with the approximate age range of twenty-five to thirty 
years old. They advised that they located an Anthony Tovar (7/22/98). I asked them to 
send a photo of Tovar. They emailed me a photo of Tovar and I forwarded the photo to 
Capt. Ferreria to assist with identification. 
I then remained on scene until the scene was released to the homeowner. 
Case continues.

BUTLER, CHAD - 34264
Watch Commanders Insight
OFFICER BUTLER, CHAD  Serial No. 34264  
  
WATCH COMMANDER'S INSIGHT:  
I, Lieutenant Nick Giordano, Serial No. 37933, Watch Commander, Foothill Patrol, have reviewed this Level I Non-Categorical Use 
of Force (NCUOF) as well as the related reports, BWV, and photographs.  
  
This NCUOF occurred when officers responded to a radio call for a domestic violence restraining order violation. Officer Butler and 
his partner responded to assist the primary unit and canvassed the area.  While they canvassed the area, they observed a possible 
suspect vehicle. Officers exited their vehicle to further investigate when the suspect suddenly exited the vehicle. The suspect 
refused to cooperate or follow commands, attempted to assault an officer and a use of force occurred.  
  
USE OF FORCE:  
The UOF occurred on a sidewalk where officers attempted to detain the suspect for a restraining order violation. The suspect did 
not comply and attempted to strike one of the officers. The use of force by Officer Butler; firm grip, physical force, punches, elbow 
strike, and bodyweight to the suspect, was objectively reasonable, and at the lowest level to reduce injury to the officers and the 
suspect.  
  
Firm Grips: I find that the application of this force was objectively reasonable and proportional given the suspect¿s continued 
efforts to resist commands and prevent arrest. Additionally, de-escalation efforts by the primary unit; ordering the suspect to stop 
resisting and comply were ineffective. I believe the continued use of this low-level force was appropriate given the type of physical 
resistance enacted by the suspect.   
  
I recommend these applications of force be classified as: IN POLICY / ADMINISTRATIVE APPROVAL.  
  
Bodyweight: I find this application of force was objectively reasonable and proportional to the suspects actions and continued 
resistance.   
  
I recommend this application of force be classified as: IN POLICY / ADMINISTRATIVE APPROVAL.  
  
Physical Force: I find this application of force was objectively reasonable and proportional given the suspects active resistance and 
failure to comply with commands.  
  
I recommend this application of force be classified as: IN POLICY / ADMINISTRATIVE APPROVAL.  
  
Punch: One punch was thrown by Butler; in response to the suspect attempt to get to his feet.  This punch was also in response to 
the actions by the suspect and his attempt to strike officers with a set of keys.  Given the proximity of all involved and the need to 
protect himself, I find the punch appropriate and proportional to the suspect¿s actions.   
  
Sergeant Gonzalez discussed the use of the punches with Officer Butler, in reference to Use of Force Directive No. 2, Strikes and 
Kicks.  The discussion addressed the avoidance of intentional punches to the head to prevent injury to the officers hand.  Officer 
Butler was receptive to the discussion and I determined that no further action is required.  
  
I recommend that this application of force be classified as: IN POLICY / ADMINISTRATIVE APPROVAL.  
  
Elbow Strikes: Two elbow strikes were thrown by Butler; in response to the suspects continued resistance. These strikes were also 
in response to the actions by the suspect and his attempt to strike officers with a set of keys.  Given the proximity of all involved 
and the need to protect himself, I find the elbow strikes appropriate and proportional to the suspect¿s actions.   
  
I recommend that this application of force be classified as: IN POLICY / ADMINISTRATIVE APPROVAL.  
   
TACTICS:  
During a canvass of the area, Officer Butler and his partner located the suspects vehicle. As officer Butler and his partner exited 
their vehicle, the suspect suddenly exited the vehicle.  
  
Officer Butler immediately broadcast their updated location and advised units that they were Code 6 on the suspect. Officer Green 
later updated it to a backup request.

During the initial portion of the contact (prior to the UOF) Officer Butler was the designated cover of
ficer while Officer Green was the contact officer.  
  
Overall, the tactics Officer Butler used prior, during, and after the UOF were objectively reasonable, necessary, appropriate, and 
did not substantially deviate from Department procedures.   
  
During the NCUOF, Officer Butler made momentary contact with the suspect's neck. In addition to the unintentional neck contact, 
the suspect sustained 
. FID Lt. Jordan #30895 was contacted and stated that the case did not rise to the level of a 
categorical UOF. Therefore, the case was to be investigated as a Level I NCUOF.  
  
POLICY / OTHER ISSUES:  
  
Officer Butler did not activate the Digital In-Car Video (DICV) prior to the contact with the suspect.   
  
Officer Butler's BWV was activated during the UOF and captured the entirety of the incident.  
  
Officer Butler utilized profanity during the UOF incident to gain compliance from the suspect.  
  
The minor deviation from DICV was addressed with a Supervisor Action Item (SAI). Officer Butler was reminded about Special 
Order No. 45 (October 2009), Digital In-Car Video Use and Deployment. The use of profanity by Officer Butler was not directed at 
the suspect in a derogatory manner and only utilized when the suspect failed to comply with commands. Upon conclusion of the 
UOF, Officer Butler maintained his professionalism. I believe that Sergeant Gonzalez adequately addressed the profanity during 
her investigation and no further action is necessary.  
  
I recommend that the tactics utilized by Officer Butler be classified as ADMINISTRATIVE APPROVAL / INCIDENT DEBRIEF.  
  
SUPERVISOR OVERSIGHT:    
Sergeant I Erika Gonzalez, Serial No. 41925, responded to the scene of the UOF and assumed responsibility as the Investigating 
Supervisor.  Sergeant Gonzalez completed separate and independent interviews of all the involved parties.  She canvassed for 
evidence and completed a thorough at scene investigation.  At the conclusion of the incident, Sergeant Gonzalez conducted an 
Incident Debrief to reinforce the positive aspects of the incident and discuss areas of improvement. I determined that Sergeant 
Gonzalez on-scene investigation was thorough and complete.

Finding Review Comments:
I, Lieutenant Ljubetic, Acting Foothill Patrol Commanding Officer, reviewed this investigation, 
including related reports, Body-Worn Video, and Watch Commander Insight, completed by 
Lieutenant Giordano. A review of Officer Butler¿s work history report revealed no area of 
concern.  
  
Officers Butler and Green, responded as an additional unit to a radio call of, Domestic violence 
Restraining Order Violation.  
  
As officers canvassed the area, they observed the suspect vehicle parked. Officers exited their 
vehicle to further investigate and observed the suspect exit his vehicle. The suspect was given 
commands to which he ignored. Officers approached the suspect and a Use of Force occurred 
as the suspect turned to face officers while armed with a pair keys and attempted to assault 
Officer Green.  
  
Officer Butler utilized a combination of Firm Grips, Punch, Elbow Strikes, Physical Force, and 
Bodyweight to stop the suspect¿s violent and aggressive behavior.   
  
The suspect¿s actions posed an immediate threat to the safety of officers, which ultimately 
resulted in the use of punches and elbow strikes.  In review of BWV, Use of Force Directive 
No. 2, Strikes and Kicks and Use of Force policy, I found it reasonable to use punches and 
elbow strikes in response to the suspect¿s violent actions.  
  
In evaluating this NCUOF, I determined the force used by Officer Butler was objectively 
reasonable, necessary, proportional, and within Department Policy and State Law. Officers 
properly used de-escalation techniques to reduce the intensity of the incident and used the 
minimal amount of force necessary. There was no evidence or allegation of biased policing, 
nor did I observe any requirement for another employee to intercede. Officers rendered aid by 
ensuring that the suspect was immediately placed in the recovery position and later received 
proper medical attention by requesting an RA for visible injuries the suspect sustained during 
the Use of Force.  
  
Regarding tactics, I/O Sergeant Gonzalez identified issues, which he covered during an 
incident debrief with Officer Butler.

Watch Commanders Insight
OFFICER GREEN, AARON  Serial No. 36890  
  
WATCH COMMANDER'S INSIGHT:  
I, Lieutenant Nick Giordano, Serial No. 37933, Watch Commander, Foothill Patrol, have reviewed this Level I Non-Categorical Use 
of Force (NCUOF) as well as the related reports, BWV, and photographs.  
  
This NCUOF occurred when officers responded to a radio call for a domestic violence restraining order violation. Officer Green and 
his partner canvassed the area and observed a possible suspect vehicle. Officers exited their vehicle to further investigate when 
the suspect exited the vehicle. The suspect refused to cooperate or follow commands, attempted to assault an officer and a use of 
force occurred.  
  
USE OF FORCE:  
The UOF occurred on a sidewalk where officers attempted to detain the suspect for a restraining order violation. The suspect did 
not comply and attempted to strike one of the officers. The use of force by Officer Green; firm grip and bodyweight to the suspect, 
was objectively reasonable, and at the lowest level to reduce injury to the officers and the suspect.  
  
Firm Grips: I find that the application of this force was objectively reasonable and proportional given the suspects continued efforts 
to resist commands and prevent arrest. Additionally, de-escalation efforts by the primary unit; ordering the suspect to stop resisting 
were ineffective. I believe the continued use of this low-level force was appropriate given the type of physical resistance enacted by 
the suspect.   
  
I recommend this application of force be classified as: IN POLICY / ADMINISTRATIVE APPROVAL.  
  
Bodyweight: I find this application of force was objectively reasonable and proportional to the suspects actions and continued 
resistance. Officer Green maintained control of the suspects legs to prevent him from standing up.   
  
I recommend this application of force be classified as: IN POLICY / ADMINISTRATIVE APPROVAL.  
  
TACTICS:  
During a canvass of the area, Officer Butler and his partner located the suspect¿s vehicle. As officer Butler and his partner exited 
their vehicle, the suspect suddenly exited the vehicle.  
  
Officer Butler immediately broadcast their updated location and advised units that they were Code 6 on the suspect. Officer Green 
later updated it to a backup request.  
  
Officer Green attempted to de-escalate the situation through verbalization with the suspect prior to the UOF.  
  
During the initial portion of the contact (prior to the UOF) Officer Butler was the designated cover officer while Officer Green was 
the contact officer.  
  
Overall, the tactics Officer Green used prior, during, and after the UOF were objectively reasonable, necessary, appropriate, and 
did not substantially deviate from Department procedures.   
  
During the NCUOF, Officer Butler made momentary contact with the suspect's neck. In addition to the unintentional neck contact, 
the suspect sustained 
. FID Lt. Jordan #30895 was contacted and stated that the case did not rise to the level of a 
categorical UOF. Therefore, the case was to be investigated as a Level I NCUOF.  
  
POLICY / OTHER ISSUES:  
  
Officer Green did not activate the Digital In-Car Video (DICV) prior to the contact with the suspect.  
   
Officer Green's BWV was activated during the UOF and captured the entirety of the incident.  
  
The deviation from DICV was adequately addressed with a Supervisor Action Item (SAI).  Officer Green was reminded about 
Special Order No. 45, (October 2009), Digital In-Car Video Use and Deployment.

Officer Green utilized a combination of Firm Grips, and Bodyweight to stop the suspect¿s 
violent and aggressive behavior.   
  
In evaluating this NCUOF, I determined the force used by Officer Green was objectively 
reasonable, necessary, proportional, and within Department Policy and State Law. Officers 
properly used de-escalation techniques to reduce the intensity of the incident and used the 
minimal amount of force necessary. There was no evidence or allegation of biased policing, 
nor did I observe any requirement for another employee to intercede. Officers rendered aid by 
ensuring that the suspect was immediately placed in the recovery position and later received 
proper medical attention by requesting an RA for visible injuries the suspect sustained during 
the Use of Force.  
  
The tactics used by Officer Green before, during and after the use of force was reasonable and 
appropriate and did not deviate from Department procedures.

Watch Commanders Insight
OFFICER CORDOBA, AMANDA  Serial No. 44817  
  
WATCH COMMANDER'S INSIGHT:  
I, Lieutenant Nick Giordano, Serial No. 37933, Watch Commander, Foothill Patrol, have reviewed this Level I Non-Categorical Use 
of Force (NCUOF) as well as the related reports, BWV, and photographs.  
  
This NCUOF occurred when officers responded to a radio call for a domestic violence restraining order violation. Officer Cordoba 
and her partner responded to a backup request by officers who were Code 6 on a restraining order violation suspect. Officer 
Cordoba observed officers involved in a UOF with the suspect and responded to assist. The suspect refused to cooperate or follow 
commands and attempted to assault officers during the incident.  
  
USE OF FORCE:  
The UOF occurred on a sidewalk where officers attempted to detain the suspect for a restraining order violation. The suspect did 
not comply and attempted to strike one of the officers. Officer Cordoba's force applications were not excessive and were 
proportionate to gain control of the suspect who continued to resist.  
  
Firm Grips: I find that the application of this force was objectively reasonable and proportional given the suspect¿s continued 
resistance and efforts to prevent arrest. Additionally, de-escalation efforts by the primary unit; ordering the suspect to stop resisting 
were ineffective. I believe the continued use of this low-level force was appropriate given the type of physical resistance enacted by 
the suspect.   
  
I recommend this application of force be classified as: IN POLICY / ADMINISTRATIVE APPROVAL.  
  
During the NCUOF, Officer Butler made momentary contact with the suspect's neck. In addition to the unintentional neck contact, 
the suspect sustained 
 FID Lt. Jordan #30895 was contacted and stated that the case did not rise to the level of a 
categorical UOF. Therefore, the case was to be investigated as a Level I NCUOF.  
  
  
TACTICS:  
  
Officer Cordoba responded to the backup and immediately attempted to de-escalate the situation through verbalization during the 
UOF.  
  
Overall, the tactics Officer Cordoba used prior, during, and after the UOF were objectively reasonable, necessary, appropriate, and 
did not substantially deviate from Department procedures.   
  
POLICY / OTHER ISSUES:  
  
Officer Cordoba BWV was activated during the UOF and captured the entirety of the incident.  
  
I recommend that the tactics utilized by Officer Cordoba be classified as ADMINISTRATIVE APPROVAL / NO ACTION.  
  
SUPERVISOR OVERSIGHT:    
Sergeant I Erika Gonzalez, Serial No. 41925, responded to the scene of the UOF and assumed responsibility as the Investigating 
Supervisor.  Sergeant Gonzalez completed separate and independent interviews of all the involved parties.  She canvassed for 
evidence and completed a thorough at scene investigation.  At the conclusion of the incident, Sergeant Gonzalez conducted an 
Incident Debrief to reinforce the positive aspects of the incident and discuss areas of improvement. I determined that Sergeant 
Gonzalez on-scene investigation was thorough and complete.
