Finding Review Comments:
I, Lieutenant Ljubetic, Acting Foothill Patrol Commanding Officer, reviewed this investigation, 
including related reports, Body-Worn Video, Digital In-Car Video and Watch Commander 
Insight, completed by Lieutenant Giordano. A review of Officer Cordoba¿s work history report 
revealed no area of concern.  
  
Officer Cordoba responded as a backing unit to Officer Butler and Officer Green.  
  
Officers Green and Butler were checking the area for a suspect of a Domestic Violence 
Restraining Order Violation. As officers canvassed the area, they observed the suspect vehicle 
parked. Officers exited their vehicle to further investigate and observed the suspect exit his 
vehicle. The suspect was given commands to which he ignored. Officers approached the 
suspect and a Use of Force occurred as the suspect turned to face officers while armed with a 
pair keys and attempted to assault Officer Green.  
  
Officer Cordoba utilized Firm Grips to subdue the suspect.  
  
In evaluating this NCUOF, I determined the force used by Officer Cordoba was objectively 
reasonable, necessary, proportional, and within Department Policy and State Law. Officers 
properly used de-escalation techniques to reduce the intensity of the incident and used the 
minimal amount of force necessary. There was no evidence or allegation of biased policing, 
nor did I observe any requirement for another employee to intercede. Officers rendered aid by 
ensuring that the suspect was immediately placed in the recovery position and later received 
proper medical attention by requesting an RA for visible injuries the suspect sustained during 
the Use of Force.  
  
The tactics used by Officer Cordoba before, during and after the use of force was reasonable 
and appropriate and did not deviate from Department procedures.

MEMORANDUM 
To: 
Police Officer Shawn Virani 
From: 
Police Chief Don Aguilar 
Date: 
March 26, 2024 
Subject: Notice of Discipline- Written Reprimand 
This memo is presented to you pursuant to Skelly v. State Personnel 
Board (1975) 15 Cal. 3d 194, and Section 8.8 of the City of Santa Paula's ("City") 
Personnel Rules and Regulations ("Personnel Rules") as notice of my decision 
to discipline you in the form of a written reprimand in your position as a Police 
Officer with the City's Police Department ("Department"). Your written reprimand 
shall be effective upon receipt of this notice. 
I. 
RULES AND POLICIES UPON WHICH DISCIPLINE IS BASED 
This Notice of Discipline~Written Reprimand ("Notice") is based upon my 
determination that you have committed one or more of the following violations of 
the City's Personnel Rules and/or Department Policy. Please note that your 
commission of any one of the following violations, standing alone, would support 
a decision to discipline you. My decision to discipline you need not be based 
upon a finding or conclusion that you committed multiple rule violations and/or 
that you violated all of the rules/policies set forth below. 
A. 
CITY PERSONNEL RULES, SECTION 8.1, EMPLOYEE 
CONDUCT 
It shall be the duty of employees to maintain high standards of 
cooperation, efficiency, and integrity in their work with the City of Santa Paula 
("City") and in their life as it impacts their work as employees of the City. If an 
employee's conduct falls below standard, he/she may be subject to disciplinary 
action ... 
Some general acts for which an employee may be disciplined include, but 
are not limited to: 
Page 1 of 5 
"Committed to Community Service" 
4. 
Neglect of duty and/or failure to perform assigned work in an 
efficient or effective manner .... 
21. 
Incompetence. 
B. 
DEPARTMENT POLICY 319 STANDARDS OF CONDUCT 
319.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE 
Page 2 of 5 
This policy establishes standards of conduct that are 
consistent with the values and mission of the Santa Paula Police 
Department and are expected of all department members. The 
standards contained in this policy are not intended to be an 
exhaustive list of requirements and prohibitions but they do identify 
many of the important matters concerning conduct. In addition to 
the provisions of this policy, members are subject to all other 
provisions contained in this manual, as well as any additional 
guidance on conduct that may be disseminated by this department 
or a member's supervisors. 
319.2 POLICY 
The continued employment or appointment of every member 
of the Santa Paula Police Department shall be based on conduct 
that reasonably conforms to the guidelines set forth herein. Failure 
to meet the guidelines set forth in this policy, whether on- or off-
duty, may be cause for disciplinary action. 
319.5 CAUSES FOR DISCIPLINE 
The following are illustrative of causes for disciplinary action. 
This list is not intended to cover every possible type of misconduct 
and does not preclude the recommendation of disciplinary action 
for violation of other rules, standards, ethics and specific action or 
inaction that is detrimental to efficient department service: 
319.5.3 EFFICIENCY 
a) 
Neglect of duty. 
b) 
Unsatisfactory work performance including but not 
limited to failure, incompetence, inefficiency, or delay 
in performing and/or carrying out proper orders, work 
assignments, or the instructions of supervisors 
without a reasonable and bona fide excuse. 
"Committed to Community Setvice" 
319.5.6 PERFORMANCE 
i) 
Any act on or off duty that brings discredit to this 
department. 
319.5.9 CONDUCT 
m) 
Any other on or off duty conduct which any member 
knows or reasonably should know is unbecoming a 
member of this department, is contrary to good order, 
efficiency or morale, or tends to reflect unfavorably 
upon this department or its members. 
II. 
FACTUAL BASIS FOR DISCIPLINE 
On or about August 30, 2023, I received a letter from Chief Deputy District 
Attorney Kevin Drescher complaining about your alleged behavior and 
requesting an investigation: Specifically, DA Drescher alleged that you made 
false statements to the District Attorney's Office that you had obtained copies of 
a surveillance video, which was later purged, and that you falsely claimed that 
the camera angle of the video would not have captured any relevant information 
regarding the investigation of an alleged kidnapping and rape of a minor. 1 The 
Department conducted an internal investigation into the matter via an 
independent, third party investigator which forms the substantive basis for this 
discipline. 
Deputy District Attorney Emily Reber stated that on June 23, 2023, she 
monitored the victim's interview and discovered the area of the kidnapping crime, 
which was at the front of Ventura High School. DOA Reber then coordinated with 
you to retrieve the surveillance video from Ventura High School. Sometime after 
the victim interview, you told DDA Reber (via a phone call) that the camera 
system was down at the school, but you were going to continue your efforts to 
retrieve the video from the school. On June 29, 2023, you informed ODA Reber 
(via a text message) that the school camera system was working, and that 
co.pies were being made for him to pick up the following Wednesday. On July 7, 
2023, DOA Reber followed up with you again, and you texted her, "Morning, I'm 
off today, but I have video from the school saved and will be combing through it 
on Monday. As far as the motel thing, only what we have of Martinez." ODA 
Reber interpreted this text communication as you telling her that you possessed 
a copy of the school video. 
1 This second allegation that you falsely stated that the angle of the camera would not have 
provided any relevant information to the investigation was determined to be unfounded and does 
not form the basis for any discipline against you, 
Page 3 of 5 
"Committed to Community Service" 
ODA Reber spoke to you on July 13, 2023 to set up a meeting to discuss 
the kidnapping/rape case and the evidence that had been collected, but you said 
you were busy with a recent homicide, so you set a July 21, 2023 meeting date. 
DOA Reber believed she told you to bring the video from the high school to the 
meeting, along with other evidence. 
At the July 21, 2023 meeting, you and ODA Reber discus·sed the overall 
case and what needed to be done next. When DOA Reber asked about the high 
school video, you said that you were going to the high school to get it after the 
meeting as well as other surveillance video from Ralphs and McDonald's. When 
you asked ODA Reber about the exact date and time of the kidnapping so you 
could search the correct timeframe at the high school, ODA Reber was confused 
because she believed that you already had the video. 
Shortly thereafter, you texted DOA Reber that the video retention period 
was only 30 days, but you were checking with the school district's IT department 
to see if the video was still stored on their servers. You ultimately determined 
and told DOA Reber that the video was not retained by the school. DOA Reber 
then told you to provide a supplemental report explaining why you did not 
retrieve the high school surveillance video which you did. 
Ill. 
ANALYSIS 
In Skelly v. State Personnel Board, supra, 15 Cal. 3d at 218, the 
California Supreme Court held that in considering the level of penalty in public 
employee disciplinary cases: 
"the overriding consideration in these cases is the extent to which 
the employee's conduct resulted in, or if repeated, is likely to result 
in harm to the public service. Other relevant factors include the 
circumstances surrounding the misconduct and the likelihood of its 
recurrence." 
In this instance, you inexcusably failed to ensure that potentially important 
evidence to a very serious crime was preserved. While you claim that school 
officials told you that the video was available for "some time" after the relevant 
day, you never followed up to determine what specific period of time the school's 
system retained video. Further, you never timely ensured that the video was 
saved or retrieved within the 30-day window after the crime resulting in loss of 
the video. Luckily, as you later and accurately determined, the angle of the 
camera would not have provided any relevant information. However, your 
negligence could have resulted in the loss of critical evidence related to a 
serious crime. I do not believe that that there is sufficient evidence to support 
that you were intentionally dishonest in your communications with DOA Reber 
with respect to the status of the video. However, I recommend and direct that 
Page 4 of 5 
"Committed to Community Service" 
you be more accurate and precise in your communications in the future to avoid 
any similar miscommunications or embarrassment to the Department. 
Any similar instances of misconduct in the future will lead to additional 
disciplinary action, up to and including termination. 
IV. 
POST-DISCPLINARY APPEAL PROCEEDINGS 
You have the right to an appeal of this discipline under Government Code 
section 3304(b), Department Policy, and/or Section 8.8 of the City Personnel 
Rules. If you choose to appeal this discipline, you must send me a Notice of 
Appeal within ten (10) days of receipt of this notice. 
Further, a copy of this Notice of Discipline~Written Reprimand, which may 
be considered adverse to your interest, will be placed in your personnel file. 
Government Code section 3306 provides you thirty (30) days to provide a written 
response to this memorandum, which will be attached to this document in your 
personnel file. 
V. 
WARNING AGAINST RETALIATION 
This provision is to notify you that it is illegal and inappropriate to retaliate 
against any person who has participated in complaining or providing information 
regarding allegations of your misconduct. You may not retaliate against any 
individual who has provided information to the City regarding your misconduct. 
VI. 
ACKNOWLEDGMENT 
I have read and understand this Notice of Discipline~Written Reprimand 
and I acknowledge receipt of this document. I understand th . 
cop of this 
document will be placed in my general personnel file.

On August 14, 2023, at approximately 1523 hours, I interviewed

I was working on June 22, 2023, and I remember SDPD officers coming to the hospital with a 
patient. The police escorted the patient into the emergency room. Initially on their arrival we 
asked if the patient was under arrest and they said, “no”. We asked them a few times and they 
were consistently saying, “no”. The officer told me that the patient did not want to be transported 
by ambulance due to the cost. So, they offered to basically give him a ride to the hospital. That 
seemed unusual to me and I had never seen that in my experience. And I thought it was interesting 
that they decided to stay with him. From my experience when the police are with a patient it is 
because they are under arrest or on a 5150 hold.  
 
Then the officers were talking to the patient and it seemed like things were getting a little more 
heated. The patient got a little defensive and it seemed like maybe I hadn’t received the whole 
story. So, I was just kind of keeping an eye on them because it seemed different from my previous 
experience.  
 
At one point the doctor came in and had to ask the officers to leave multiple times during the 
treatment. They were hovering and it was making a lot of the staff uncomfortable. There was 
something about … I don’t know if it was stolen property or not, but it seemed like they were 
trying to get a confession out of the patient or something like that. And the patient was getting a 
little more aggressive and he was saying he wanted to leave. And the police were saying that if he 
did, they were going to place him on a 5150 for grave disability. The doctor had told them at that 
time, that he would discontinue the hold immediately if they decided to do that.  
 
 
At the end of the visit, I don’t know if the patient ended up being arrested. It was very unclear if 
the patient was under arrest. Because like I said at the very beginning, they were very clear that 
he was not under arrest then they began talking about placing him on a hold. At one point, now I 
am certain of it, they did tell him he was under arrest. I don’t think he was ever in handcuffs, and 
to my knowledge they never read him his rights or anything like that. And I can’t remember if they 
left with him or not.  
 
I remember it taking a long time for the whole treatment process and the officers were getting 
impatient. They were very frequently asking myself, the nurse, or the doctor if the patient was 
going to receive a CT or X-Rays of his head. They were asking why he hadn’t received treatment 
so far, and they were a little bit inappropriate in their line of questioning. It was inappropriate 
because it wasn’t an innocent question like, “Is he going to receive this kind of treatment?” It was

 at Scripps

I was working the night in question, and I briefly and vaguely remember the officer that brought in 
that patient. He wasn’t my patient, but I do remember having a few interactions with the officer. I 
do remember him coming in through the ambulance bay which is where SDPD typically brings in 
patience on 5150s or whatever the case maybe. I don’t know if the officer just didn’t know the 
protocol or how to check in a patient, but he immediately came to the nurse’s station desk and he 
began demanding a room for the gentleman he had brought with him. This was in the Alpha Pod, 
and I remember the patient being handcuffed, but it was awhile back so I couldn’t say for sure. I 
don’t recall the nurses who were at the station with me at the time the officer brought in the 
patient. But I do remember him being handcuffed.  
 
So, I remember him coming in and making demands to get him and his patient a room. He didn’t 
give us any information about why he was there or if he was on a 5150. Without any information 
he just began demanding a room from us. We educated him on the proper protocol which is to 
pick up the phone in Alpha pod and to call our charge nurse and to go over the reasons of why he 
is bringing in a patient. And then the charge nurse will come over and assign a room if there is 
one available at the time. And I remember a little bit of resistance from him and he was pushing 
back asking why we couldn’t put the patient straight into a room and at that point the charge 
nurse came over and began handling it so I just stepped back and let them do their thing.  
 
I don’t recall any demands he made regarding the specific medical treatment of the patient. I was 
unsure at the time whether the patient was on a 5150 or under arrest. I later found out that he was 
not on a 5150 or under arrest and that is when a lot of us started questioning why this officer is 
here. We thought it was very unusual and we were very confused especially because the officer 
was hovering around the patient for most of his visit.  
 
It was awhile back, but the officer’s demeanor, I don’t want to say it was hyperaggressive, but it 
was definitely more assertive then necessary. It didn’t feel like he was asking for help or telling us 
what was going on, it was more like, “I am here. This is what I need. I need it now.” That was 
what was communicated through his words and his body language. As far was what he 
specifically said I definitely would not be able to recall that.  
 
I would describe his behavior as argumentative. When we told him how to check in the patient, he 
was not initially compliant with our instructions. All I can say is that he seemed to be a little more 
understanding once the charge nurse showed up to explain the process to him herself.

SDPD Department Procedure 4.01, IV, C: Stop/Detention and Pat Down Procedure, revised August 
27, 2021, states in part:  
 
C. Detention 
 
A detention, also referred to as a “stop”, occurs when officers use their authority to compel a person to 
halt, to remain in a certain place, or to perform some act, such as walking to a nearby location. Courts 
have used the terminology “investigative stop” for a detention. A detention is allowed so an officer may 
have a reasonable amount of time to investigate a person’s possible involvement in actual or perceived 
criminal activity, allowing the officer to make an informed decision whether to arrest, or to release, the 
subject. If the persons have been told they are not free to leave the officer’s presence, a detention has 
occurred. When conducting a detention, the officer shall notify the subject contacted that he or she is no 
longer free to leave. However, officers are not required to make such a notification if it would hamper an 
investigation or jeopardize the officer’s safety 
 
1. If an officer reasonably suspects that a person has committed, is committing, or is about to 
commit any crime, the authority to detain that person exists. Courts have used the terminology 
“Criminal activity is afoot” to describe these circumstances. The officer may exercise this 
authority in any place that the officer has the right to be. Both pedestrians and persons in 
vehicles may be detained. A detention is warranted if there is a reasonable suspicion by the 
officer that:  
 
a. Some activity relating to crime has taken place, is presently taking place, or is 
about to occur; and,  
 
b. The person to be stopped or detained is involved in that activity. 
 
4. Detention vs. Arrest  
 
a. If not handled properly, a “detention” could become an “arrest” which, if not   
supported by “probable cause” to arrest, would be illegal.  
 
b. General Rule: The least intrusive means should be used during a detention. 
 
c. The following list contains some factors that could cause a detention to turn into an 
arrest:  
 
(1) Numerous officers involved;  
 
(2) Display of weapons;

(3) Use of handcuffs;  
 
(4) Person is placed in back of a patrol car;  
 
(5) Encounter is in non-public setting;  
 
(6) The officer’s authoritative manner and actions imply that compliance    
      is compelled; and,  
 
(7) The officer did not advise the detainee of his right to terminate the    
      encounter.  
 
Note: The use of handcuffs or weapons or placing someone in a patrol car do 
not automatically make the contact an arrest if the actions are seen as 
reasonably necessary under the circumstances (person attempts to flee, officer 
safety concerns) and the person is told that they are only being detained, as 
opposed to arrested. 
 
5. Proper justification for a detention does not permit unreasonable conduct during the  
detention. All police activity during a detention shall be done in a reasonable manner. The 
courts, in determining whether the detention was reasonable and lawful, will consider every 
phase of a detention. 
 
a. Duration of the Detention  
 
A person stopped pursuant to this procedure may be detained for a reasonable amount 
of time under the circumstances. Officers should detain a person only for the length of 
time necessary to determine if the person should be arrested or released.  
 
b. Scope of the Detention  
 
A reasonable on-the-scene investigation is all that is authorized by law during a 
detention. Therefore, an officer shall not move a detainee unless:  
 
(1) The officer obtains the detainee’s consent to be moved;  
 
(2) The officer has probable cause to arrest the detainee;  
 
(3) A victim cannot, for valid reasons, be brought to the scene of the  
      detention;

(4) The movement is for a reasonable distance and facilitates the completion  
of the investigation (i.e., securing the detainee in a patrol car while completing an 
investigation); or,  
 
(5) The movement is for the safety of the officer or the detainee.  
 
c. Explanation to a Detained Person  
 
Officers shall act with as much restraint and courtesy towards the detained person as is 
possible under the circumstances. Plainclothes officers making a detention shall 
identify themselves as law enforcement officers as soon as it is appropriate. At some 
point during the detention, the officer should give the detainee an explanation of the 
purpose of the stop, unless such an explanation would jeopardize officer safety or 
hamper an investigation.  
 
f. Tactical Options  
 
Officers should strive to maintain a position of advantage (POA) and place the 
subject(s) contacted at a disadvantage whenever possible. Three techniques are: 
placing a subject on the curb, on the patrol vehicle’s push bumper, or in the back seat 
of a patrol vehicle. While officer safety is of primary concern, curb sitting was not 
designed to be a standard practice in all situations and officers recognize that 
community members find this tactic disrespectful.  
 
If a situation justifies having a subject sit on the curb, the subject should be removed 
from that position once the threat has been mitigated (i.e., additional officers arrive on 
scene). This technique is only appropriate under circumstances where officer safety is 
threatened.  
 
California Penal Code 240 reads:  
 
An assault is an unlawful attempt, coupled with a present ability, to commit a violent injury on the person 
of another. 
 
California Penal Code 245 reads in part:    
 
(a)(1) Any person who commits an assault upon the person of another with a deadly weapon or  
instrument other than a firearm shall be punished by imprisonment in the state prison for 
two, three, or four years, or in a county jail for not exceeding one year, or by a fine not 
exceeding ten thousand dollars ($10,000), or by both the fine and imprisonment.

California Penal Code 594 reads in part:  
 
(a) Every person who maliciously commits any of the following acts with respect to any real or  
personal property not his or her own, in cases other than those specified by state law, is guilty of 
vandalism: 
 
(1) Defaces with graffiti or other inscribed material. 
(2) Damages. 
(3) Destroys. 
Whenever a person violates this subdivision with respect to real property, vehicles, signs, fixtures, 
furnishings, or property belonging to any public entity, as defined by Section 811.2 of the Government 
Code, or the federal government, it shall be a permissive inference that the person neither owned the 
property nor had the permission of the owner to deface, damage, or destroy the property. 
 
(b)(2) (A) If the amount of defacement, damage, or destruction is less than four hundred dollars ($400),  
vandalism is punishable by imprisonment in a county jail not exceeding one year, or by a fine 
of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000), or by both that fine and imprisonment. 
 
California Welfare and Institutions Code 5150 states in part:  
 
(a) When a person, as a result of a mental health disorder, is a danger to others, or to themselves, or 
gravely disabled, a peace officer, professional person in charge of a facility designated by the 
county for evaluation and treatment, member of the attending staff, as defined by regulation, of a 
facility designated by the county for evaluation and treatment, designated members of a mobile 
crisis team, or professional person designated by the county may, upon probable cause, take, or 
cause to be taken, the person into custody for a period of up to 72 hours for assessment, 
evaluation, and crisis intervention, or placement for evaluation and treatment in a facility 
designated by the county for evaluation and treatment and approved by the State Department of 
Health Care Services. The 72-hour period begins at the time when the person is first detained. At a 
minimum, assessment, as defined in Section 5150.4, and evaluation, as defined in subdivision (a) 
of Section 5008, shall be conducted and provided on an ongoing basis. Crisis intervention, as 
defined in subdivision (e) of Section 5008, may be provided concurrently with assessment, 
evaluation, or any other service. 
 
(b) When determining if a person should be taken into custody pursuant to subdivision (a), the  
individual making that determination shall apply the provisions of Section 5150.05 and shall not 
be limited to consideration of the danger of imminent harm.

Report # 23-006308 - Supplement - 1 Report
NARRATIVE
My department issued Axon body worn camera 
) was not initially activated during this 
incident, but it was activated when I noticed it had not been properly activated. The BWC footage 
partially captured the incident. The footage was later uploaded onto a secure server on Evidence.com.
On Wednesday, 05/03/23, I was working as a Deputy Sheriff wearing a full "Class D" utility uniform 
that clearly identified me as a Deputy Sheriff with the Alameda County Sheriff’s Office (ACSO), in my 
fully marked patrol vehicle (3398), assigned to patrol at the Eden Township Substation (ETS) in San 
Leandro.
About 0419 hours, ACSO Transit Deputies requested emergency cover for a suspicious person (S1) 
who had physically assaulted an operator of a Alameda County Transit Bus at the San Leandro BART 
Station located at 1401 San Leandro Boulevard in San Leandro.
Sergeant S. Light and Deputies M. Ella, P. Serrano, O. Sallam, and Z. Snider arrived to assist.
Upon my arrival, I saw Deputies Serrano and Ella attempting to place S1 into handcuffs. S1 was on a 
concrete divider, where the buses load and unload passengers directly in front of the BART station. S1
was on his left side and was thrashing his legs wildly and violently in an attempt to escape from the 
deputies.
I rushed to help and was able to place S1’s legs into a figure-four-leg-lock. S1 did not resist my efforts 
to place his legs into this control hold.
Deputies Serrano and Ella placed S1 into handcuffs and detained him on the northeast curb line of the 
concrete divider. S1 displayed obvious signs and symptoms of recent illicit drug use. S1 was sweating 
profusely, had a thick white coating on top of his tongue, and displayed wild and erratic behaviors. S1 
was non-compliant and would not comply or listen to any of the deputies’ commands.

Additional Transit deputies arrived and attempted to ascertain the welfare of S1. S1 began to thrash 
his body wildly and kick his legs towards deputies. S1 attempted to scoot away on his hands and feet, 
while handcuffed, and screamed, “Let me go! Fuck you!”
ALCO Fire and a Falck ambulance later arrived to medically evaluate the victim of the assault and S1.
Sergeant Light arrived on scene, and I asked him to bring the WRAP to help control S1’s erratic and 
combative behavior.
The WRAP is a safety restraint device used to prevent the subject from injuring himself and others.
Multiple deputies attempted to control S1’s active resistance and his combative behavior. I gave S1 
multiple commands to stop resisting and to relax. S1 did not comply and continued to kick at deputies 
and thrash his body. Multiple deputies attempted to control S1’s upper body/torso. Deputies continued 
to give S1 commands to stop fighting and to stop resisting, but S1 did not comply.
I assisted Sergeant Light and the other involved deputies in placing S1 into the WRAP. During this 
attempt to place him into the WRAP, S1 continued to thrash his body, swung his head side to side 
wildly, and kicked his legs towards us. I used my knees and placed them on the back of S1’s calves to 
add pain compliance. S1 continued to thrash and fight my weight, which was on top of his calves.
Deputy Serrano and Salam rolled S1 over, so he was sitting upright to finish the placement of the 
WRAP. I remained in control of S1’s legs.
I told Deputy Snider to place a Chicago Spit Mask on S1’s head to prevent him from spitting at 
deputies. Deputy Snider placed the spit mask on his head but did not maintain control over S1’s head. 
Simultaneously, S1 kicked his legs upwards, which knocked me off balance, and I fell forward towards 
S1’s face. I stopped myself from falling forward and retained my balance. S1 saw that my face was 
exposed, and I saw him draw his head backwards and then he forcefully head butted me on the right 
side of my face. This caused immediate pain on my right temple and behind my right eye. At the time 
of this incident, I did not have any substantial swelling or bruising.
It should be noted, Sergeant Light and all of the other involved deputies witnessed S1 purposely head 
butt me on the right side of my face.
Once I was struck in my face, Sergeant Light removed me from the incident to ensure I sustained a 
severe headache and pain behind my right eye.

KNOW YOUR RIGHTS UNDER THE SUNSHINE ORDINANCE 
Government's duty is to serve the public, reaching its decisions in full view of the public. Commissions, boards, councils, and other agencies 
of the City and County exist to conduct the people's business. This ordinance assures that deliberations are conducted before the people and 
that City operations are open to the people's review. For information on your rights under the Sunshine Ordinance (Chapters 67 of the San 
Francisco Administrative Code) or to report a violation of the ordinance, please contact: Sunshine Ordinance Task Force Administrator in 
Room 244 at City Hall, 1 Dr. Carlton B. Goodlett Place, San Francisco, CA 94102-4683. (Office) 415-554-7724; (Fax) 415-554-7854; E-mail: 
SOTF@sfgov.org. Copies of the Sunshine Ordinance can be obtained from the Clerk of the Sunshine Task Force, the San Francisco Public 
Library and on the City's website at www.sfgov.org. Copies of explanatory documents are available to the public online at 
http://www.sfbos.org/sunshine or, upon request to the Commission Secretary, at the above address or phone number. 
LANGUAGE ACCESS 
Per the Language Access Ordinance (Chapter 91 of the San Francisco Administrative Code), Chinese, Spanish and or Filipino (Tagalog) 
interpreters will be available upon requests. Meeting Minutes may be translated, if requested, after they have been adopted by the 
Commission. Assistance in additional languages may be honored whenever possible. To request assistance with these services please contact 
the Police Commission at (v) 415.837.7070 at least 48 hours in advance of the hearing.  Late requests will be honored if possible. 
DISABILITY ACCESS 
Police Commission hearings are held in Room 400 at City Hall, 1 Dr. Carlton B. Goodlett Place in San Francisco. City Hall is accessible to persons 
using wheelchairs and other assistive mobility devices.  
Ramps are available at the Grove, Van Ness and McAllister entrances. The closest accessible BART station is Civic Center Station. For 
information about SFMTA service, please call 311. This meeting will be broadcast and captioned on SFGovTV. 
Assistive listening devices, real time captioning, American Sign Language interpreters, readers, large print agendas or other accommodations 
are available upon request. Please make your requests for accommodations to the Police Commission at (v) 415.837.7070. Requesting sign 
language accommodations at least 4 business days prior to the meeting will help to ensure availability. Allowing a minimum of 48 business 
hours for all other accommodation requests (for example, for other auxiliary aids and services) helps ensure availability. To request 
accommodation, please contact [SFPD Commission Officer, sfpd.commission@sfgov.org, 415-837-7070].  
Remote public participation is available upon request for individuals who cannot attend in person due to disability. Making a request to 
participate remotely no later than one (1) hour prior to the start of the meeting helps ensure availability of the meeting link. 
LOBBYIST ORDINANCE 
Individuals and entities that influence or attempt to influence local legislative or administrative action may be required by the San Francisco 
Lobbyist Ordinance [SF Campaign & Governmental Conduct Code 2.100] to register and report lobbying activity. For more information about 
the Lobbyist Ordinance, please contact the San Francisco Ethics Commission at 25 Van Ness Avenue, Suite 220, San Francisco, CA 94102; 
(Office) 415.252.3100; (Fax) 415.252.3112; Website: sfgov.org/ethics.

Chain of Custody:
On Thursday, July 20, 2023, I worked as a detective for the Alameda County Sheriff’s Office. I was 
assigned to the Eden Township Substation Crimes Against Persons Unit, and part of my daily duties 
included the investigation of officer involved shootings that occurred in unincorporated Alameda 
County.
About 1100 hours, Detective Lieutenant S. Mc Millian, Detective M. Campi, and I met with Department 
of Justice (DOJ) Special Agent R. Knippschild in the front parking lot of the Eden Township 
Substation. Lieutenant Mc Millian, Detective Campi, and I escorted Special Agent Knippschild to the 
Great Room of ETS where he provided me with Deputy A. Perez-Rojas’ departmental issued firearm, 
magazines, and ammunition. The firearm, magazines, and ammunition remained inside their original 
evidence packaging. I signed each package to document the chain of custody. Special Agent 
Knippschild also provided me with a DOJ property receipt for the mentioned items. I signed the 
property receipt and was given a carbon copy of the form.
Once I received and signed for the items, I took photographs of the packaged evidence and DOJ 
property receipt form. I packaged the form and transported all the items to Alameda County Sheriff’s 
Office Evidence building, located at 2020 150  Avenue in San Leandro, where it was processed.

One (1) black Sig Sauer P226 9mm semi-automatic pistol (SN: 
)
One (1) black Streamlight TLR-1 HL weapon mounted light fixed to the rail of the firearm
One (1) black 20 9mm round magazine inserted into the magazine well of the firearm
Two (2) black 15 9mm round magazines
Unknown amount of Speer 9mm unexpended ammunition. Because the ammunition was packaged, I 
did not perform another round count. Additionally, I was aware DOJ planned on using the ammunition

Conclusion:  
 
The following factors were considered regarding Officer Duran’s allegation of exceeding 
lawful peace officer powers by unlawfully entering the residence and detaining 
: 
● Officer Duran admitted that she did not hear or see any sounds of distress from 
occupants inside the apartment or the immediate area that would warrant exigent 
circumstances to enter the residence. 
● Officer Duran admitted entering the house without a warrant or consent from 
.  
● Officer Duran’s justification of entering the house to check on 
’s well-being 
was insufficient to justify the exigent entry and circumvent the Fourth Amendment 
of the US Constitution. Additional information and circumstances would be needed 
to establish that 
 was in distress, such as crying, calling for help, or 
information that 
 and the children inside were the possible victims of lewd 
or lascivious crimes. 
● Officer Duran did not obtain enough information to establish enough facts and 
probable cause to justify an exigent entry into the apartment to check the well-
being of 
. Subsequently, placing 
 into handcuffs was not warranted 
based on 
’s refusal to consent to a search of her residence.  
● Officer Duran did not direct officers to gain additional facts to establish a 
compelling argument that a person or persons inside the apartment were in 
distress and were in danger of life or well-being.  
Based on the information gathered, it is my recommendation of the allegation that Officer 
Duran violated DEPARTMENT POLICY 340.3.5(u):  Exceeding lawful peace officer 
powers by unreasonable, unlawful, or excessive conduct be sustained. 
The following factors were considered regarding Officer Duran’s allegation of 
unsatisfactory work performance: 
● Officer Duran did not conduct a proper investigation to establish a compelling 
argument that she needed to go inside the apartment. She did not review the court 
order to establish enough facts and probable cause to justify an exigent entry into 
the apartment to check the well-being of 
. Subsequently, placing 
 
into handcuffs was not warranted based on 
’s refusal to consent to a search 
of 
residence.  
● Once 
 walked out of the house and was detained, Officer Duran should have 
involved a sergeant immediately.  
● Officer Duran admitted that she should have slowed everything down once the 
restrained person/suspect, 
, was detained outside the home.  
● Officer Duran admitted it was her responsibility to confirm the restraining order and 
the conditions before responding to the call for service. She did not verify the 
restraining order and conditions this time because Officer Vazquez told her 
 
was in violation.  
● It is an officer's responsibility to confirm a restraining order and its conditions before 
enforcing the order.

13 
 
● 
 Additional due diligence should have been directed, such as: 
o Have officers verify the conditions of the court order and verify the conditions 
of the order.  
o Have officers contact other neighbors to establish if they had heard or seen 
signs of subjects in distress. 
o Have officers use other methods, such as calling 
 and trying to obtain 
’s phone number to call 
and check on 
 before making entry. 
Based on the information gathered, it is my recommendation the allegation that Officer 
Duran violated DEPARTMENT POLICY 340.3.5 (c):  Unsatisfactory work performance 
including, but not limited to, failure, incompetence, inefficiency, or delay in performing 
and/or carrying out proper orders, work assignments, or instructions of supervisors 
without a reasonable and bona fide excuse be sustained.

) driving eastbound on Palomar Airport Road from 
Melrose Drive in Carlsbad. I was driving southbound on South Rancho Santa Fe Road and located a

responded to the area. Once additional units were in place, I attempted to initiate a high-risk traffic stop 
at the 800 block of W San Marcos Boulevard. The driver of the F150, later identified as Brent Ebert 
pulled into the parking lot of the shopping center on the south side of W San Marcos Boulevard.  Ebert 
failed to yield and sped out of the parking lot, driving over the curb and barely missing Corporal Buckley's 
(4063) patrol vehicle which was blocking the driveway to the parking lot. Ebert headed north on S Bent 
Ave and turned eastbound onto W San Marcos Boulevard. Ebert entered the eastbound State Route 78 
and exited at Twin Oaks Valley Road where he failed to stop for the red light and headed southbound on 
Twin Oaks Valley Road.  At Craven Drive, Ebert veered into the northbound lanes of South Twin Oaks 
Valley Road and continued southbound until turning eastbound onto Village Drive. We terminated the 
pursuit, turning off our overhead lights, following the vehicle at a safe distance.  Ebert was observed 
turning eastbound onto Wandering Way, southbound onto Savona Lane, eastbound onto Garland 
Avenue and finally northbound onto Custer Avenue. The vehicle pursuit lasted approximately 2.1 miles 
and approximately 3 minutes. Throughout the pursuit, Ebert drove at high rates of speed, up to 82 miles 
per hour on the freeway and 60 miles per hour on surface streets. Ebert made numerous unsafe lane 
changes and drove on the wrong side of a divided roadway. 
 
At the dead end of Custer Avenue, Ebert exited the vehicle and fled on foot. Since Ebert did not place 
the vehicle's transmission into park, it rolled back into the lead patrol vehicle. The patrol vehicle suffered 
minor damage to the front end. Traffic Deputy, Corporal Guerrero (0817) investigated the collision (see 
Case #23177566 for details). 
 
Deputy Druda (0639) began a foot pursuit and followed Ebert who climbed the fence on the side of the 
house located 877 Custer Avenue. Deputy Druda went through the gate and as he attempted to 
apprehend Ebert, a use of force ensued (see Deputy Druda's officer report). Corporal Maldonado came 
to assist Deputy Druda and was also involved in the use of force (see Corporal Maldonado's officer 
report). Deputy Haggerty (4097) and Deputy Manibusan (0640) assisted detaining Ebert (see Deputy 
Haggerty's officer report and Deputy Manibusan's officer report). During the use of force, Deputy Druda 
suffered redness and swelling to his left knee. Deputy Maldanado sustained redness and bruising to his 
right knee. Deputy Manibusan sustained scratches, redness, and minor bruising to his right forearm and 
wrist. Ebert suffered a laceration above his left eye, a fracture to his left cheek bone, an abrasion to his 
nose and two cuts to his right wrist. 
 
 
San Marcos Fire Department Engine #141 and RA #141 responded to the scene and transported Ebert 
to Palomar Medical Center for evaluation. 
 
Deputy Druda contacted the register owner of the stolen vehicle and released the vehicle to the owner at 
the scene. Deputy Druda contacted Stolen Vehicle System and removed the vehicle as stolen. A records 
check indicated the vehicle was stolen out of the city of San Diego on 06/17/2023. California Highway 
Patrol took the initial stolen vehicle report 
 Deputy Salazar photographed the 
recovered vehicle and of Deputy Druda and Deputy Manibusan.

MINOR INJURY (F), 496 D (A) - PC - POSS STOLEN VEH/VESSEL (F), 12500 (A) - VC - DRVG 
WITHOUT VALID DRVR'S LIC (M), 2800.2 (A) - VC - EVADE PEACE OFCR WITH WANTON 
DISREGARD FOR SAFETY (F), 2800.4 - VC - EVADING A PEACE OFFICER:WRONG WAY DRIVER 
(F), and 12022.1 - PC - COMMIT FEL ON BAIL OR O/R RELEASE (BAIL+). 
 
Ebert was transported to Vista Detention Facility (VDF) for booking. 
 
Body worn cameras documented the incident. 
 
Evidence:   
 
1. CD of digital photographs 
 
Injuries:   
 
Deputy Druda suffered redness and swelling of his left knee. 
Deputy Maldanado sustained redness and bruising to his right knee. 
Deputy Manibusan sustained scratches, redness, and minor bruising to his right forearm and wrist.  
Ebert suffered a laceration above his left eye, a fracture to his left cheek bone, an abrasion to his nose 
and two cuts to his right wrist. 
 
Property Damage:   
 
Minor front end damage to patrol vehicle (#20357).  
 
 
Follow-up:   
 
None.  
 
 
Related Reports:  
  
CHP-187A Pursuit Report 
Deputy Druda's officer report #141166 
Corporal Maldonado's officer report #141164 
Corporal Guerrero's accident report SDSO case #23127566

The suspect continued to flee despite my commands and proceeded to jump over the closed gate that led into the backyard. I 
observed the suspect fall headfirst over the five-to-six-foot tall gate and briefly lost observation of him for about two to three 
seconds. Based off my training and experience, fleeing felons and vehicle thieves are known to carry firearms or deadly 
weapons, and will use physical force against law enforcement to avoid being arrested. I caught up to the wooden gate and 
pushed it open and regained visual observation of the suspect. I observed the suspect roll onto his back and use his feet to 
kick me to prevent me from gaining control of him. I used my bodyweight to prevent him from continuing to kick at me and felt 
him grab onto my gear near the right side of my waist where my firearm was holstered. I continued to yell "Get on the fucking 
ground" as he pulled on me and attempted to stand up. He continued to grip onto my gear and pull me closer to his body. 
 
To prevent the suspect from gaining control of me or any of my issued gear, to include a deadly weapon, I used a closed fist 
with my right hand and punched the suspect in the face four to five times until I felt him release his hand from my gear. I 
attempted to gain control of the suspect's left arm with my hands to roll him onto his stomach and place him in handcuffs. The 
suspect continued resist by interlocking his left hand to his right arm above his head. He asked, "Why are you fucking 
punching me man" and I stated, "Because you're grabbing my fucking waist." He continued to grip onto his right arm with his 
left hand and I used my left hand and punched him in the arm one time, which caused him to release his right arm and 
allowed me to gain complete control of his left arm. 
 
Additional Deputies arrived to assist, and we were able to place him in handcuffs without further incident. The suspect was 
immediately rolled into the recovery position and escorted to the street to be evaluated by paramedics. He was identified as 
Brent Ebert 
) by a Deputy on scene. Ebert has an extensive criminal history to include the following charges: 
 
.  
 
Force was necessary to prevent Ebert from escape; self-defense; and to prevent him from possibly running into an occupied 
residence or backyard which could have resulted in injury to innocent bystanders. Due to the time of day and warm summer 
weather, there was a likelihood that the residence had an open backdoor or window, which Ebert could have entered through. 
The force used was effective and ultimately resulted in safely detaining him in handcuffs and preventing further injury to 
Deputies or bystanders.  
 
During the physical altercation, I sustained a scuff with redness on my left knee, a scratch on my right elbow, and pain to my 
right hand. Medical treatment was not necessary for my injuries. Ebert had apparent bleeding from his face, which was 
unknown to have resulted from him falling headfirst over the five to six foot gate or because of the necessary force used 
against him. Ebert was transported to Palomar Medical Center for further medical evaluation and treatment. 
(b)(6)(A)

Use of Force Supplemental Instructions 
 
Lines 1 & 3:  Fill in the blanks.  
 
Line 2: If the suspect was committing a crime and force was used to stop or apprehend the subject, document the appropriate penal 
code.  If the UOF occurred in the performance of the officer's duties, document the incident description, i.e. officer transport, officer 
escort, making arrest, detaining suspect, cell extraction etc. 
 
Primary Reason for Using Force: Check appropriate box(s). 
 
Subject Appeared To Be: Check if applicable. 
 
Number of Officers on Scene: List number of officers present.  
 
Number of Officers Using Force: List number of officers that used force. 
 
Level(s) of Resistance Encountered: Check appropriate box(s). 
 
L.E. Tool/Technique Used: Check appropriate box(s).  If known and/or applicable, include duration (approximate length of time) 
tool/technique was used.  If known and/or applicable, include the number of contacts (approximate number of strikes, impacts, etc.) 
when requested on form. 
 
Was Initial Use of Force Effective?  If initial force used was effective, check “Yes.”  If initial force used was ineffective and additional 
force was necessary, check “No.”   
 
Was Additional Control or Force Needed:  If initial force used was ineffective and additional force was necessary, check “Yes.”  If 
initial force used was effective, check “No.”   
 
Target Distance: If applicable (refers primarily to less lethal weapon systems), approximate distance or provide range (i.e. 7-15 feet, 
15-20 yards, etc.) from subject during application of force.   
 
Subject Injured: Check “Yes” if medically treated for injury sustained as a possible result of force applied by a officer(s) – does not 
include previous injuries suffered prior to officer contact.  Check “No” if subject was not injured or simply complains of injury/pain 
suffered as a result of force applied by an officer(s) and refuses medical attention.  Any complaints of pain shall be documented in the 
use of force report narrative (whenever any physical force used by a officer results in a complaint of injury or an injury that necessitates 
medical treatment of a subject, a supervisor will be notified immediately). 
 
Extent of Treatment: Check appropriate box. Check none if subject was evaluated and no treatment was required.  Specifically, check 
“Treated at Scene” if subject was treated at scene by EMS for injuries that may have resulted due to force applied by officer(s).  Check 
“Treated at Hospital” if subject was transported to hospital for treatment of injuries that may have been sustained as an apparent result 
of force applied by officer(s).  Check “Hospitalized” if subject was admitted to the Hospital as a result of injuries that were sustained as 
a result of force applied by officer(s).  
 
Officer Injured:  Check appropriate box (see above).  
 
Extent of Treatment:  Check appropriate box. Check none if officer was evaluated and no treatment was required.  Specifically, check 
“Treated at Scene” if officer was treated at scene by EMS for injuries.  Check “Treated at Hospital” if officer was transported to hospital 
for treatment of injuries.  Check “Hospitalized” if officer was admitted to the Hospital as a result of injuries.   
 
Other Force Used/Comments/Equipment Performance:  This section can be used to document other force options not listed on the 
form; relevant comments about the incident such as complaints of pain/injury (room permitting) and negative/positive comments 
regarding equipment performance.   
 
Mark Figure to Indicate Contact Points: When applicable, mark the areas on the figure where applied force contacted the subject’s 
body.   
 
Sergeant:  Sign, list ARJIS number and date reviewed.  
 
Lieutenant: Sign, list ARJIS number and date reviewed.  
 
Captain: Sign, list ARJIS number and date reviewed.

SYNOPSIS: 
 
On June 9, 2023, SCC Warden (A) Steve Smith submitted a request for a Direct Adverse Action 
(DAA) with a Subject Only Interview (SOI) regarding allegations of on-duty misconduct 
committed by Correctional Officer Brett WOODHAMS (WOODHAMS).  
 
On June 28, 2023, the Office of Internal Affairs (OIA), Central Intake Panel (CIP) approved the 
request for a DAA with a SOI.   
 
On June 29, 2023, I, Special Agent Adam Jimenez, was assigned case responsibility.

Investigation into this matter gathered information to examine the following:

memorandum for overpayment to the Sierra Conservation Center Personnel Office, violating 
CDCR’s Zero Tolerance EEO Policy.

INTERVIEW: 
 
INTERVIEW OF SUBJECT – CORRECTIONAL OFFICER BRETT WOODHAMS 
 
On August 11, 2023, Senior Special Agent (SSA) Jesse Perez and I conducted a digitally recorded 
interview of WOODHAMS (Exhibit 5). WOODHAMS was represented by California Correctional 
Peace Officers Association (CCPOA) Staff Legal Counsel David Sears (Sears). WOODHAMS was 
previously provided an Investigatory Interview Administrative Subject Memorandum (Exhibit 6) and 
was read the Advisement of Rights – Administrative Investigation Form (Exhibit 7). The following is 
my synopsis of the information provided during the interview: 
 
I had WOODHAMS review relevant policies from the Department Operations Manual 
(DOM 31010.1-Equal Employment Opportunity Policy, 
DOM 33030.3.1-Code of Conduct, DOM 33030.3.3-Law Enforcement 
Code of Ethics), as well as Title 15 from the California Code of Regulations (CCR § 
3391 Employee Conduct), which he said he was aware of (Exhibit 8). WOODHAMS 
confirmed he was aware of the expectation of demonstrating honesty, cooperating fully 
with an investigation, and providing truthful statements. 
 
WOODHAMS said he was hired as a correctional officer (CO) in December of 2013, 
and he has worked at SCC during his employment. Around the time of May of 2023, 
WOODHAMS said his regular assignment was
watch, in the Outpatient Health Unit 
(OHU).

written comments on the forms, which were submitted to the Personnel Office, were not 
professional.  
 
WOODHAMS confirmed as a peace officer, he is held to a higher standard. 
WOODHAMS said he regretted writing the comments. WOODHAMS said the 
comments he wrote were not addressed to anyone in particular, and he did not know 
who was going to read them. When asked what he meant when he wrote, “You retards.” 
WOODHAMS explained he meant the incompetence of the Personnel Office about not 
being able to get paid, or reimbursed in a timely manner.  
 
 
 
 
WOODHAM confirmed on or about May 30, 2023, he wrote, “You retards have no clue 
what your doing,” or words to that effect, on his submitted memorandum for 
overpayment to the SCC personnel office, violating CDCR’s Zero Tolerance EEO 
Policy. 
 
 
WOODHAMS said his unprofessional conduct was not normal. WOODHAMS said he 
holds himself to a high standard and he would commit to maintaining high standards as 
a CO.

Nakho who was still sitting inside the locked gated area. I observed the gate to be secured with a pad 
lock and steel cable lock that was not wide enough for me to access. Deputy Peratis informed me that 
Steve was in violation of a temporary restraining order. I asked Deputy Peratis to meet me by the 
secured gate. 
 
While waiting for Deputy Peratis I continued to observe Steve make non-sensical statements and 
exaggerated hand gestures. Once Deputy Peratis arrived at my location, I asked her to retrieve a 
breaching tool in order to access the gated area. I told Steve that he was in violation of a restraining 
order. I told Steve that he needed to listen to all my directions so that he, myself, and/or my partners 
didn't get hurt. An unidentified subject was speaking to Steve whom he called "primo." This subject told 
Steve that he wasn't allowed to be there and that he can't be home. Steve asked me if he could go back 
home, and I told him "no".  
 
Steve then got up and walked towards the fence and looked back at me. I yelled "Steve, don't do it. Do 
not do it, I promise I will chase you." I put out over the radio that I had one subject running northbound 
towards Boll Weevil which initiated a "Code 3" response from my partners in the surrounding area. I 
described the subject as a middle eastern male, shirtless, with black shorts and shoes. I lost visual on 
Steve and asked units to flood the area to check for him. All available Lakeside and Santee units 
responded to assist with the call.   
 
While several units checked the area, Deputy Peratis put out on the radio that she located the subject at 
9739 Winter Gardens Blvd #12. I ran over to assist Deputy Peratis and observed Steve at the top of the 
stairwell in front of #12 and the adjacent unit. The space Steve was standing in was approximately 4 ft X 
5 ft wide. Steve was standing at the top of the stairs and waiving a spatula that could potentially be used 
as blunt object type weapon. Due to the location where this was taking place, I called for a less lethal 
shotgun that was loaded with CTS 2581 Specialty Munitions (Super Sock) in case we needed it. 
Deputies are not trained to fight in stairwells and the situation presented high risk for both deputies and 
Steve who was being verbally non compliant. I decided against using my Conducted Electrical Device 
(CED) in fear that it would cause Steve's muscles to lock up at the top of the stairs and cause him to 
possibly fall face forward. Also decided not to deploy Oleoresin Capsicum (OC) spray due to the small 
working space that it would easily affect deputies as much as Steve.  
 
At about 2049 hours, Sergeant Worthington (6928) arrived on scene near the bottom of the staircase and 
was present while I gave Steve verbal commands. I told Steve that he needed to come down from the 
stair top, that I was with the Sheriff's Department and that he needed to come down. Steve ignored my 
commands and assumed what I perceived as fighting stance by slighting blading his body at the top of 
the stairs, balled up his fists, and flailed around aggressively. Steve continued to scream non sensical 
statements. I told Steve he was under arrest, and he replied. "Fuck you!" I again told Steve that he was 
under arrest and that I did not want him to get hurt. Steve ignored me. I asked Steve if there was 
anything I could do to gain his compliance and come down from the stairs. Steve still ignored me.

Deputy Addenbrooke (0133), Deputy Maxin (7865), Deputy W. Worthington (0363), and Deputy Michel 
(0548) were near me at the bottom of the staircase assisting me with the call. K9 Deputy Simpson (2597) 
and his K9 partner "Maco" also arrived on scene to act as a deterrent and was ready to deploy him if 
needed. Sergeant Worthington told Steve to come down from the stairs with his hands up. Steve ignored 
the commands from Sergeant Worthington. Deputy Michel told Steve to come downstairs, or force may 
be used against him and for him to get on his stomach. Steve did not comply with Deputy Michel's 
warning. Deputy Michel deployed four rounds of specialty munitions. Deputy Michel's first three rounds 
struck Steve but appeared to have little effect. The 4th round struck Steve on his right inner thigh and 
caused him to fall to the ground. (See Deputy Michel's Deputy Report for further detail). Had force not 
been used, deputies and Steve would have been placed in a high-risk environment likely to sustain an 
injury due to the location being the top of the stairs had anyone fallen causing serious injury or possibly 
death.  
 
Upon seeing Steve fall to the ground on his back, I ran up the stairs and attempted to restrain Steve. I 
used both of my hands to grab Steve's left arm and roll him to his stomach in the prone position. Steve 
ignored my commands, tensed his arm and resisted my pull, but I was able to overcome his resistance 
and placed him on his stomach. Once Steve was placed on his stomach, another deputy secured his left 
arm and I saw that Steve was attempting to use his legs to resist being placed flat on the ground. I used 
both of my hands to grab Steve's legs and pulled them straight. I used downward pressure with both of 
my hands on Steve's legs for approximately 1 minute in order to keep them in place while Deputy 
Addenbrooke and Deputy Peratis secured the rest of Steve's body placing his other arm behind his back. 
Deputy W. Worthington and Deputy Addenbrooke were able to secure Steve in handcuffs. (See Deputy 
Peratis, and Deputy Addenbrooke's Deputy's Report for further detail). Deputy Addenbrooke and Deputy 
Peratis sat Steve up and assisted him to his feet. Deputy Addenbrooke and Deputy Peratis escorted 
Steve out of the stairwell and began to walk him over to a marked patrol car. Had I not used force, Steve 
may have continued to be uncooperative or attempted to continue to evade putting himself, the public, 
and deputies at risk of further injury while attempting to take Steve into custody during a high-risk 
incident.  
 
While Deputy Addenbrooke and Deputy Peratis were escorting Steve to a patrol car, I observed he 
began to drop his body weight, pulling away from them, and resisted being escorted. Deputy 
Addenbrooke and Deputy Peratis utilized a hammer lock technique on Steve in order to escort him safely 
and quickly to a nearby vehicle. Steve continued to resist by dropping his body weight. Deputies decided

didn't get hurt. An unidentified subject was speaking to Steve whom he called "primo." This subject told 
Steve that he wasn't allowed to be there and that he can't be home. Steve asked me if he could go back 
home, and I told him "no".  
 
Steve then got up and walked towards the fence and looked back at me. I yelled "Steve, don't do it. Do 
not do it, I promise I will chase you." I put out over the radio that I had one subject running northbound 
towards Boll Weevil which initiated a "Code 3" response from my partners in the surrounding area. I 
described the subject as a middle eastern male, shirtless, with black shorts and shoes. I lost visual on 
Steve and asked units to flood the area to check for him. All available Lakeside and Santee units 
responded to assist with the call.   
 
While several units checked the area, Deputy Peratis put out on the radio that she located the subject at 
9739 Winter Gardens Blvd #12. I ran over to assist Deputy Peratis and observed Steve at the top of the 
stairwell in front of #12 and the adjacent unit. The space Steve was standing in was approximately 4 ft X 
5 ft wide. Steve was standing at the top of the stairs and waiving a spatula that could potentially be used 
as blunt object type weapon. Due to the location where this was taking place, I called for a less lethal 
shotgun that was loaded with CTS 2581 Specialty Munitions (Super Sock) in case we needed it. 
Deputies are not trained to fight in stairwells and the situation presented high risk for both deputies and 
Steve who was being verbally non compliant. I decided against using my Conducted Electrical Device 
(CED) in fear that it would cause Steve's muscles to lock up at the top of the stairs and cause him to 
possibly fall face forward. Also decided not to deploy Oleoresin Capsicum (OC) spray due to the small 
working space that it would easily affect deputies as much as Steve.  
 
At about 2049 hours, Sergeant Worthington (6928) arrived on scene near the bottom of the staircase and 
was present while I gave Steve verbal commands. I told Steve that he needed to come down from the 
stair top, that I was with the Sheriff's Department and that he needed to come down. Steve ignored my 
commands and assumed what I perceived as fighting stance by slighting blading his body at the top of 
the stairs, balled up his fists, and flailed around aggressively. Steve continued to scream non sensical 
statements. I told Steve he was under arrest, and he replied. "Fuck you!" I again told Steve that he was 
under arrest and that I did not want him to get hurt. Steve ignored me. I asked Steve if there was 
anything I could do to gain his compliance and come down from the stairs. Steve still ignored me.  
 
Deputy Addenbrooke (0133), Deputy Maxin (7865), Deputy W. Worthington (0363), and Deputy Michel

needed. Sergeant Worthington told Steve to come down from the stairs with his hands up. Steve ignored 
the commands from Sergeant Worthington. Deputy Michel told Steve to come downstairs, or force may 
be used against him and for him to get on his stomach. Steve did not comply with Deputy Michel's 
warning. Deputy Michel deployed four rounds of specialty munitions. Deputy Michel's first three rounds 
struck Steve but appeared to have little effect. The 4th round struck Steve on his right inner thigh and 
caused him to fall to the ground. (See Deputy Michel's Deputy Report for further detail). Had force not 
been used, deputies and Steve would have been placed in a high-risk environment likely to sustain an

Seeing Nakho's behavior, actions and taking his prior history with deputies into consideration, we believed Nakho would be 
combative towards deputies. It was determined to use a CTS 2581 (Super Sock) specialty munitions shotgun in order to 
safely take Nakho into custody.  
 
I informed Nakho he needed to comply, or force would be used against him. I gave a final command for Nakho to lay down on 
the ground and Nakho ignored my commands. I then fired one super sock round with the Less Lethal Shotgun towards 
Nakho's lower left abdomen. The round had no effect on Nakho. Nahko continued his erratic behavior as he held on to the 
spatula. I fired a second super sock round towards Nakho's lower left abdomen and fired a third super sock towards Nakho's 
left upper thigh, as I gave verbal commands to Nakho to get on the ground. The first three deployments had minor effects on 
Nakho as he continued his erratic behavior. I then fired a fourth super sock round towards Nakho's inner right thigh causing 
Nakho to fall to the ground. At this time, deputies ran toward Nakho to take him into custody. I rendered the less lethal 
shotgun safe, and I had no further contact or involvement in taking Nakho into custody.  
 
The force used on scene was used to effect an arrest and necessary during the high-risk incident. Had I not used the level of 
force I did, it would have only led to further disorder forcing me to use a higher degree of force than needed in the first 
instance. Using a specialty munitions shotgun was the best option we had considering Nakho's erratic and assaultive 
behavior. 
 
Photos were later take of Steve and logged into Evidence at the Lkeside Station.

Use of Force Supplemental Instructions 
 
Lines 1 & 3:  Fill in the blanks.  
 
Line 2: If the suspect was committing a crime and force was used to stop or apprehend the subject, document the appropriate penal 
code.  If the UOF occurred in the performance of the officer's duties, document the incident description, i.e. officer transport, officer 
escort, making arrest, detaining suspect, cell extraction etc. 
 
Primary Reason for Using Force: Check appropriate box(s). 
 
Subject Appeared To Be: Check if applicable. 
 
Number of Officers on Scene: List number of officers present.  
 
Number of Officers Using Force: List number of officers that used force. 
 
Level(s) of Resistance Encountered: Check appropriate box(s). 
 
L.E. Tool/Technique Used: Check appropriate box(s).  If known and/or applicable, include duration (approximate length of time) 
tool/technique was used.  If known and/or applicable, include the number of contacts (approximate number of strikes, impacts, etc.) 
when requested on form. 
 
Was Initial Use of Force Effective?  If initial force used was effective, check “Yes.”  If initial force used was ineffective and additional 
force was necessary, check “No.”   
 
Was Additional Control or Force Needed:  If initial force used was ineffective and additional force was necessary, check “Yes.”  If 
initial force used was effective, check “No.”   
 
Target Distance: If applicable (refers primarily to less lethal weapon systems), approximate distance or provide range (i.e. 7-15 feet, 
15-20 yards, etc.) from subject during application of force.   
 
Subject Injured: Check “Yes” if medically treated for injury sustained as a possible result of force applied by a officer(s) – does not 
include previous injuries suffered prior to officer contact.  Check “No” if subject was not injured or simply complains of injury/pain 
suffered as a result of force applied by an officer(s) and refuses medical attention.  Any complaints of pain shall be documented in the 
use of force report narrative (whenever any physical force used by a officer results in a complaint of injury or an injury that necessitates 
medical treatment of a subject, a supervisor will be notified immediately). 
 
Extent of Treatment: Check appropriate box. Check none if subject was evaluated and no treatment was required.  Specifically, check 
“Treated at Scene” if subject was treated at scene by EMS for injuries that may have resulted due to force applied by officer(s).  Check 
“Treated at Hospital” if subject was transported to hospital for treatment of injuries that may have been sustained as an apparent result 
of force applied by officer(s).  Check “Hospitalized” if subject was admitted to the Hospital as a result of injuries that were sustained as 
a result of force applied by officer(s).  
 
Officer Injured:  Check appropriate box (see above).  
 
Extent of Treatment:  Check appropriate box. Check none if officer was evaluated and no treatment was required.  Specifically, check 
“Treated at Scene” if officer was treated at scene by EMS for injuries.  Check “Treated at Hospital” if officer was transported to hospital 
for treatment of injuries.  Check “Hospitalized” if officer was admitted to the Hospital as a result of injuries.   
 
Other Force Used/Comments/Equipment Performance:  This section can be used to document other force options not listed on the 
form; relevant comments about the incident such as complaints of pain/injury (room permitting) and negative/positive comments 
regarding equipment performance.   
 
Mark Figure to Indicate Contact Points: When applicable, mark the areas on the figure where applied force contacted the subject’s 
body.   
 
Sergeant:  Sign, list ARJIS number and date reviewed.  
 
Lieutenant: Sign, list ARJIS number and date reviewed.  
 
Captain: Sign, list ARJIS number and date reviewed.

During this time, I used the ankle strap to safely wrap Nakho's ankles, so he could not kick and flail his legs anymore.  After 
safely applying the ankle strap to Nakho's legs, I assisted Deputy Paulino (#0288) in securing Nakho's legs with the lower leg 
portion of the "WRAP." 
 
Once secured in the lower portion of the "WRAP", I assisted Deputy Peratis (#0720) in securing Nakho in the upper body 
portion of the "WRAP."  I assisted in pulling the upper body portion of the "WRAP" over Nakho's head, securing and synching 
the right-side strap, and leaning Nakho forward, securing the front buckle and strap so Nakho would safely be fully secured in 
the "WRAP" and unable to roll around or flail his body and preventing him from causing injury to him or any Deputies.   
 
Once Nakho was safely secured in the "WRAP," I did not have any more involvement with Nakho.   
 
I believe if the force used had not been used, Nakho could have continued to kick, bite or spit on me or other Deputies present 
causing injuries to myself or other Deputies. If the "WRAP" had not been placed on Nakho's person, he could have continued 
to struggle with Deputies making it difficult for them and medics to treat him properly and safely take him into custody.  I 
believe the "WRAP" was necessary due to Nakho's aggressive behavior and unwillingness to cooperate with Deputies on 
scene. Nakho could have further injured tried to injure myself or other Deputies on scene if he had not been placed in the 
"WRAP" and to avoid a future use of force with Nakho's person while at the residence. The "WRAP" minimizes the amount of 
movement he could have to further hurt myself or other Deputies on scene. 
 
Sergeant Worthington (#6928) was on scene throughout the incident. There is body worn camera (BWC) video of the incident.  
Photos were taken of Nakho and later logged into evidence at the Lakeside Station.

Use of Force Supplemental Instructions 
 
Lines 1 & 3:  Fill in the blanks.  
 
Line 2: If the suspect was committing a crime and force was used to stop or apprehend the subject, document the appropriate penal 
code.  If the UOF occurred in the performance of the officer's duties, document the incident description, i.e. officer transport, officer 
escort, making arrest, detaining suspect, cell extraction etc. 
 
Primary Reason for Using Force: Check appropriate box(s). 
 
Subject Appeared To Be: Check if applicable. 
 
Number of Officers on Scene: List number of officers present.  
 
Number of Officers Using Force: List number of officers that used force. 
 
Level(s) of Resistance Encountered: Check appropriate box(s). 
 
L.E. Tool/Technique Used: Check appropriate box(s).  If known and/or applicable, include duration (approximate length of time) 
tool/technique was used.  If known and/or applicable, include the number of contacts (approximate number of strikes, impacts, etc.) 
when requested on form. 
 
Was Initial Use of Force Effective?  If initial force used was effective, check “Yes.”  If initial force used was ineffective and additional 
force was necessary, check “No.”   
 
Was Additional Control or Force Needed:  If initial force used was ineffective and additional force was necessary, check “Yes.”  If 
initial force used was effective, check “No.”   
 
Target Distance: If applicable (refers primarily to less lethal weapon systems), approximate distance or provide range (i.e. 7-15 feet, 
15-20 yards, etc.) from subject during application of force.   
 
Subject Injured: Check “Yes” if medically treated for injury sustained as a possible result of force applied by a officer(s) – does not 
include previous injuries suffered prior to officer contact.  Check “No” if subject was not injured or simply complains of injury/pain 
suffered as a result of force applied by an officer(s) and refuses medical attention.  Any complaints of pain shall be documented in the 
use of force report narrative (whenever any physical force used by a officer results in a complaint of injury or an injury that necessitates 
medical treatment of a subject, a supervisor will be notified immediately). 
 
Extent of Treatment: Check appropriate box. Check none if subject was evaluated and no treatment was required.  Specifically, check 
“Treated at Scene” if subject was treated at scene by EMS for injuries that may have resulted due to force applied by officer(s).  Check 
“Treated at Hospital” if subject was transported to hospital for treatment of injuries that may have been sustained as an apparent result 
of force applied by officer(s).  Check “Hospitalized” if subject was admitted to the Hospital as a result of injuries that were sustained as 
a result of force applied by officer(s).  
 
Officer Injured:  Check appropriate box (see above).  
 
Extent of Treatment:  Check appropriate box. Check none if officer was evaluated and no treatment was required.  Specifically, check 
“Treated at Scene” if officer was treated at scene by EMS for injuries.  Check “Treated at Hospital” if officer was transported to hospital 
for treatment of injuries.  Check “Hospitalized” if officer was admitted to the Hospital as a result of injuries.   
 
Other Force Used/Comments/Equipment Performance:  This section can be used to document other force options not listed on the 
form; relevant comments about the incident such as complaints of pain/injury (room permitting) and negative/positive comments 
regarding equipment performance.   
 
Mark Figure to Indicate Contact Points: When applicable, mark the areas on the figure where applied force contacted the subject’s 
body.   
 
Sergeant:  Sign, list ARJIS number and date reviewed.  
 
Lieutenant: Sign, list ARJIS number and date reviewed.  
 
Captain: Sign, list ARJIS number and date reviewed.

immediately began resisting by pulling his arms away from Deputy Trevino and Deputy Peratis. I pulled Steve's legs toward 
me to flatten his posture. I then went to Steve's right side, used my left knee to put downward pressure on his lower back for 
approximately 30 seconds. I grabbed his left arm and put it behind his back. Deputy Worthington #0363 placed handcuffs on 
his left wrist as I grabbed his right. I reached under Steve's right arm and pulled it behind his back which I could feel him 
resisting by trying to push his arm forward. I was able to overcome the resistance and handcuff his right wrist behind his back. 
Once Steve was handcuffed, he was escorted down the stairs, toward the patrol vehicle. Steve started to resist again by not 
wanting to walk forward. I used downward pressure on the back of his head and pulled him forward in order to keep him 
walking. 
 
It was decided it would be safer and easier to place Steve in a WRAP device. Steve was taken to the ground and a WRAP 
device was applied with Sergeant Worthington as the safety officer. Deputy Maxin assisted with the leg restraints, and I 
assisted with the body harness. I used downward pressure on Steve's back and back of his head to push him forward to apply 
the WRAP device correctly and firmly. Steve was placed in an upright position until medics came. At this time, I had no further 
contact with Steve.  
 
I used this level of force with Steve because he was already told multiple times he was under arrest and had to come down 
the stairs. Steve responded with "Fuck you!", and was still holding the spatula, all while standing on a small platform at the top 
of a stairwell. We do not train any defense tactics on stairwells because it is a very dangerous thing to do. Steve was under 
the influence a controlled substance and his response and behavior portrayed he was not going to comply with our commands 
which he would resist our efforts to arrest him. Had I not used the level of force I did at the top of the stairwell, as quick and as 
hard as I did, it would have only led to further disorder forcing me to use a higher degree of force than needed in the first 
instance. Using a specialty munitions shotgun was the best option we had. A conducted energy device would have caused 
Steve to lose all control and would have fallen down the stairwell which could have caused a fatal injury. Using oleoresin 
capsicum (OC) spray would have only contaminated the entire area making a completely unsafe to enter to make an arrest. 
The decisions we made quickly gained control over Steve to make the arrest quickly.  
 
Photos were taken of Steve and later logged into Evidence at the Lakeside Station. 
 
This concluded my portion of the investigation.
